PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 May, on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the House that there be a cognate debate on this Bill, the Corporations Bill, the Corporations (Fees) Bill, the Securities Exchanges (Application for Membership) Fidelity Funds Contribution Bill, the Securities Exchanges (Membership) Fidelity Funds Contribution Bill, the Securities Exchanges Fidelity Funds Levy Bill, the National Guarantee Fund (Reportable Transactions) Levy Bill, the National Guarantee Fund (Participating Exchanges) Levy Bill, the National Guarantee Fund (Members of Participating Exchanges) Levy Bill, the Futures Organisations (Application for Membership) Fidelity Funds Contribution Bill, the Futures Organisations (Membership) Fidelity Funds Contribution Bill, the Futures Organisations Fidelity Funds Levy Bill, the Close Corporations Bill, the Close Corporations (Fees) Bill, the Close Corporations (Liquidators' Recovery Trust Fund Contribution) Bill, and the Close Corporations (Additional Liquidators' Recovery Trust Fund Contribution) Bill? There being no objection, that course will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I introduced the Australian Securities Commission Bill and the two subsequent Bills on 25 May 1988 on the basis that they were to lie on the table over the winter recess to allow public exposure and examination of the Bills. In my second reading speech I foreshadowed and welcomed continuing consultation with the business community up to the passage of the legislation and referred to the role of my Companies and Securities Consultative Group in this process. Since that time there has been extensive consultation on the legislation. Many business organisations, such as the stock exchange and the Sydney Futures Exchange, have written or spoken to me on the legislation. The Consultative Group called for and received public submissions. It has rigorously and closely examined the legislation and considered the concerns raised by many business organisations and professionals such as the Unit Trust Association. I would like to again record my appreciation for the work of the Group.

SPEECH.PARA: The overall response of the business community has been very supportive of the legislation. As a result of discussions with the business community and others, the practical operation of the legislation has been improved. These improvements will require amendments that will be moved in the committee stage of the debate. I will deal with the amendments in more detail in the committee stage. However, they can be generally categorised as follows:

Amendments to the fund raising provisions of the Bill to clarify their operation, to increase protection for investors in respect of certain classes of fund raising and to identify those situations where prospectuses are not required.

Amendments to ameliorate some unintended consequences of reforms which were to clarify and rectify some technical anomalies in the takeover provisions, the securities recommendations provisions and the licensing provisions of the cooperative scheme legislation.
Amendments to bring administrative law elements of the Bills into conformity with Commonwealth practice.
Amendments to clarify the role and power of the Australian Securities Commission; and

Amendments to the futures industry provisions, which I foreshadowed at the time of the introduction of the Bills, to minimise any disruption as a result of the constitutional underpinnings of those provisions.

The House would know that originally the Senate had a committee dealing with the companies and securities proposal and recommended legislation. I have been advised that the Senate wishes to have the Bills further examined and, for that purpose, proposes to establish a joint parliamentary committee. I understand the Senate does not object to the Bills in the sense that they establish a national companies scheme but, rather, wishes to satisfy itself that the drafting adequately provides for efficient capital markets while providing appropriate safeguards for investors. The stock exchange has written to me offering its support to the secretariat of such a committee.

I have no objection to the proposal but, at the same time, I am anxious that this House have a chance to participate in any committee review of that nature. I am told that this creates some practical problems in the sense that it would appear that we do not readily have a capacity to move a motion here unless the respective committees agree to set up such a joint proposal. So I have in mind that, when the House deals with these matters, they will go to the Senate on the basis that the Senate will then refer them to the appropriate committee. That committee would then liaise with a standing committee of this House to set up a joint committee composed not of all the members of the respective committees but representatives of them so that they can take evidence and report back at the conclusion of that period, which I hope will not be beyond February next year.

I also mention that, because of the nature of the background to this legislation there has been cooperation and continual discussions with my ministerial colleagues in the States. Recently I received a letter from one of the State Attorneys-General suggesting a special meeting of the Ministerial Council again to discuss the legislation. I would like to inform my colleague the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) that it has been agreed there will be such a meeting in Sydney on 1 November this year to discuss this legislation.

I thank the House for its cooperation. I wanted honourable members to know the position so that there is no doubt about the fact that I want more scrutiny of the Bills and, of course, the business community would like to be participating in that. Honourable members would have noticed that it even wanted to be involved with the secretariat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments made by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) only add to the confusion which surrounds the total package of legislation before us today. In fact, he has just said that on 1 November there will be a meeting of the Ministerial Council at which this legislation will be discussed. The implication of that is that it does not matter what we pass here or what is referred to any committee or the Senate as the legislation will go to the Ministerial Council and the members of the Ministerial Council will then say, `We think you ought to have these changes', whatever the changes may be. So back to the drawing board goes the Attorney-General and he livens up the session with a few more amendments and we try it again. That is the implication of what the Attorney-General has just said.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know how the Attorney-General runs his business. He must have been a good mayor in the Kingsford-Smith electorate, but the way in which he runs the corporations and securities legislation which is before us is nothing short of scandalous. Yesterday afternoon 27 pages detailing 280 amendments were dumped on my doorstep. At 5.30 last night, while some officers were briefing me on these matters, the Attorney-General rang me and said, `We are going to call on all the amendments tomorrow', contrary to earlier advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course we can do it.

—If you think that you can take in 280 amendments, successfully understand them, and put them into legislation in 12 hours, you should not be sitting here; you should be a justice of the High Court of Australia. This is an absolutely impossible situation and it characterises the whole presentation of this corporations package of legislation. There has been no consultation around Australia. A small group of faceless men were picked to sit on that committee on the basis of their being agreeable to this legislation. What happened when these amendments came out last night? Two members of the Companies and Securities Consultative Group rang me and asked me what the amendments were.
—Order! Would the honourable member for Ryan speak through the Chair and not across the table. The Attorney-General will cease interjecting.

—Those two members of the Consultative Group were obviously so well informed that they did not know what was in the amendments. They rang me to find out what was going on. In terms of the consultation process that went on, we have a small steering committee with six or seven members-people who are all highly connected with big business who were involved in the so-called consultative process. There were a number of satellite committees around the place, but my information is that they met only twice. It was the steering committee which had the most to say. When the Attorney introduced this package to the House in May and let it sit on the table, there was a great scurry because we had to pull out from the package a number of unintended consequences. Most of those unintended consequences went to the personal liability of members of the steering committee in relation to the legislation. They were quick to the draw: they were looking for points with respect to personal liability and not the overall law consequences at all. So they telephoned the Attorney-General and said, `You're a good guy, Lionel; you must get us off the hook on these things.' As a result, out came the amendments; but there was no consultation around Australia in relation to them.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact the Attorney did such a good job that he consented to attend a meeting in Brisbane, which was advertised all around the countryside:
Legislate or cooperate.
Don't miss this debate.
Of vital importance to company directors.

The meeting was scheduled for 18 August from 9 a.m. until noon at the Sheraton Hotel, and admission was $40 for non-members, which is a high price to pay to listen to the Attorney-General. Nevertheless, 24 hours before the lunch it was cancelled. Why was it called off? The Attorney called it off because he did not want to go to Queensland and discuss what was happening in relation to company law. You cannot deny that: it is a fact of life.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member will speak through the Chair, please.
—You are still not right, John.

—It is a fact of life. The lunch did not go on. The Attorney was due there and never showed up. So, in terms of consultation, the whole matter falls to the ground. There is no public demand around Australia for massive changes in corporate law-none at all. Certainly some weaknesses have developed in the eight years that we have had the cooperative scheme. There have been some weaknesses in the administration and some aspects in relation to company names; and there have been some aspects in relation to computer compatibility. However, there is no reason to change the whole company law because of some management structural problems. That is all it is. Any manager can sort out computer problems, naming rights, and so on. Instead of that, we have this massive package of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the hidden agenda? What is the real reason behind all this? It is the fact that Labor has always wanted to have its hands around the throat of business through the corporate structure. By doing that it can ultimately implement through the corporate structure the recommendations of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) paper Australia Reconstructed and achieve some of its other Fabian desires. That would not happen with Mr Nice Guy, the Attorney-General. I know the Attorney would not want to do those things, but there are a few mad hatters in his Party who would, and they make no bones about it. Senator Gareth Evans had some quaint things to say about corporate law in Australia. If the Government goes down the line of centralising power, as proposed in these amendments, ultimately the ACTU will ring up and say, `Hey, we want some people on the board of that company' or, `We want access to superannuation funds for all sorts of reasons' or, `We want to know all about the remuneration paid to various people within the companies'.

Ultimately behind all this is the old Fabian desire to grab the neck of corporate Australia. It is the greatest grab for power by the central government of Australia without holding a referendum since the Constitution was first brought down, and the Attorney-General knows that as well as I do. In fact, I would think that after the last referendum the Attorney would not be looking around for too many more. The last referendum cost Australian taxpayers $46m. Yet it was only the Government and a substantial number of the Press Gallery who believed that the questions would be passed. I refer the Attorney-General to an editorial which appeared in the Australian Financial Review after the referendum. It stressed that people should not build monuments to themselves. Now that the referendum has fallen down, I guess we are now seeing the Lionel Bowen retirement memorial in the form of these corporate changes.

It is worth looking at some of the real problems. Firstly, let us look at the constitutional validity. The legislation has been drafted so that as many heads of power, even those with only remote connections, are dragged into it. Even the draftsmen of this Bill apparently harbour grave doubts about its constitutionality. The legislation produces several overlapping provisions. In the event that any one provision is ruled invalid, it may be severed but others will remain standing. It is all right for the draftsmen but what about the practitioners who have had to wade their way through these convoluted and misguided clauses?

I ought to refer here to the football case of Western Australia in which Sir Garfield Barwick, the Chief Justice at the time, warned against this type of draughting. He said that it was no doubt convenient for Parliament and the parliamentary draftsman to avoid the risk of unconstitutionality by using statutory definitions expressed in terms of the relevant constitutional power, but in the long run such a course may well prove highly inconvenient and costly to those affected by the statute, in this case the Australian business community. I think that those things ought to be well and truly looked at.

On top of that we ought to look at the basis of some of these actions, which are based largely on the Byers opinion. According to the front page of the Australian, Byers said that we were in a very dangerous economic position. He said that the only way out of it was for the Constitution to be altered to give the Commonwealth Government control over industrial relations, incorporation of companies, and trading and financial and other markets.

This clearly indicates that his overall optimistic legal opinion cannot be relied upon. If the Constitution must be altered to regulate trading and financial markets, why is the Government attempting to do just that here today without a referendum? The original legal opinion upon which this legislation is based is now off the rails. In his opinion Byers included mining, manufacturing companies, real estate and trustee companies but excluded recreational, scientific, education and charitable companies. Once one admits, as Byers has, that not every company is a trading or financial corporation, each company must then be examined on its own merits in the courtroom to see what category it falls into. These loopholes are everywhere and cannot by plugged.

This legislation will lead to a consti- tutional minefield of separate Commonwealth and State legislation with consistent questioning and inherent doubts about where a company should be properly constituted. One particularly difficult category relates to companies which cannot carry on business activities and act as holding companies. There are hundreds of listed companies which fall into this category. Uncertainty will arise where a body corporate is clearly not a trading corporation and does not carry on interstate business-for example, building societies and friendly societies.

The Attorney-General has openly welcomed a challenge to this legislation. That is a fine state of affairs. Litigation may take years, at a terrific cost to business, and all the while the business community will be operating in a climate of uncertainty. For example, a ruling that a company simply does not exist because the law under which it was incorporated is constitutionally invalid would be catastrophic to trade and commerce in Australia. In the first royal commission into the Constitution in 1926 Sir Owen Dixon said that it may be doubted whether a power which would extend to regulating all activities and affecting all transactions so long as they are carried on, entered into or performed by companies is a desirable one and that short of this it is difficult to confer power which will be sufficient for all purposes of company legislation. Dixon's words seem to me to have a ring of solidarity to them today as they did in those times. He said that he could not overestimate the seriousness of the constitutional question as it relates to these matters.

There is a great parallel between the actions taken here in relation to this corporate legislation package and the actions taken in relation to the taxation legislation. The Bills before us today are most complex and certainly voluminous. The legislation is over three inches thick, over 3,000 pages and constitutes a complete rewrite-not just adjustments-of company law as we know it today. The legislation is dwarfed only by the almighty tax legislation. The Attorney-General might insist that that is not so, but I would challenge him. Even informed analysts conversant with the existing provisions of the Companies Code are finding that there is insufficient time to analyse the Bills. The absence of any draft regulations makes it impossible to comment on any provisions that are heavily reliant on the regulations, making any adequate analysis impossible at this point. Terminology which has been built up over the years and relied upon by practitioners has suddenly been turned upside down by draftsmen in the Attorney- General's Department. It is a definition-driven Bill.

If I were allowed the time to do so, I could take honourable members through one of the definitions to show just how complex this legislation is. There are no fewer than 26 new definitions of companies alone. The sheer size and complexity of the legislation will lead to commercial uncertainty and will substantially increase compliance costs for business. Like the tax Act, users will not know whether to follow the spirit or the letter of the law. The tax laws and company laws need to be clear so that there is no contradiction between the spirit and the letter of the law. Companies are entitled to know precisely what their obligations are and to seek interpretations through the courts.

I turn to some of the aspects of the companies and securities legislation. As I have said, I have read all 1,350 clauses. However, I am far from being an expert on them. The more I look at the legislation the more difficulties I see in it. Be that as it may, I have identified a number of areas which are of great significance. First, I mention the subject of plain English. There are difficulties with what is termed the plain English style of drafting in relation to this legislation. At this stage nobody knows what effect the changes in drafting will have on what is now well-settled law. The uncertainty that this will cause in the business community cannot be measured at this time. It is something that will come to the fore after the legislation is debated and implemented. Secondly, in regard to applications for registration, chapter 2 deals with the constitution of companies and in particular four different types of companies. First is the division 1 company, a new company incorporated under the legislation. Then there is the division 2 company, which is a company incorporated under the existing companies code of a State which must transfer its incorporation under the national companies legislation. Division 3 relates to a foreign company, a corporation incorporated to operate in Australia or its external territories which wishes to transfer its incorporation to Australia. Division 4 relates to a close corporation which wishes to convert to company status.

There are difficulties with each of these companies. However, referring specifically to division 2 companies, we are talking about companies currently registered under the various State codes. Under the national companies legislation these companies must make application for registration after the legislation becomes law. I do not know the exact number of companies in Australia, but they certainly run to hundreds of thousands. However, I suggest that this new requirement will involve thousands and thousands of applications under the new process and the time and cost to industry will be enormous. Thirdly, I refer to activity statements. The application must also be lodged with what is to be termed an activity statement. A company is required to lodge an activity statement every 12 months. This is in addition to the annual return which is currently to be lodged.

This extra piece of paper or regulation has been introduced on nothing other than constitutional grounds to establish a sufficient nexus between the particular company and the corporations powers under the Constitution-that is to say, by filing the activity statement a company will need to disclose whether it is either a trading or a financial corporation to prove that it is carrying on activities which would make it such. The difficulty that arises in respect of the activity statement is that where one has a company which may be more than a holding or investment company-it is neither a holding company nor a financial corporation-such a company would find itself in a state of limbo. Indeed, the legislation seems to acknowledge this in acknowledging that companies will become dormant from time to time. On a literal reading of the legislation it would seem that if one has a company which becomes dormant for more than three months it is duty bound to be wound up. With respect, that appears to be ridiculous.

Clauses 810 to 816 of the Corporations Bill provide for a new register of all persons who hold proper authorities from the licensee to be kept by dealers and investment advisers. The register shall be in writing and shall contain a copy of the proper authority. While this register of proper authorities will indicate who is empowered to act as a representative, it will not deal with the problem of evidence as to whether a particular action occurred within a representative's power of agency. In regard to this provision Butterworths Company Law, No. 8 of 1988, states:

One wonders whether the new structure will be seen as so unwieldy and complicated that it will be preferable to persist with the old system of licensing the representatives. The cost to dealers and investment advisers of maintaining the register of proper authorities will be significant and will involve a great deal of paperwork.

And so it goes on throughout the entire process. While the explanatory memorandum states that the acquisition of shares code provisions are more logical and simplified, there are many clauses that go against this completely. In terms of vetting, we have seen an attempt not only to abolish part A statements, but also to eliminate the vetting of prospectuses. The amendments brought forward last night change that. I am yet to fully examine the consequence of those changes. In terms of the part A statements, which currently are required to be submitted to the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC), under the new provisions companies will get 24 hours to ensure that the appropriate people have signed them and they have been sent out. There is no liability on the NCSC, or the proposed Australian Securities Commission, to take responsibility for what is in there. That responsibility is pushed back onto the experts.

I will press on to some of what I call the other amazing areas that have been brought up. We find that there are to be set up an advisory committee, a panel and the Australian Securities Commission (ASC)-three new bodies. The Securities Commission apparently will take over the day to day workings of the NCSC. It will have no policy role. That apparently was advocated by the Attorney-General's Department. An advisory committee has been set up. It will be hand-picked by the Attorney-General and, I was informed by departmental officials in my briefing yesterday, will have its own secretariat. The amount of money involved is unstated. This committee is due to advise the Minister on all matters relating to corporate law.

Madam Speaker, I draw your attention to the classic Yes, Minister case: members of the Consultative Committee come to town, are picked up in a Commonwealth car, and are taken for morning tea with Lionel. They tell him what a great job he is doing in this area, and say, `Thank you very much for putting us on this committee. It all helps us down the track in Pitt Street and Collins Street. However, there are one or two things we would like put into the legislation that you might consider'. Out of the door, into the Commonwealth car, and home they go. The first person through the Attorney-General's office the next morning is the Secretary to the Department. There are no greater protectors of empires than departmental secretaries. The Attorney-General knows that as well as I do. They are the first to defend their ground. Three points have been brought up by this Consultative Committee, and they all make good sense. The Secretary says to the Attorney-General, `The first point is not bad; we are already looking at that. We have a committee looking at the second point, and I think we will tack it onto the other Bill that will be brought in next week. The third point is really not relevant; we will not have any more of that'. `Yes', says the Attorney, `that is quite right'. He is too busy to worry about those types of things.

The Secretary will win hands down. The Attorney knows that as well as I do. This advisory group may be great window dressing. It may give something to all members of the advisory committee to beat up their egos, but the realities are different: company law in Australia will be captured by the Attorney-General's Department. There are many fine lawyers there, but I am yet to concede-and I will never concede-that corporate law in Australia is best run from Canberra. Any person who has been a practitioner in the area of securities or banking will tell us that the activities taking place in Pitt Street or Collins Street are far more up to date, totally contemporary, and relate to the international scene. It takes a long time for policy items from those areas to be caught up with here in Canberra.

The area of the panel is another matter which should be looked at. The concept is that the Australian Securities Commission can act only as a policeman-going around, delving and making various inquiries. Then it must seek an audience with the panel in order to make a declaration as to whether the activities are unbecoming. When members of the panel eventually come together and the submission is put forward to the Commission, time has gone by. The essence of the financial market is decisions. A decision must be made as the situation arises. It cannot be allowed to drift down the track for six months or even a month as appears to be the case in this legislation. I might be wrong about that but that is my impression. While I hope that the panel system will work-it has a relationship to the position in London-there are examples which I believe will cause some trouble in the future particularly in relation to the need for speed. There is also a tremendous need for market practitioners to be involved in the panel. There is no point at all in having on the panel people who are unrelated to the market attempting to make decisions in this area.

I want to skip through this huge package and finally say a few words about the steering committee. The Attorney-General said in introducing this legislation that the steering committee had sought wide consultation. I am led to believe that the committee received only 20 submissions, of which only 18 were relevant. That was despite all the advertisements placed in the newspapers. This is the great way in which the Government attempts to bring about these amendments to our law-18 submissions as a result of advertisements all around the countryside. Yet the Attorney-General sweeps in here and tells us that there is such great control. No attempt has been made to get widespread support for or understanding of this matter and there has been no attempt at all to ensure that users, outside a small group, are in any way associated with the remarks that have been made. As a consequence, I wish to move the amendment that has been circulated in my name. I move:

That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that all of the Securities Bills and the circulated amendments of the Government should be referred to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which should confer with a similar committee of the Senate.'.

In moving that amendment, the Opposition wants to see the whole package of Bills canvassed around Australia properly so that people have time to consider the components of the amendments put forward and the real aspects of them. So many areas have been undiscussed. There are so many areas of Australia-as the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) would know because in his part of Australia this legislation is not wanted-which want to see this Committee going around Australia interviewing people in Perth, Adelaide, Hobart and Brisbane and hearing what they think about the legislation. This is not a unitary country; it is a federation. The Attorney-General might live in Sydney and think that everything is okay, but people do not live by Sydney alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nor Brisbane.

—No, but it is better than New South Wales. As a consequence of that, the proposal we are putting forward in our amendment would be in the best interests of the Australian business community. In looking at these matters, the Opposition would like the Bills to be considered not only in relation to the new law that has been brought about but also as they relate to the continuing operation of the cooperative schemes in company law. This has been brought about over an eight-year period during which many benefits have flowed. The Opposition seeks to continue the cooperative arrangements as they relate to company law.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there has developed in Australia a need for some upgrading of the takeover code as it relates to the securities industry. In that period we have seen the development of the Australian Stock Exchange in which the various capital cities' stock exchanges-the Australian Stock Exchange, Brisbane, the Australian Stock Exchange, Melbourne, the Australian Stock Exchange, Perth and so on-have formed into one body. As a consequence of that they have been able to achieve a harmony in the Stock Exchange which frankly I would not have thought possible from my days as a member of a committee of one stock exchange. Irrelevant jealousies between Sydney, Melbourne and the rest of the provincial capitals meant it just did not seem at all possible.

It seems to me that when this committee reviews these matters it ought to look at the relationship that has developed and see whether there is a role for a Federal law pertaining to the takeover of companies-to the takeover code itself, not company law. I draw that distinction. We might well find that the takeover code and the associated interest might be best placed in the Federal structure. But certainly that does not apply to company law. As a consequence of such action we would be ruling out some of the activities that State governments have undertaken over the years-be it Bolte in relation to Ansett, Wran in relation to a lot of his mates in New South Wales or Bjelke-Petersen in relation to a lot of his mates in Queensland. This should in no way affect company law and the role of each State corporate affairs commission (CAC). The relationship between the State CAC and its regional commercial centre is vital. Cutting that off and making the State CAC a branch office for Canberra would completely denude such relationships.

The Attorney knows as well as I do that when taxation law was made uniform the role of State commissioners was changed to the role of deputy commissioners. Up until the 1970s one was able to get a reasonable decision on most matters from the deputy commissioner in one's capital city. Today he is no more than a post-box. All power is down here with Boucher. If we ask a local deputy commissioner for a decision, he will not know. He is a branch office; he will find out. The same will apply to this matter before you can say `Jack Robinson'. (Extension of time granted)

I thank the Attorney. To conclude, it is important to draw a distinction between the role of company law and the role of the takeover code. They are totally distinct areas. We have to take note of the developments that have occurred in the stock exchange in the last few years and of the development of certain related areas. That is what such a committee, if it were established, would have a look at. It would have to take soundings from around Australia to see what people think outside Pitt Street and Collins Street, which have had a dominating influence in this area to date.

The Opposition will not be opposing the Close Corporations Bill. It is a new concept. It brings about rather than a memorandum and articles of association more a statement of intent that has to be registered. Shareholders must number no more than 10. One aspect of these changes is that they do lift the corporate veil. I think it is common practice in the corporate world these days for any private company or partnership that seeks accommodation in some form, by way of loans or whatever other way it may come about, to be required to give personal indemnities to the authority which is lending the money, be it a bank, an insurance company or whatever. So while common practice dictates that the companies themselves can be of straw but the men of substance are the shareholders, in this case we are institutionalising the lifting of the corporate veil. I can understand the reasons behind that. However, the precedent being set in this manner gives rise to concern regarding its extension into other areas. Because of that I draw people's attention to it.

It would not be our intent to see the lifting of the corporate veil in that manner. If we were in government, we certainly would not extend it. Indeed, I think that the basis of the close corporation as put forward in the Bill is not anywhere near as attractive as many of the people promoting it would think. Whilst we are not opposing the Bill, I strongly advise all people in the small business sector who may wish to take advantage of it to take considerable advice on the matter because it strikes me, on reading the Bill, that there may not be the advantages over the existing situation in it that have been trumpeted.

Close corporations will still be required to lodge documents. They will still be required to give an account of their activities. They will no longer be required to keep certain accounts. I have always thought that one of the failings of small businesses has been in their accounting. If they were forced to practise the discipline of accounting one would generally find that their rate of failure would diminish. Under this legislation there will be no requirement for them to account, except to themselves. I suspect that that will be an invitation to them to walk away from adequate accounting, which will only lead to more trouble in the future. However, as I said, we will not be opposing the Bill.

I come back to company numbers. Let us look at the new provisions regarding the naming and numbering of companies. The legislation provides that each and every company will have a number akin to an ID card for companies. It must appear on all company documents, in other words, on the company seal, on its publications and negotiable instruments. It appears that the only persons to benefit from this will be the printers. Why are numbers now required? If all companies are to be registered federally, many companies' names will be identical or will overlap. According to the Government, the only way to resolve this chaotic situation is to give each company a number. Companies existing at the time of the introduction of the legislation are able to retain their names, even if those names are identical to the names of companies in other States.

So the legislation will override the State business names Acts. Consequently, a company will be able to use a well established business name, forcing its proprietors to take passing off action in the Federal Court of Australia. In a recent, well known case the appellant was forced to pay costs of $140,000. It is highly unlikely that small businesses will be able to protect themselves against predators or large, unscrupulous corporations which may walk across State boundaries in this way. The consequences of this, as the Attorney would know, will be that all State boundaries are pulled down. We could have Arnott's biscuit companies nos. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6. Which one will the man in the street choose? The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) would probably choose No. 5. As a consequence, a person's commercial activities would be at risk. In looking at this situation, normal sense indicates to me, in trying to settle business names across Australia rather than coming up with this solution, that one of the consequences will be that many companies, especially in the financial area, will ultimately be registered, for example, as company No. 126 Pty Ltd. That might be convenient and easy, but it is the inevitable consequence of these naming operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —They might be known by their tax file numbers.

—Certainly, we will have help in relation to that. With regard to the takeover code, whilst the explanatory memorandum states that the acquisition of shares code provisions are more logical and simplified, the number of sections dealing with the subject is to be increased from 62 to 157. The chapter is peppered with changes; new concepts and definitions which will create a new area of litigation and uncertainty.

SPEECH.PARA: The major change concerns the abolition of the vetting of part A statements and profit forecasts. Lip service is to be paid to pre-vetting of part As. In effect, the Commission must take a decision to be registered by 5 p.m. on the day following the lodgment. Commission staff who currently have a detailed knowledge of the workings of the takeover code will no longer be needed. Clerical staff will be necessary only to check the signatures. A major law firm recently praised the work of the CACs in this respect. It stated that the staff were efficient and speedy and that their attitudes were commercially practical and constructive. This source of expertise will be lost. It will not be available either to the public for consultation or to the Commission to enable it to adequately investigate breaches and the enforcement of the legislation.

The question is also raised as to whether the interests of shareholders and the public will be sufficiently protected. I say that because in many cases a part A takeover document, when lodged with the NCSC, has a great number of variations made to it at the behest of the Securities Commission. In all cases that I can think of that has not only been beneficial to the shareholders of a company that is under attack but has also alleviated legal necessities and challenges which would have occurred if the part A statement had been issued in its original form. One does not have to look very far for examples of what might have occurred. I refer in particular to the Bell takeover documents and the changes that occurred in that regard. Under the proposed scheme those would not have been stopped. The documents would have been sent out. The shareholders in receipt of those offers would have acted, only to find subsequent legal action being taken. The ordinary investor would be disadvantaged by those actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member's time has expired. Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most telling point made by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) in this debate is that Collins Street and Pitt Street are far ahead of this Parliament in responding to corporate realities in the 1980s. That apparently provokes the response from the Opposition that it should so remain; that this Parliament should not modify or bring its procedures up to speed or find an effective way to respond to those changed environments; rather, we should be atavistic; we should look back to the days of the 1930s and 1940s and the views then held by the judges who were quoted in this debate and who thought that it might not be appropriate even to have a national companies scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The practical reality is that Australia has changed since Federation, and the systems that operated clumsily and tentatively in the first stages of the development of our nation to respond to the new corporations that were then only a recent legal invention are no longer appropriate. The world has changed significantly and the corporate style and mechanisms and the way in which Australia operates as a nation have changed. No more are we six separate colonies from an economic point of view. We are effectively a nation with a national economy, with trading corporations and financial corporations which act across State boundaries. To look backwards and to say that we should still have different answers applying to different kinds of business transactions in different States is simply to dream of a nostalgic past which is no longer appropriate or constructive. That is what we are asked to dream about.

The honourable member for Ryan quite plainly looked back and said, `Once upon a time you could go to a Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in one State and get an answer that was appropriate and different from that of commissioners in other States'. We can no longer run a legal system for companies and for tax in Australia that gives different answers for those who are doing business in New South Wales or Tasmania. Why should Tasmanians be disadvantaged by a particular ruling or a set of guidelines that flow from a local office? Why should those in New South Wales follow different procedures from those that apply in other States? Simply put, the answer is that it makes no sense at all. It is most appropriate that the Australian Government has brought before this Parliament in this bicentennial year legislation that reflects our new national maturity.

We are no longer six separate colonies. We no longer treat companies as new, exciting and recently invented legal figments. It is no longer appropriate for individual States to have companies using the same names trading in different jurisdictions within Australia. We are looking towards having a national scheme. The reality is that all concerned in business share those views.

A surprising suggestion that is put to us is that there has been no consensus on this issue; that there is no major call now for uniform national legislation in this area. There has been a significant call for such legislation, not only from this chamber but also from the Senate. The then Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs in its 1987 report concluded that the cooperative scheme had outlived its usefulness. It unanimously recommended that the Commonwealth introduce comprehensive legislation to assume responsibility for all areas covered by the existing scheme. That unanimous call reflects a common perception not only in the business community and the legal community but in the community generally. We can no longer get by with coach and buggy rules, cobbled together as well as possible in the earlier circumstances, which no longer keep us up to date with what is happening in Pitt Street and Collins Street.

It is no good being romantic or backward looking and atavistic about these kinds of notions. If this Parliament is to treat the Australian business community in an appropriate manner, to keep up with the business community, to reflect the changes in the market, to reflect the changes that have transformed Australia's way of doing business, we cannot simply say that we rely on answers from the past. Even the honourable member for Ryan, the shadow spokesman on this issue, points out that there are deficiencies with the cobbled-together federal scheme. There are a number of difficulties. For years, divergencies have occurred between the different States and, more fundamentally, there is the problem of responsibility-the problem of who controls the direction and thrust of that scheme. At the moment, no parliament, government or Minister is responsible for the direction and progress of the operations of the scheme. This has given rise to considerable resentment and difficulties amongst the various States that have participated and also amongst the business community. It is no longer appropriate to overlay artificial boundaries on the national economy. It does a grave disservice to the business community and to Australia generally to seek to continue artificial State boundaries in this area.

The Government has seized this opportunity, has brought in a package of legislation and has undertaken extensive consultation with the business community. It is no surprise that a significant number of amendments have been brought into this place today. We would expect that after the undertakings of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) and his commitment to that process of consultation. Of course, that process has resulted in the business community's views being heard and in the amendments that are now before the Chair.

But let us look at the responses that have come from members of the Opposition because really they are not responses that do credit to the proposals before the House. The reality is that we have a scheme that is based on the Australian Constitution. But what is the response of members of the Opposition? It is a two-bob each way attack. Firstly they attack us by saying, `The Australian Constitution is a remarkable document which should not be changed. It serves us well, we should keep it as it is and we should reject change'. But when we exercise the powers that exist within the constitutional framework now and we utilise those mechanisms, as we are doing in a practical and efficient way in this draft legislation, we are accused of using the Constitution, of relying on too many heads of power giving rise to legalisms and difficulties of interpretation. What nonsense! It is exactly the process that the draftsman has used in the trade practices legislation. It is a process that has been utilised in many pieces of Commonwealth legislation introduced by both Labor and Liberal governments. It is a process which takes advantage of those provisions which exist presently in the Constitution.

What are we asked to do? We are asked not to exercise the power that the Constitution confers, to pretend that we do not have those powers, to look backwards to days when the High Court of Australia was more narrowly literalistic in its interpretation. The debate from the Opposition side in this House has simply been a call for nostalgia, to stay where we are, to change nothing, to respond to nothing and not to accommodate the realities of the change in our business and political environment.

It has been suggested that we do not have a unitary system. Of course we are not a unitary system-we are a federal system-but the Constitution gives to the Commonwealth Parliament certain express and implied powers. One of the express powers given to this Parliament and to the people of Australia to be exercised in the national interest is the power is to make laws with respect to financial and trading corporations. There are other powers upon which this legislation depends and can be upheld. What nonsense to criticise the Parliament for seeking to exercise its legitimate and proper role in these areas!

Significant changes have been introduced in this package of legislation. One of the more significant changes, and criticism of this change is again a reflection of the backward looking views of the Opposition, is that it uses plain English. What a shock, what a revolutionary proposal! I suppose that we might even suggest that it is Fabianism or socialism to use plain English in legislation. It obviously worries the honourable member for Ryan that it does so. The honourable member for Ryan complains that no-one knows what plain English means. It is a difficult proposition to put forward and I imagine that it is a difficult proposition for those who have complained so often to us of the difficulty of reading legislation expressed in language that only lawyers are capable of translating. I would have thought that it would be in our interests, as a parliament, to work towards expressing all our legislation in plain English; that this is a course of conduct to be commended rather than to be criticised. I have no doubt at all that those who enter into the business community will be pleased if it is possible to state in plain English the intentions that are being expressed in this package of legislation. These are not simple concepts but it is important to express them as simply and clearly as possible. I would have thought that a criticism of expressing those intentions in plain English simply misses the mark.

There are many important substantive points about this legislation. I only pause to address a number of the more significant issues that come to my attention. The first point is the introduction of the close corporation scheme. It is a very important innovation directed towards the interests of those small businesses which presently find the processes of incorporation unduly rigid. I am delighted to note that the Opposition does not oppose the close corporation scheme. However, in the Opposition's less than fulsome appraisal of the scheme, there was a suggestion that there may be a precedent in the intention of the draftsman to permit personal liability of those who are members of a close corporation under certain circumstances. In that regard it is important to note that provisions in part 15 of the close corporations Bill are very limited in their application and apply only in circumstances where, for example, the number of members of the corporation has been permitted to exceed 10, which is the limiting number; where proper accounting records have not been kept; if the corporation acts as a holding company; and if corporation members continue to trade once insolvent without taking appropriate and remedial action; and in other such limited circumstances. Essentially, the Close Corporations Bill reflects the desire of the small business community in this area to have an efficient, simple process of incorporation which, on the one hand, protects members and gives them the shield of corporate protection but, on the other hand, makes sure that if such corporations continue to trade, for example, once they know themselves to be insolvent, creditors are not defeated. These are important steps forward.

The other point that I think it important to mention-to the best of my knowledge it has not been raised in this debate-is the landmark decision to abolish the doctrine of ultra vires. The doctrine of ultra vires has been a blot on the way in which corporate law has evolved. Originally, when a corporation was something of a novelty, the courts sought to restrain this new legal creature from acting outside the boundaries of restrictive memorandums and articles of association. In so far as that applied to restraining a company from acting other than as its own incorporating documents declared it to have powers, that made some sense, but it also caused enormous difficulties for people having contact with corporations. If people entered into a contract with a corporation which had no power-for example, they entered into trading contracts or any particular form of activity-those who were said to have notice of that lack of power, by the fact that the memorandums and articles were registered, could find themselves facing legal difficulties.

All that complexity of law has been substantially swept aside in both the close corporations area and in the corporations sector as a whole. In the close corporations legislation the relevant provisions are found in clauses 43 to 44 and, in the Corporations Bill, in clauses 159 to 164 onwards. Let me address the provisions in the Corporations Bill itself. Similar provisions apply to close corporations. In addressing those provisions in particular I make it plain that anyone having business with a corporation can rely on certain presumptions. Presumptions that can be relied upon are: that at all relevant times the company's constitution has been complied with, that the persons who appear on the returns as directors, executive officers or secretaries, have been duly appointed, that the people who are held out by the company to be officers or agents have been duly appointed, that those who appear to have authority to issue documents on behalf of the company have such authority, and the like. That means that people can do business with companies without being at some risk that a sharp legal representative at a later stage may be able to raise some technical defence to that transaction based on documents that a person has not sighted.

The objects of the provisions are set out in section 160, which explains that the objects of sections 161 and 162 are to abolish the doctrine of ultra vires and its application to companies and, without affecting the validity of companies dealing with outsiders, to ensure that a company's officers and members give effect to the provisions of the company's constitution. So it will still remain possible to prosecute those who deliberately flout their own company's constitutional memorandum of association but, at the same time, there is protection for those who have innocent dealings with companies. They are very important, perhaps technical, provisions, but they are appropriate to respond to the undue technicality of the law that has evolved with respect to the question of companies' powers and the limits that are placed on those powers by the doctrine of ultra vires.

Finally, this package of legislation provides an effective mechanism for dealing with the total range of company activity in Australia-from the largest corporations which are active in the international sphere and in Australia's national market to the small corporations which will benefit from the close corporation scheme and its flexibility. This legislation is evidence that the Government is looking forward and is trying to make sure that Australia's legal system keeps up with the rapid advances that are occurring in the world. It is evidence that the Government is not looking backwards, is not seeking reassurance from the past but is instead grappling with the realities of the present and facing the challenges of the future. I commend the package of legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of Bills represents some of the most important legislation to come before the House in recent years. However, as the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) pointed out, some 280 amendments have been circulated in the last two or three days at best.
—Last night.

—Only last night. A whole raft of amendments was introduced in this place this morning. And the stated intention of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) is that we should proceed to the committee stage later today. That is a preposterous proposition. I hope that on reflection, and to enable sensible consideration of all the amendments in the committee stage, the Attorney-General will consider amending the parliamentary program so that all interested members will have a chance to examine the amendments. It was quite a proper yet rare thing for the Government to allow the legislation to lie on the table over the winter break to enable people to examine it. The Government claimed credit for that, and it was a very commendable action. However, the Government is writing off all that good work and the opportunity that some of us had to consider the legislation with its intention to force these amendments through the committee stage later today. It makes the Attorney-General's earlier good intentions meaningless.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation seeks to achieve in companies law what the famous uniform tax case has long since established in the area of taxation. If our current tax laws are any indication, the already extensive Bills before us today should be greeted with some trepidation. The Commonwealth takeover of all companies legislation is a recipe bordering on total control and regulation of Australian business. As the honourable member for Ryan said, it is a massive grab for power; or is it a grab for massive power? The few parts of the legislation which simplify procedures for Australian companies do so at the expense of conceding the power to regulate to a single central government. Perhaps supporters of this scheme are confident of their ability to keep a check on the regulatory inclinations of Federal governments and the inevitable clutch of accompanying bureaucratic advisers in the Public Service. However, past experience leads me to be less than optimistic about that.

The participation of the States in the present cooperative scheme might seem to be a hindrance now, but it is a valuable limit on the possible excesses of Commonwealth governments. The number of members opposite who have a genuine belief in deregulation and free market principles is very small-in fact, one might say that it is minuscule. The necessity of deregulation now will not tomorrow guarantee any freedom from the old doctrine of the Australian Labor Party (ALP), its old Fabian doctrine and tenets. Over the years the ALP has proposed 13 constitutional amendments which would have either directly or indirectly expanded Commonwealth power in the areas of companies law and commerce in general. All of them have been rejected by the people in referendums. So the Government cannot claim any mandate for these changes. There is no demand, no-one is knocking down our doors for us to legislate in this way.

By refusing to amend the Constitution Australians have already specifically denied the Attorney-General the power that he seeks for the Federal Government through this legislation. The constitutional barrier is the most significant obstacle to the operation of this legislation, even if it should pass through Parliament. The Government must come to realise that it does not have absolute power, and it must know also that it cannot achieve all of its goals through legislation. Indeed, and thankfully, the Government is prohibited by the higher law of the Constitution from legislating in many areas which, although very important, are simply not the responsibility of the Commonwealth. To be bound by a democratic Constitution is not a constraint which appeals to the ALP or the current Federal Government. This Government does everything it can to weaken, undermine or avoid the constitutional limits on Commonwealth power when and for as long as it sits on the treasury bench. In the referendum of 3 September Australian voters rejected the deceit of the proposals put forward and the Labor Party's discontent with our Constitution.

In these Bills the Attorney-General demonstrates again a Napoleonic desire for overall control in the field of Australian law, notwithstanding that the defeat of the 3 September referendum effectively saw the Attorney-General banished to his Elba after his failure to secure further Commonwealth powers. Unwilling, it seems, to accept defeat, his reaction to that debacle was a tirade of abuse, insulting the commonsense of all Australians who simply did not accept his points of view. This companies legislation now represents the Attorney-General's Waterloo, and it represents his last chance to secure power which the Commonwealth does not possess and which it was not given under the Constitution. The legislation also promises to be the Attorney-General's last hurrah, given his impending retirement. He finds opposed to him a wide coalition of the States, business groups, professional associations and informed legal opinion. Like Napoleon, even old friends in the Labor State governments are opposed to his schemes but, like Napoleon, he refuses to concede another defeat. Yet I hope that his eventual absence from this place will be the metaphorical equivalent of St Helena, only much more pleasant and enjoyable because he has earned a pleasant retirement.

The Commonwealth already has significant constitutional responsibility in areas affecting companies, securities and other areas of commercial law. These include banking, foreign trade and commerce, insurance and bankruptcy. In particular, section 51 (xx) of the Constitution grants power over `Foreign corporations, and trading or financial corporations formed within the limits of the Commonwealth'.

Informed legal opinions suggest that these wide powers are not sufficient to allow the Commonwealth to implement its national companies scheme. The Law Council of Australia is of the opinion that some corporations which are presently covered by State legislation do not fall within the constitutional power of the Commonwealth. Again the honourable member for Ryan has mentioned some of those. Because of this, it is clear that the States will need to maintain parts of existing legislation, producing a new system of dual responsibility with new and terribly confused divisions of power. If the Law Council is correct, the Bowen plan, with its effective usurping of State corporate affairs commissions (CACs) becomes unworkable. The present cooperative scheme, for all of its particular problems-problems which, incidentally, can be reformed-at least overcomes the problem of dual legal responsibility through existing parallel legislation.

It is apparent that this proposed legislation fails the constitutional test which is the first test which legislators must apply to Bills before this Parliament. Leaving that aside for the moment, there are other aspects which warrant attention. When considering legislation it would usually make sense to consider the details of the Bills to be able to judge whether those details are in accord with the Government's objectives and whether those objectives are desirable. That is not possible with this legislation. The Attorney-General has made it clear that he is less concerned with the details and effects of these Bills than he is with achieving his objective of a nationalised system of companies legislation and control.

The corporation Bills and accompanying proposals are, according to the Attorney-General, substantially the same as for the existing cooperative scheme. The cooperative scheme was conveniently overlooked by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), who seemed to think that there were no provisions and that progress had not been made. He spoke wistfully of colonies and the fact that we had progressed past that stage. That was pretty apparent to anyone.

The changes which the Attorney-General outlines are mainly in areas of procedure or administration, rather than major changes to the regulation of corporations, or so the line goes. Let no-one be fooled. The changes to the administration of company law will undoubtedly impose greater centralisation. Bestowing, as it will, unlimited Federal Government control of companies law, this legislation has the potential to be first in a series of measures to re-regulate Australian corporate practice. I would not trust any government of any political complexion with the regulatory powers which passage of these Bills will confer.

On top of the existing corporate affairs commissions, this legislation proposes to create an Australian Securities Commission (ASC). The ASC will take on the regulatory and investigative powers of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) but they will be greatly enlarged. It is further proposed that the State CACs are to act as delegates or agents of the ASC in the States. This administrative scheme effectively introduces a further large bureaucratic structure to regulate Australian business.

But even that is not all. The limited enforcement powers now vested with the NCSC will be strengthened and they will be exercised by another new body, the Corporations and Securities Panel. Mechanisms will still have to exist for consultation with State governments over the funding and activities of the corporate affairs commissions, as well as the return of seven-eighths of the revenue raised under the scheme to the States. Legal jurisdiction over the scheme will be vested in both the Federal Court of Australia and the State supreme courts. Thus the potential confusion of and cost to be borne by future litigants are further compounded. In addition, as if to add confusion to confusion, a Companies and Securities Advisory Committee is to be set up to provide consultation with `a broad spectrum of community interests'. No doubt this Committee will include the usual bevy of unrepresentative trade union leaders and so-called consumer advocates. The long list of administrative changes which will add the new quangos these Bills propose to establish clearly contradicts the Minister's claims that the goal of this extensive package of legislation is to simplify existing companies law. It is something of an understatement to observe that the new procedures are not obviously or even arguably more simple than those of the present cooperative scheme. The ultimate goal, and it is an unmitigated goal, of these administrative changes is the centralisation of power. That also happens to be a major platform for objectors.

Advocates of the Bowen plan argue that the changing nature of a national economy and internationalisation of commerce require national uniformity, rapid responses to these circumstances and clear centres of power and authority. In short, any change is said to require greater concentrations of power in the hands of the Commonwealth and its bureaucrats in Canberra. That is demonstrably wrong and it is demonstrably short-sighted. Commerce throughout the world is clearly changing and probably at a rapid pace but those changes have shown the inability of centralised systems to adapt to desirable change. Increasingly, successful governments overseas have discovered that diversity and flexibility are more effective than a single uniform national system along the lines now proposed by the Attorney-General.

Australia is a federation. Differences between the States do exist. If nothing else, the distance from Canberra to Perth is so great that it enhances the value of local knowledge and works against efficient regulation from afar. Many Western Australian representatives of business and business owners in that State have already experienced the frustration of dealing with a regulator who has no knowledge of the operations of a particular firm and because of the distance and expense of travel has no prospect of ever acquiring adequate knowledge.

A further legitimate criticism of the cooperative scheme is that it is too centralised and therefore does not encourage competition between the States in terms of efficiency. Nor would it facilitate efficient interchange of registrations between the States. Experience in the United States offers a good example of the beneficial effects of diversity in companies legislation. Competing States there have strong incentives to minimise taxes and charges on corporate registration, to ensure rapid and efficient applications of stable, predictable law and to attract businesses to particular States by providing a better service for corporate clients. Instead, this legislation will take us in the opposite direction, imposing a single, unified system and a complicated bureaucratic structure to administer already burdensome regulations.

The Minister's arguments for this legislation are little more than wrestling with straw men. He vigorously attacks the cooperative scheme as being outdated and unable to cope with rapid changes in the financial and securities markets. Yet his proposed changes will not remedy that. Changes to paperwork, reporting and the more controversial vetting requirements might facilitate some new procedures on the national stock exchange relating to electronic trading but they are relatively minor alterations to the overall regulatory framework. Changes to the registration procedures for company names would be welcomed, I think; so might the removal of requirements to lodge memoranda and articles of association. But these minor changes hardly justify the bulky legislative package which we are debating today or the heady rhetoric of the Attorney-General. After going through the tortuous process of examining the intricate detail of this legislation, just as others have, one can only observe that most of the detailed changes are possible under the codes of the existing cooperative scheme. Thus, the strongest conclusion that can be drawn from the Attorney-General's criticism of present companies law and arrangements is that it might be time to reform the cooperative scheme itself. However, such reform would require extensive consultation with those States for which the Attorney-General seems to have such disregard. It would also involve considering the opinions of the NCSC and all businesses. The ensuing reforms would not be drafted exclusively by, or reinforce the influence of, the Attorney-General's Department. It is as simple as that. The sensible option is too hard and not enough power will result to the Commonwealth. For these reasons, I do not expect this legislation to have the short life which it deserves.

I acknowledge that the four codes of the cooperative scheme have many problems. They are often ambiguous and difficult to interpret. They have imposed unnecessary regulation on both large and small businesses. In contrast, this legislation compounds the problems of the cooperative scheme by redrafting the law, introducing new ambiguities and requiring extensive legal interpretation in the courts. Imposing centralised administration on top of all that makes the proposals even more dangerous. They represent an enormous leap into the dark. The Minister adopted a rather silly majoritarian argument when he said that the cooperative scheme is undemocratic because there is no direct responsibility to a single Minister or parliament. This he has said of a scheme accountable to at least seven Ministers and parliaments at both State and Federal levels. The time available to me in this debate is running out and I conclude by saying that the unified national companies scheme proposed in this legislation represents the further centralisation of Australian government, and let there be no doubt about that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Australian Securities Commission Bill and cognate legislation and to oppose the amendment. Following the speech of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) and the remarks of my colleague the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), I wish to make a few brief points about the matter at stake. Much has been made by Opposition members of the cooperative scheme, its relevance and efficiency. Government members have taken the view that if one examines the performance of the business community operationally and the Australian capital market in terms of changes and dynamics, one sees that we now have a single Australian capital market which is fast moving and relevant. Those who are familiar with the daily business programs that appear on television are aware that the prices quoted are single prices for the Australian capital market. They reflect transactions across Australia, and the people who make business decisions tend to reflect that reality.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened is that very properly Australian business has grown and changed with the needs of the day, but the regulatory framework has not done so. It is clear to anyone who looks at the operation of the cooperative scheme that it contains considerable deficiencies. One could spend a lot of time talking about such deficiencies, but I shall touch on only one or two relevant matters. I refer first to the question of information and access to such information. It is clear from the way in which the system has been working that there are deficiencies both in terms of the information base and the way in which the enforcement aspects can be dealt with. The information base is inadequate. Clearly, the notion of having an Australian Securities Commission would improve the operation and information in regard to the regulatory framework.

I turn to the question of enforcement. It is clear to anyone who examines certain corporate affairs activities in Australia over time-I can identify the States, but I shall not do so at the outset-that in some States there have been deficiencies in enforcement. Those deficiencies cause problems when particular cases are not dealt with. They also create problems and crises of confidence in the private sector generally. Honourable members on the Labor benches strongly believe in having a strong and viable private sector, but are aware that that can happen only if there is a general confidence in the community that business will be conducted with relatively high degrees of honesty, openness and efficiency. If it can be demonstrated that certain corporate affairs officers at certain times have fallen short of the mark in enforcement-and it can easily be demonstrated-we should begin to ask ourselves whether we need a new system. The answer is that of course we do.

Let me also refer to particular cases that will be familiar to honourable members and to the community in general. A recent situation arose in the Bond-Bell share acquisition. Clearly, some issues required addressing and the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) attempted to do so. Proper questions were being asked in this place, but the Attorney-General did not have access to the information because there was no legislative requirement for the NCSC to report to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just use the telephone. He can be contacted at any time of the day.

—The honourable member for Ryan is attempting to make some comments, but the reality which must be demonstrated is that there was no proper legislative arrangement within which the Attorney-General could operate. We are saying that the Australian Securities Commission will put that there. I know that the honourable member for Ryan has come a long way in his learning on this matter, and I compliment him on that. There is constant tension between the honourable member, who has a high level of intelligence, and those in Queensland who would drag him down, but I commend the honourable member for always resisting those attempts. The trouble with the cooperative scheme is that it is based on the lowest common denominator. If one State does not want to get into the scheme it drags down the whole process, and the honourable member knows that very well. That is why we are saying that the Australian Securities Commission needs at least to have a higher level of regulatory arrangement. There is no doubt about that and I think Opposition members recognise that fact.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned the Bond-Bell matter. There was also earlier the attempt by the Bell Group to take over Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. We ultimately required the Ministry of this Government to look at that matter. It had to do so because there were strategic matters involving the steel industry, but again what had to be acknowledged was that the NCSC arrangement was good for its time but that times change. I referred earlier to some shortcomings in enforcement and there have been difficulties at various State levels. I could bring those difficulties to the fore in this debate, but I choose not to do so as I do not think it would help the debate. The essential issue is that we need a regulatory authority which recognises that we have a single capital market, that such a market is highly dynamic and changing, and that the cooperative scheme is a lowest common denominator scheme. To that extent it is deficient. There are some people at State level who will say, `You are taking away the access'. That is not true either. The proposal does not allow for that. The proposal still leaves offices operating within the States and also returns funds to the States. Therefore, there is not room for people to be critical in those terms. When we have taken up the issue at State level, people have been forced to concede that. It gets back to the old States' rights argument. Unfortunately, that does not wash any more when one is talking about efficient business and business management in a fair and equitable way.

On the dark side let us also talk of the question of insider trading and how it is necessary to have an Australian Securities Commission to deal with that matter. I say to the honourable member for Ryan and his Opposition colleagues that what the Australian Securities Commission Bill is about is recognising that we have a single capital market and a highly dynamic business community. We want to provide a regulatory framework which reacts and relates to that and which is not governed by the lowest common denominator approach to corporate regulation. I think that the cooperative scheme demonstrates that and we should recognise it in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I would have forecast, this kind of debate always raises a number of matters. Whilst we try to rebut them by saying that we are not seeking more power for Canberra, it is the way to go these days to confuse people by saying that we are, even though the legislation relates to the fact that in this particular case-and I do not suggest that the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) is being misjudged-the present scheme that we are anxious to replace started in 1978. To use somebody else's expression, in 1978 that was perhaps the best that could have been obtained.
