SPEECH.PARA: The point we face is that we are not back in 1890 or 1900 when the Constitution was drawn up and when there was at least enough wisdom among those who drew it up to say that it should contain power to deal not only with foreign corporations, because they would be coming here and investing-that was pretty good foresight back in the 1890s-but also with trading and financial corporations formed within the Commonwealth and with operations that naturally went across State borders. That is the situation.

We now have a very effective method of investment in shares and securities right across Australia as one market. There are not six or seven markets. There are no longer six or seven stock exchanges; they have now formed themselves into the Australian Stock Exchange. There are not six or seven different units of currency. There are no problems from the point of view of raising capital in any other State, even though one might be trading basically in Sydney or Melbourne. So we have the development of what we call law by custom. Because trading means that companies have to become national, and now international, there ought to be a legal framework that will meet that.

The great point at issue here is that this law at present, pursuant to the existing scheme, is not answerable to any parliament in Australia. It is incredible to think that, by having to reach some compromise, we have the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities, which group of Ministers looks at submissions made to them as to how we might alter what is called the law pursuant to the agreement. Once they make their decision, that is the end of it; no parliament can alter it. No questions can be asked about it in the sense that there can be any ministerial responsibility.

The two matters that the Opposition refuses repeatedly to face up to are that there is no ministerial responsibility for this law whatsoever and that there is no parliamentary accountability whatsoever. It has become a fiction in this place that we introduce what are called corporation laws, or matters related to corporation activities, and they cannot be amended by any member of this House or of the Senate. It is unique in Australia. The Ministerial Council grapples with the issues that normally would have been the subject of debate either in the State parliaments or in this one.

The converse situation is that if there is power somewhere-we submit that it is here and the Opposition says it is not-why do the States not pass the laws they can now simultaneously? The six of them can easily do it. There is no need for us at all. The Commonwealth would not be needed because the laws would run on State powers. I know what those in the business community would say about that. They would say, `That's not the proposition we want. We want to have some concept of nationalism'. The States could easily form a group called the National Companies and Securities Commission. They could delegate that. The six State Ministers could meet their group and ask how things are going in each State. There is no need for us to be here. The only bit of power we have is in respect of the Australian Capital Territory. That is the present situation. What does it lead to?

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the position with all the major companies in Australia before that.
—They did that because they wanted uniformity.
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Ryan to cease interjecting and ask the Attorney-General to ignore the interjections.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I must ignore interjections, but I want to make the point that they might have done it for stamp duty. If we were to increase the stamp duty the States would not be so anxious to do it. The issue I wish to raise is that the Ministerial Council receives every now and again a report which says how things are going in the securities market. One of the problems we in this nation have is to encourage Australians to act on a national basis and invest in the stock market-to put capital into industries which can expand, develop or start. It is important to raise capital from the point of view of getting our industrial, commercial and financial activities doing very well not only in Australia but also internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: When I talk to those in the business community, they say, `It is about time we had some national concepts'. Trustees say, `Do you know that as a nation we are very seldom considered in the international markets to be appointed trustees? Why? Because we are beholden to six or seven pieces of legislation and we do not get any business at all'. That is the first thing. I give the honourable member for Ryan credit for being anxious to improve the situation, but he is cabin'd cribb'd and confined by saying that we are trying to give power to Canberra. That is nonsense. We are trying to give some efficient legal framework to a business community that is trying to do something. He asks how well it is going. How well does he think it is going, with a number of corporate affairs commissions doing very well but naturally relating to the issues within their States?

TALK.START.PARA: —Your Attorney's delegation--

—I want the honourable gentleman to listen. He has had his chance, even with an extension of speaking time. In 1986 the Commission published a Green Paper which proposed substantial changes in the light of insider trading. Because of widespread opposition from the business community to its complexity, those changes were withdrawn and it was announced that fresh attempts would be made. Does the honourable member see the problems?
—It is like your amendments.

—No. This is what he does not want to hear: many prima facie instances of insider trading have been identified, but great difficulty has been experienced in obtaining admissible evidence. That is known to people investing in the stock market and they say, `Why can't you fix up that matter?' They are the issues. The point we are making here is that the honourable gentleman is saying that in the finish we might need to do something about the securities area. We tried that. We put up a proposition and the honourable gentleman himself was the first to scuttle it-even though his leader did not. We talked about having that part of the responsibility, but the States said, `No, we are not going to have a split scheme' and rejected it. The honourable gentleman encouraged them to do so. He won that battle. I am not anxious to do something that would in any way interfere with the business community but members of the business community gave evidence to the Senate committee-and it might be said that they changed their mind-that they favoured a national scheme because they could not see that they would get uniformity of action.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me deal with some of the specifics. There has been great castigation of the consultative committee that I set up. I think it did a good job. The committee comprised about 40 people who formed themselves into communities. I acknowledge that those in Perth would say that this was too far away from the realities of what they are about, but we do not see the Perth people having trouble organising their own arrangements at times. That has been the subject of questions asked here as to what we know about the situation. The honourable gentleman's suggestion is that I ring up somebody to find out. Perhaps I would have to do that to find out, because no other information is ever given. On that basis, we have to examine what we are about here.

As to accountability, we have to realise that the questions asked are not answered in any parliament. No parliament at all gives the answers. The honourable gentleman thinks that is a very good thing. As he said, I think he got the best he could in 1978. He is the father of the scheme. What father would disown a child like this? Nevertheless, we are saying that he ought to be able to improve its education and standard. That is the point. There has been plenty of discussion with the business community.

The honourable member then complained that the consultative group had received only 20 submissions. I would submit that this is not a bad response. In other words, not so many people were worried about the proposal. Only 20 submissions were received. Does the honourable member suggest that the group should have had thousands of replies? The business community has been continually discussing this matter; I have talked to it and it is very clear that the Australian nation is divided between the west and the east. The west is fearful of domination by Sydney and Melbourne. That is the present position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at your own Law Society in New South Wales.
—Order! The honourable member for Ryan has been spoken to previously. He will cease interjecting or I will have to take action.

—The honourable member should look at what we are about here. The legislation does not give more power to Canberra; it is a question of giving a legal framework to a responsibility. The Ministers are asking me to meet them again on 1 November. I welcome that. I make the point that we are either in this scheme or out of it; there is no point in being halfway to nowhere.

SPEECH.PARA: When the States want to have an investigation of a company-that may be a good idea, but it could cost hundreds of thousands of dollars-the first people they come to are those of us in government and they tell us that we have to pay half the costs. We ask why and they tell us that they do not have any money. We tell them that they have all the money and that the case has occurred in their State. They reply, `Oh no, under the scheme you pay for all investigations'. That is a bit of a joke. We are being asked to pay hundreds of thousands of dollars for an investigation that will take place basically in one State because that is the arrangement that the honourable gentleman developed. It cannot happen in that situation. What about the $65m profit that the States make? What about the 1,500 employees they have in their corporate affairs commissions? Are they unable to do something about investigations? Why are they coming to me on this issue and telling me that I had better chip in half the costs? That half is taxpayers' money-being spent simply because the State thinks that it is a good idea to investigate a company. It is a good idea to investigate but that scenario shows the basic weakness of some of these suggestions.

The honourable member for Ryan himself would be the first to ask, `Why are you spending more money than was appropriated in the Budget?'. I would have to tell him that if I listened to all the demands I would need a lot more taxpayers' money and would have to let the States keep the surplus and run on with their corporate affairs commissions because they say that these commissions have enough to do. The problem with that scheme is that there is no coordination between them on what they should be doing together. I think that they could develop that. If they did so and if they developed their legal structure there would be no need for us at all. I would think that the stock exchanges and the business community in Australia would think that this was surprising because it would mean a return to pre-1978 and I am sure that that is the wrong thing to do. The honourable member has already indicated that he thinks it is the wrong thing to do. The problem I have is that when I put up a split proposition he was the first to oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the type of proposition you put up.

—No, not at all. The honourable member never made one suggestion until the dying stages of the extended debate here today when he said that he thought there might be a chance for some Federal law. I do not know what that means; the honourable member has never spelt it out. All I have ever tried to do is say that if we are to have responsibility-as we have-we should have some legal framework to back it up. We should have a proper Australian Securities Commission composed of members of the business community. We should have an advisory committee composed of members of the business community and not, as the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) so unfairly states, of trade unionists. Have Opposition members not read the legislation? The Bill itself says that in appointing the members, the Minister shall have regard to the views of the business community of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the intention was to have representatives from every State on the advisory committee. The States have opposed every aspect of this Bill. They have not put forward one constructive suggestion and they are now worried about the amendments. They are worried about the Bill; they do not want it. Perhaps they will be successful. I do not know. If, in the process of going around Australia, the committee finds that the business community does not want the legislation, then obviously it will report that way, but the point is that honourable members should not think that because the business community does not want something here it does not want an improvement in the present scheme. The present scheme is not working. That is the point.

We have all sorts of concepts: we have to talk about numbers for companies that will be registered. That is not a new concept. I understand that throughout the world companies use numbers. It prevents delays and confusion of people who are trying to get companies with similar names. Numbers are much more distinctive than names. The delays that the business community has of four or six months in trying to find out whether the names are available should be considered. The honourable member for Ryan rejects that.

The problem we have is that on all these issues we are trying to help the business community but the Opposition is saying that it does not want to do so. We put up a split scheme, it was rejected by the honourable member and also by the States. We put up the issue of consultation and that has been very productive. We have tried to draft the legislation in a fashion that would certainly be more streamlined, but because we have to go into the concept of putting a proposition in which we are not allowed to have a split scheme, we are talking about a scheme which would be federal but State driven in the terms under which we would enter into arrangements with the States. That is the proposal. The States went half way to that on the basis that some of them might agree with the proposition as long as they could have a veto on what law could be introduced. We cannot have federal responsibility, parliamentary responsibility and ministerial responsibility if there is the suggestion of a veto by some State Ministers. We just cannot run that concept. I have asked the States to reconsider that and that might be the purpose of the meeting on 1 November.

What we have here is the beginning of a good concept where the States and the Federal Government will agree that there is a need for the division of the law. I think that can happen, but it will need the cooperation of the Opposition and the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Everybody would need to know what was going on.

—Everybody would know what was going on because there would be a report. At present we do not get any report to this Parliament. No information is given to any Minister on the day to day machinations and on that basis we have the problem of accountability. On that score we are talking about a whole lot of new ideas. From the point of view of administration we want less litigation. The NCSC has been bedevilled by excessive litigation so therefore we have the concept of the panel being created to guarantee a barrier between the investigator and the prosecutor. That is a normal process. If one tries to suggest that one should be both the investigator and the prosecutor, one is carted off to all the supreme courts. One sees the problem in the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd takeover where an excessive amount of litigation has developed and the NCSC could not really continue to function because it was continually involved in litigation.

SPEECH.PARA: The idea of the panel is to give quick advice to the business community. The idea of being able to understand the issue means the business community itself will be able to regulate its own affairs. If there are complaints by consumers or investors who want to take the issue further, that can happen. But never at any stage has it been suggested that we are trying to build up some other bureaucracy-not at all. In fact, we are trying to take the matter back to the business community and make it accountable. That community is prepared to accept it. There is no question of centralisation. At present it is a question of disintegration, of 1,500 employees across Australia with the proliferation of priorities. They all have different priorities and we want to get some understanding as to what we are about.

There was some recognition of the advantages of close corporations and there is an opportunity for small business to participate here. Partnerships have always existed and there should be an opportunity for them at least to have some corporate alternative. This is the way to go. There would be some personal liability but it would not be as complete as in the partnership situation; it is more streamlined and it does not have the weaknesses that were mentioned by the honourable member. I think that that is progressive law.

In conclusion I emphasise that what we have here is an attempt to overcome the problems that the stock market identifies, to try to streamline the position and to give it a legal base, parliamentary accountability and ministerial responsibility. I know that this should go to a committee and that the Senate will insist that that happen. I welcome that; it is the appropriate course to take. I cannot accept the amendment because it suggests that the Bill go to a committee of this place.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Moore's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 12-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 13 (General powers of investigation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 13, page 9, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:

``(2) Where the Commission has reason to suspect that unacceptable circumstances within the meaning of Part 6.9 of the Corporations Act 1988 have, or may have, occurred, the Commission may make such investigation as it thinks expedient:
(a) for the purposes of determining whether or not to make an application under subsection 733 (1) or 734 (2) of that Act; or
(b) otherwise for the due administration of a national scheme law.''.

The amendment makes it clear that the Australian Securities Commission has the power to investigate unacceptable conduct in connection with a takeover that might fall short of a breach of the law. The amendment will enable the Australian Securities Commission to investigate such conduct in determining whether to apply to the Corporations and Securities Panel for a declaration of unacceptable conduct under clause 733 of the Corporations Bill.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 14 to 18-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 19 (Notice requiring appearance for examination).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 19, page 12, lines 12 and 13, omit subclause (3), substitute the following subclause:
``(3) A notice given under subsection (2) shall:
(a) state the general nature of the matter referred to in subsection (1); and
(b) set out the effect of subsection 23 (1) and section 68.''.

This amendment affords natural justice to persons whose attendance at an Australian Securities Commission (ASC) examination is required. The amendment makes it clear that a notice from the ASC requiring a person to appear and answer questions at an examination must contain a statement of the nature of the matter to which the investigation relates. This will enable the person to be aware of the relevance of the inquiry. The amendment will also require the notice to set out the person's right to legal representation under clause 23 of the Bill and a person's right to claim privilege against self-incrimination under clause 68 of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Attorney-General to explain this amendment further so that I can understand how it fits with the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment relates to clause 19, page 12, lines 12 and 13, and omits subclause (3), substituting the following subclause:

SPEECH.PARA: ``(3) A notice given under subsection (2) shall:
(a) state the general nature of the matter referred to in subsection (1); and
(b) set out the effect of subsection 23 (1) and section 68.''

The amendment provides that the notice from the Australian Securities Commission to the person who is required to appear before it must contain a statement of the nature of the matter to which the investigation relates. The present clause does not contain that obligation. Accordingly, the person will be given better notice of the issue.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 20 to 42-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 43 (Exercise of certain power of the Commission in relation to securities).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Clause 43, page 21, line 15, omit ``section 732'', substitute ``Part 6.9''.

This amendment preserves the role of the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). As presently worded, the clause does not recognise the role of the Director of Public Prosecutions in relation to Commonwealth offences. The amendment will empower the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) to commence and carry on prosecutions, but without prejudicing the DPP's statutory powers and functions. Although the ASC will be able to make an initial decision to prosecute, the Director of Public Prosecutions will be able to take over or terminate the prosecution or give instructions concerning the prosecution. Similar amendments are proposed to the corresponding provisions of the Corporations Bill and the Close Corporations Bill.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 44 to 48-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 49 (Commission to cause prosecution to be begun).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Clause 49, page 24, line 36, omit ``shall'', substitute ``may''.
(5) Clause 49, page 25, at the end of the clause add the following subclause:
``(5) Nothing in this section affects the operation of the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983.''.

These amendments enable the Director of Public Prosecutions to participate in carrying out prosecutions. On that basis, although the Australian Securities Commission might make a decision to prosecute, the amendments enable the Director of Public Prosecutions also to give directions concerning the prosecution.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not clear from what the Attorney-General said how the Government's proposed amendment (4), which substitutes the word `may' for `shall' in clause 49, page 24, line 36, ties in to his reference to the Director of Public Prosecutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 49 states:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) This section applies where, as a result of an investigation or from a record of an examination, it appears to the Commission that a person:
(a) may have committed an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or a Territory; and
(b) ought to be prosecuted for the offence.
(2) The Commission shall cause a prosecution of the person for the offence to be begun and carried on.

Our amendment (4) omits the word `shall' from clause 49 (2) and substitutes the word `may'. As I said, there is a discretion. The Australian Securities Commission (ASC) is not obliged to commence or carry out a prosecution, although it may do so. Whilst it may make an initial decision to prosecute, the matter might be then handed over to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP). Therefore, it would not be in the Commission's hands. The DPP could then use discretion whether to go ahead with or terminate the prosecution. In other words, the amendment gives the Director of Public Prosecutions the opportunity to say that the ASC need not go ahead with a prosecution, and it would not go ahead.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 50 (Commission may cause civil proceeding to be begun).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Clause 50, page 25, line 22, after ``may'' insert ``, with the person's written consent,''.

As it is presently worded, clause 50 does not require the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) to obtain a person's consent before undertaking civil proceedings in that person's name. The amendment will ensure that the ASC will not be able to undertake civil proceedings without the person's written consent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which person?

—Where, as a result of an investigation, there is a suggestion that it is in the public interest for a person to begin and carry on Federal proceedings, the Commission may cause such proceedings to be taken. In other words, if as a result of an investigation one finds that somebody has suffered damage and therefore is entitled to take an action, this is an opportunity for the Commission to take the action on the person's behalf. That is self-evident, if honourable members read it. But the issue that was not covered by the clause is that one needs the person's consent to do it. On that basis, consent is the relevant factor in the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 51 to 62-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 63 (Non-compliance with requirements made under this Part).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Clause 63, page 29, line 39, omit ``or (3)''.
(8) Clause 63, page 30, line 2, after ``(2)'' insert ``or 48 (2)''.
I do not have any speaking notes for these amendments. A typographical error needs to be altered.

TALK.START.PARA: —This exacerbates the situation about which the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and I have complained. The Attorney-General cannot tell us what the amendments are about and what their effect will be. I accept that a typographical error might be involved, but the amendments insert other subclauses. They might well be the product of a typographical error, but presumably the honourable member for Ryan and others in the business community who are interested have already considered the clause in its present form. The Committee deserves an explanation of its effect. It should not be told simply that a typographical error is involved. As I said, specific subclauses are referred to. The Attorney-General might want to find out about this and tell us later, if that is possible. I simply want to know what it is all about.

—I understand that there is reference to a section which should not be there. Therefore, that is the idea of the omission contained in the amendment. If the honourable gentleman wants me to come back to it, we could do that.
—It might suit the Attorney and the honourable gentleman, but it does not suit the Chair.

—I am sorry about that. The position, as I understand it, is that there is a typographical error which should not be there. Therefore, the amendment seeks to omit it. I do not see that it has any other significance.
—One of the amendments calls for the insertion of a subclause. It does not concern something that should be omitted, as the Attorney-General said. Proposed amendment (7) deals with that.
—Amendment (7) reads:
—I accept that, but amendment (8) calls for the insertion of a subclause, and we are dealing with both amendments. The Attorney is right on the first count, but incorrect on the second.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendment (8) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 63, page 30, line 2, after ``(2)'' insert ``or 48 (2)''.
We propose to insert after line 2 on page 30 `or 48 (2)'. That would be consistent with the arrangements that we are making.

TALK.START.PARA: —I dispute that. If this is going to happen often, I wonder whether we should withdraw it.
—I draw the comments of the Attorney-General to people's attention. He has said, in effect, that he does not know what the implications of the change are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My information is that this enables clause 48 (2), which deals with the panel, to have the same effect as clause 23 (2), which deals with the Australian Securities Commission. In other words, they are put on an equal footing.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 64 agreed to.
Clause 65 (Obstructing person acting under this Part).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Clause 65, page 30, line 30, omit ``$1,000'', substitute ``$2,500''.
This amendment omits `$1,000' and substitutes `$2,500'. It is a matter of a particular penalty, so I think it is self-explanatory.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the reasons for the change from $1,000 to $2,500?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Usually in these matters there is some conformity between the term of imprisonment and what the financial penalty ought to be. It is a standard issue in all legislation. Therefore, if the term of imprisonment is six months, it is deemed that the monetary penalty ought to be higher than it is. The penalties are adjusted from time to time in accordance with inflation as well.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 66 to 69-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10) Clause 70, page 32, lines 39 to 42 and page 33, lines 1 to 4, omit subclause (3), substitute the following subclause:
``(3) If the Commission does so, the Court may inquire into the case and may order the person to comply with the requirement as specified in the order.''.

This clause applies where the Commission is satisfied that a person has, without reasonable cause, failed to comply with the requirement. If the Commission does so, the court may inquire into the case and may order the person to comply with the requirement. Again, the amendment is better drafted than the present clause.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Clause 72, page 33, line 37, omit ``such shares'', substitute ``shares in the body''.
(12) Clause 72, page 33, line 39, omit ``such shares'', substitute ``shares in the body''.

In moving these two amendments I think we are again giving a better definition. Instead of talking about `such shares' we are using the words `shares in the body'. I do not want to make any further explanation as there is no uncertainty about it.

Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 73 and 74-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 75 (Orders under this Division).
Amendment (by Mr Lionel Bowen) proposed:
(13) Clause 75, page 35, lines 28 to 32, omit subclauses (5) and (6).

TALK.START.PARA: —By omitting the two subclauses the immediate implication is that there has been a considerable change of mind. Would the Attorney-General care to expand on those reasons?

—The present position is that a person aggrieved by an order enforced under this division may apply to the court. It appears that we do not want to proceed on that basis; we have other opportunities for dealing with this. Apparently, we do not want to have a person able to go against a decision by applying to the court. In other words, it would be deemed to be more effective to have the matter within the control of the order made by the Commission. If the honourable gentleman feels that a person ought to be given an opportunity to go against the order he should vote against the amendment.
—In view of the comment of the Attorney-General, as I understand it, the only appeal within the Act is to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Therefore, these insertions are probably an error.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subclause (5) of clause 75 provides:

SPEECH.PARA: A person aggrieved by an order in force under this Division may apply to the Court for variation or revocation of the order.

Subclause (6) refers to proposed new subsection (5). I would have thought that that was a perfectly reasonably provision to have in the legislation. There must be some powerful reasons for even contemplating taking it out, but those are not immediately apparent to me. Surely such an important provision would have an influence on those with whom the Attorney-General claims to have spoken in his exhaustive lead-up to the introduction of this legislation. Surely that is something that would have been considered because there is a protection there for a person aggrieved by an order in force under this division.

Having gone through a great deal of discussion before the legislation was first prepared, to remove that, presumably without the same exhaustive discussion or examination, might be a breach of faith with those who have supported the Attorney-General in introducing this legislation. But, more importantly, it removes the redress available to a person aggrieved. I would have thought that that was an entirely reasonable proposition and one which should be maintained in the legislation, however undesirable it is in other respects.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can satisfy the honourable gentleman by saying that what was said earlier is right. The Act has been restructured to enable, in the first instance, an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). That is what is happening. Of course, there can be an appeal from the AAT to the court. In other words, that section of the Act is not being displaced; it is just one removed. The idea was that, as we have an Administrative Appeals Tribunal, it might be able to deal effectively with a case on its merits. If it is not satisfied it will still be able to pursue this course. In accordance with the drafting, this proposal provides an opportunity for a court to review decisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal but that will be dealt with in a later section.
—If I had had that explanation in the first place I would not have even bothered the Attorney-General.

—I appreciate the position that we are all in. I can understand that the honourable gentleman, whilst completely opposing the legislation, is now anxious to improve the very numerous amendments. My officers felt that some amendments were technical and they have not had a chance to brief me on them because yesterday we were not able logistically to incorporate them. I think it would be helpful to have them incorporated because the proposed committee at least will be dealing with legislation that has been corrected in drafting terms. I am aware that the honourable gentlemen want to spend a lot of time discussing these amendments and I suppose that that will save discussion when the committee is formed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to say to my colleague the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) that if he read this clause in conjunction with clause 70, which relates to treatment by the court, I think that would be helpful.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 76 to 120-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 121 (Consultants etc.).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (14) Clause 121, page 49, line 20, omit ``Commission,'', substitute ``Commission''.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder why the Attorney-General hesitated.
—I wonder why too. This appears to be an amendment without a result.

—This amendment proposes to take out a word and replace it with exactly the same word. Even the spelling of the word is the same and both words have a capital `C'. I put it to the Attorney-General that it just does not make sense. Perhaps we need an amendment to the amendment. In response to something the Attorney-General said earlier in discussion on the previous clause, I want to assure him that I do not want to discuss these amendments at all. I would be perfectly happy not to be discussing them, given the second reading debate. But we will look like fools if these amendments go through without discussion in this place, regardless of how they may be treated by some committee which has not even been created yet. I assure the Attorney-General that I would prefer to be somewhere else rather than discussing these amendments. But I really want to understand them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome this detailed discussion by the honourable gentleman. I agree with him that I could not see the error in the proposed amendment but he will see it. It happens to be the comma which has been taken out. I would have thought that both of us would have seen it but I admit that I am as short-sighted as the honourable gentleman.
—The sharp-eyed Clerks at the table saw it.
—It would have helped us all if we had seen that we were deleting a comma.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 122 to 126-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 127 (Confidentiality).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (15) Clause 127, Page 51, lines 10 to 18, omit subclause (2), substitute the following subclauses:

``(2) For the purposes of subsection (1), the disclosure of information as required or permitted by a law of the Commonwealth or a prescribed law of a State or Territory shall be taken to be authorised use and disclosure of the information.
``(3) For the purposes of subsection (1), the disclosure of information by a person for the purposes of:
(a) performing the person's functions as:
(i) a member, staff member or Commission delegate; or
(ii) a person who is acting as a member or staff member or who is authorised to perform or exercise a function or power of, or on behalf of, the Commission; or
(b) the performance of functions or services by the person by way of assisting a Commission delegate;
shall be taken to be authorised use and disclosure of the information.
``(4) Where the Chairperson is satisfied that particular information:

(a) will enable or assist an agency, being the Advisory Committee, the Panel, the Disciplinary Board, the Review Board or any other agency within the meaning of the Freedom of Information Act 1982, to perform or exercise any of the agency's functions or powers;
(b) will enable or assist the government, or an agency, of a State or Territory to perform a function or exercise a power; or
(c) will enable or assist a government, or an agency, of a foreign country to perform a function, or exercise a power, conferred by a law in force in that foreign country;
the disclosure of the information to the agency or government by a person whom the Chairperson authorises for the purpose shall be taken to be authorised use and disclosure of the information.
``(5) The Chairperson may delegate all or any of his or her functions and powers under subsection (4) to a member or staff member.
``(6) Nothing in any of subsections (2), (3) and (4) limits:
(a) anything else in any of those subsections; or
(b) what may otherwise constitute, for the purposes of subsection (1), authorised use or disclosure of information.''.

This clause relates to the disclosure of confidential information by the Australian Securities Commission to certain agencies. It enables the Commission to disclose confidential information as required or permitted by law, or to assist an Australian overseas authority to perform a function similar to an ASC function. Of course, that would relate to mutual assistance treaties. I am advised that the amendment widens the categories of authorised disclosure. It will enable disclosure of information to a person or organisation for purposes associated with the performance of that person's or organisation's function, for example, disclosure to a securities or futures exchange for the purpose of conducting disciplinary proceedings. It will also enable disclosure to bodies created by the Bill, such as the panel or the Accounting Standards Review Board, or to domestic or foreign authorities which do not exercise functions similar to those of the ASC, if the ASC chairperson is satisfied that such disclosure will assist those authorities in the performance of their functions. I am advised that the amendment is similar to a provision in the Customs Administration Act, namely, section 16.

TALK.START.PARA: —I repeat something I said a moment ago, that is, that this amendment adds a further 30 or more lines-I have not had a chance to count them-to the legislation while replacing about half a dozen lines at the most. That is a major alteration by any stretch of the imagination. Again, I wonder whether the faith and confidence that the Attorney-General and his Department established in the lead-up discussions to this legislation are not betrayed by amendments put forward at such short notice. Certainly, that is not difficult to believe, given the Attorney-General's obvious difficulty with some of these changes, as illustrated by his comment that he has not had time to be briefed on these changes by his Department. That certainly indicates that no-one else has had a chance to discuss them either. It more than undermines the case he made that this legislation is the product of deep and meaningful discussions with people around Australia. That cannot possibly be the case when one contemplates an amendment of these dimensions.
—When the Attorney is addressing the previous question I ask him to describe the implications involved in information being passed from one agency to another with respect to a libel action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The information would be privileged in that sense, pursuant to statute which, as the honourable member would appreciate, is normal. We are dealing with the disclosure of information to assist those other bodies in the performance of their functions, for example, the Accounting Standards Review Board and our foreign authorities. If we have confidence in the Australian Securities Commission and it has confidential information, in the terms of normal law enforcement it is entitled to protect the other agencies with respect to that information. In other words, at the present time the Commission has the opportunity to disclose the information. We often do that already in other areas, for example, between State instrumentalities and the Commonwealth, particularly with respect to security or intended crime.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) seems to be concerned about the fact that we will do something about which he wants more information. The heading of the clause indicates that there is confidentiality. There will be an ability to disclose that information to enable the other bodies to have an opportunity to understand more effectively information that might have been gathered on a confidential basis.

I think that what we are all about is trying to assist in better law enforcement. While we attempted to do that in the original clause, the amendment is certainly a lot wider and it spells out, for example, the various areas that are involved. I repeat what I said at the beginning of the debate: I can understand the Opposition wanting a close examination of this legislation. I welcome that. However, there have been very many amendments as a result of suggestions received when the Bill was available to the public for a period of some five months. In other words, there has been a genuine effort to comply with the suggestions received.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should have been better briefed.

—I would have liked to be better briefed, but the legislation is now before us. I am anxious that the Bill be examined. I would have thought, and I hoped, that we might be able to agree to the Bill. However, the Opposition has the difficulty of opposing the Bill, and I understand that. The Opposition now wants to have the Bill completely debated, and that is fair enough. I made the point at the outset that we would have a committee of the two Houses, which is something that members opposite may or may not accept. I would have thought that in that situation we could have avoided the committee debate in this place. I can see that the Opposition's strategy is to debate the Bill for so long that it may not pass, and that is its prerogative. I will not delay members opposite or gag them-the debate will just go on and on. If that is the way it will be, we probably have only to look at how we might use up the time rather than to look at the merits of the Bill. I wanted members opposite to genuinely examine the Bill in the appropriate committees of both Houses. However, members opposite do not want to do that; instead, I think that they just want to delay the Bill, and I cannot stop them from doing that.

—In response to the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), I point out that people in the business community that I spoke to, particularly in the accounting profession, indicated that the availability of information to the Accounting Standards Review Board and the Disciplinary Board would assist them in the management of their profession. I understand that the thrust of this amendment flows from that feedback from the community. As the Attorney-General (Mr Bowen) said, it is that disclosure process, after the Bill was made available to people to examine for a period, that brings us to this position in relation to this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond to the Attorney. I point out that it took almost three days to debate the cooperative scheme, so by no means is it inappropriate to take the time to request information on this Bill.
—Did you send it to a committee?
—Yes, it went on for a whole three days.
—In a committee?
—It was two days in a committee.
—You are talking about a parliamentary committee.
—No, I am not talking about a parliamentary committee; I am talking about a committee of the House.
—The honourable member for Ryan will not discuss the matter across the table.

—A question is raised with respect to the fact that the amendments were dropped on me at 5.30 last night, when I was told that they would be debated today. So I have every right to be suspicious about what they might contain. I was not given time to read them and consider their contents. I am asking the Attorney-General for explanations, as is the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), and we are richly entitled to do that. The presentation of the amendments has been totally botched. It is completely misleading to suggest that, because the Bill will go to a Senate committee-which may or may not join up with one from this House-that is the more appropriate place in which to raise these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney has already admitted that the sort of committee proposed from the Senate will have a very narrow view of the legislation-not a broad view but a narrow view. As a consequence, we are richly entitled to an explanation of the 280 amendments brought forward by the Attorney.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked why we were amending this clause now, and I said that we were responding to submissions put to us and providing for people who might want the information. I went on to say that I thought it was going to be a long process and that I understood that that was what the Opposition wanted. I made the point that we were agreeing to appropriate scrutiny by a committee appointed by both Houses, but the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) seemed to say that that may not happen. I give him an undertaking that it will happen, not because I want him to shorten his interests in the matter but just to make it very clear that that was the proposal. I wonder what the State Attorneys-General think of the performance. As I pointed out, they will be seeking to come to some arrangements on 1 November. If they do maybe the committee will not be necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to leave it in the air that we are being obstructionist, which is the implication of what the Attorney-General has said.
—I did not say that.
—It sounded like that to me. If he did not say that I accept his assurance on it.
—I said there was another opportunity.

—There is not another opportunity, in the sense that once this legislation goes through this chamber it is beyond the control of this place and anything may happen to it after that. Really this is part of the mentality of the Government. I say this very respectfully: this chamber is not a legislative chamber and there is some good reason to view it that way, but let us not perpetuate that view of the House of Representatives when we are confronted with very important legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I just want to add that I am not concerned with what the State Attorneys-General want. They have had a go at legislation in this area. I do not care how they view our operations in this place. I hope that in their own parliaments they get an adequate opportunity to discuss at great length the legislation now before us and the complementary State legislation that flows from it.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being past 12.45 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 101a I shall report progress.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Question Time yesterday the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack) raised with me matters relating to the conduct of Question Time. The honourable member for O'Connor raised with me the daily number of questions asked during Question Time and asked that I consult with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the matter. The House will understand that the suggestion that I consult with the Prime Minister is unrealistic and I do not intend to do so.

INTERJECT.PARA: I remind the House that on 22 October 1986 I made a comprehensive statement on Question Time, also in response to the honourable member for O'Connor. I commend to honourable members a reading of that statement, but feel that the following points should be repeated:

Bearing in mind the length of some of the questions and the ground they cover, controlling the length of answers becomes even more difficult. The House should grasp the nettle and determine its procedures so that Question Time will serve the purpose that members require. If the House wants more questions, it should face that fact and adopt the Standing Orders to ensure this.

. . . that it is the House, through its members, which decides the way the House operates. Although the problems we are facing with Question Time have been with us for many years, the House has not been prepared to accept its responsibilities. Instead, members have consistently place the blame for the inadequacies of the system on the Chair, when the responsibility lies solely with the House, and the House alone. I now place the matter in the hands of the House, where it squarely belongs.

Honourable members will be aware that on 27 November 1986 the Procedure Committee reported to the House on the conduct of Question Time. The report included recommendations to improve the number of questions asked. In March 1987 the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) gave notice of a motion with similar intent. Neither set of proposals has been debated by this House.

Yesterday the honourable member for O'Connor referred to the number of questions asked during the period of Speaker Snedden and currently. I point out to the House that the average number asked in 1976, 19.3, was the highest number for any year since 1970. In the ensuing six years the average number was 16 and in the 5 1/2 years during the present Government the average has been 12.2. At the end of the autumn sittings, the average was 12.5. There is a slight difference between 12.5, 16 and 19.3. I understand that the honourable member for O'Connor has some responsibility for the organisation of Opposition business in the House. In the light of what I have said, I suggest that the course of action he should pursue is to take up the matter with the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in order that the issue might be resolved.

The matter raised by the honourable member for Tangney was the question of relevance of answers as provided for in standing order 145. The difficulty of determining the relevancy of answers has been expressed by me on numerous occasions in the past. On numerous occasions I have asked Ministers to remain relevant or to draw their answers to a close.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —That was unnecessary. Whilst, as the honourable member for Tangney says, standing order 145 is one of the shortest standing orders, it is not necessarily the clearest by way of interpretation. The question of relevance is generally a matter of opinion or judgment. I find myself in exactly the same position as previous Speakers who have had difficulty in pleasing all sections of the House. As Speaker Jenkins observed in 1984:

INTERJECT.PARA: When general questions are asked it is very difficult to define them down to specific relevant parts.

I have indicated before, and I repeat-although it should not be necessary-that I possess no power to require the Prime Minister to end an answer. Indeed, although I am reluctant to admit it, I have no power to order any Minister to end an answer. In the past I have done so. I have never done so in relation to the Prime Minister. I give him, as I give the Leader of the Opposition, considerable latitude, and I do not intend to change that practice.

Again, I remind the House that the Procedure Committee report on Question Time made recommendations on the relevance of answers. The House, in whose court the matter rests, has not dealt with that issue either.

At Question Time the spirit and intent of the Standing Orders are often misused and abused. Constant interjections, many unrecorded by Hansard, flow across the House. Many of those who draw the Chair's attention to the Standing Orders are often themselves outside those Standing Orders. I again tell the House that the Standing Orders apply to all members. Speakers have always tolerated interjections, but repeated interjections become disorderly. Failure to accept the authority of the Chair puts members totally outside the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before making an announcement about ministerial arrangements, I hope that the Chair will allow me the indulgence of saying, I am sure on behalf of all members of the House, how thrilled we all were at the magnificent achievements in the lunch period of Debbie Flintoff-King. Our congratulations go to her-and best wishes to Ric Charlesworth and his mates.
—It's a wonder you weren't there.
—I would love to have been there, but I had my priorities right. I was there in spirit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Trade Negotiations, Mr Duffy, is departing Australia today on Government business. He will return to Australia on 12 October. Questions normally directed to Mr Duffy should be addressed to the Minister for Defence, Mr Beazley.

SPEECH.PARA: As a courtesy, I inform the House that the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support, Mr Punch, is representing the Government at European Community Day at World Expo 88 in Brisbane and will be absent from Question Time today. Questions which would normally be addressed to Mr Punch should be directed to the portfolio Minister, Mr Willis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Treasurer to the recent repayments of some of our yen and Swiss franc loans which were announced by the Treasurer during his swanning around overseas. Given that these loans were initially negotiated substantially because they attracted very low interest rates-3 to 5 per cent-will the Acting Treasurer explain to the House why these low interest rate loans are being repaid in preference to a number of much higher interest rate loans on the Government's books? Is it because the Government has no confidence in its ability to maintain the value of the Australian dollar?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the question from the honourable member I would say that this Government has had a greater task in managing the borrowing program largely because of policies that it inherited and for which he and the Leader of the Opposition were largely responsible. The honourable member should bear in mind that nearly 50 per cent of those borrowings which we will be paying back this year were entered into not by this Government but by the former coalition Government.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Speaker. We have already arrived at the question of relevance. You have just made a very considered statement to the chamber and the Opposition is doing everything in its power to comply by asking specific questions. The question was about why the Treasurer paid out a 3 per cent loan instead of a 10 per cent loan, and the Acting Treasurer is dodging the question. He does not know.
—Order! The Minister is answering the question. I suggest that the honourable member for O'Connor abide by the rest of the Standing Orders and not continue to disrupt the House.

—This Government believes that it is important, if a government is interested in protecting itself from exchange rate variations, to start off by paying off the debt. The debt we are paying off is one which was largely accumulated by our predecessors in office.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Well may they laugh but, as I said before, nearly 50 per cent of the debt that we will be retiring this year will be debt which was entered into by our predecessors. Of course, it is prudent for us to begin the task of paying back the debt which was accumulated largely because of the fiscal inheritance which we received from the Leader of the Opposition and his brilliant economic adviser, who now sits on the other side of the House as the honourable member for Wentworth. The honourable member for Wentworth has produced some figures, the accuracy of which I cannot support. He has made certain assumptions.
—So Keating's press release is wrong, is it?

—This is the press release of the shadow Minister for Finance. The shadow Minister's press release makes certain assumptions about exchange rates prevailing at certain times. I am quite happy to have those matters checked for him. But the simple fact is that this Government is concerned about diminishing the debt. That is why we have been pursuing a responsible fiscal policy, a responsible wages policy, in stark contrast with the irresponsibility of those who went before us.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Housing and Aged Care, and it concerns the review of the highly successful home and community care program. What progress is being made in the triennial review of the program? Is the Minister seeking to put in place a strategic plan for each State? Has the program been successful in Victoria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Burke for his question. In referring to the success of the home and community care program, particularly in Victoria, I mention the honourable member's success in gaining credit for that program in his electorate. The program has been extremely successful. The triennial review is well under way and is reaching completion. It is important to note that, as part of that review, we are to have strategic plans for the first time in Australia to ensure that the home and community care program is properly put in place. Victoria is the first to announce, with the Commonwealth, its strategic plan.

ANSWER.PARA: The reality is that the home and community care program has been one of the major social justice achievements of this Government. In 1985 it brought together under one umbrella a range of services that were scattered all over the place to serve the frail aged and the young disabled. It is symbolic of the Hawke Labor Government's commitment to building aged care and social justice programs. Funds for the program have increased by over 20 per cent every year since the program began. It now receives over $200m a year. It is also symbolic of the Cain Labor Government's commitment to building an aged care and social justice program. It has matched the Commonwealth all the way. Now in its strategic plan the State has displayed its clear commitment to the people of Victoria. We have had a few gold medal performances. The home and community care program, from both this Government and the Victorian Government, is itself a gold medal performance.
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the cackles coming from those opposite are curious. That is all we get out of them as policy-cackles. Instead of care, we get scare. That is the limit of their policy on aged care. As they are so interested in the home and community care program, it is interesting to note that the Liberal Party policy does not even mention the home and community care program as such. Imagine it! The people who are purporting to become the Government of Victoria in a few days' time do not even mention the home and community care program in their policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I heard a few National Party cackles as well. Does the National Party have a policy? Who has heard of it? What are its priorities? The reality is that this is probably a rare example of unity between the National Party and the Liberal Party: neither party has a policy on the home and community care program. What are the implications for the aged and disabled of the Opposition parties being in government in Victoria? If I were a frail aged or disabled Victorian, I would be very worried about the prospect of the rabble from that side coming into government next week. But that will not be the case. There is only one choice for the future of the home and community care program, that is, a combination of the Hawke Labor Government and the Cain Labor Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Treasurer to reports in this morning's press that the Prime Minister issued a denial that he, the Prime Minister, had predicted at a meeting of the Labor Caucus that interest rates would fall a little. Following the Prime Minister's denial, will the Acting Treasurer withdraw his remark made in the House yesterday that `this Government has set the circumstances whereby there will be a general downward trend in interest rates'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said yesterday is what I will repeat today. That is, the stance of fiscal policy and the stance of general economic policy being pursued by this Government are such that they will underpin lower interest rates. That is the case. That is the case because we have brought in a Budget based on fiscal policy which will see a surplus of $5 1/2 billion, a surplus which is a massive turnaround from the deficit that we inherited from our predecessors. That deficit was something like 4 per cent of gross domestic product, and now we have a Budget surplus of something like one per cent of GDP. That transference, that turnaround, in fiscal policy has not been matched anywhere in the world. There are other aspects of our economic policy which, in terms of the management of inflation and so on, will also ensure that there is an underpinning of a lower interest rate regime.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me say again what I said yesterday: we do not rely on manipulation for the management of interest rates. I think Opposition members must be living in some kind of time warp. They must think that we are still back in the regulatory regime that they used to manage month upon month when they tried to manipulate rates quite deliberately. Of course, if there were an election in the offing they would manipulate even more enthusiastically.

Interest rates in this country are determined by market forces. They are determined by factors, some of which we have control over, some of which we do not, such as international circumstances. The important thing to remember is that there is a demand for finance in this country which is underpinning a very substantial investment surge. Something like 12 per cent investment is predicted over the next 12 months. In order to ensure that there is maximum scope for that investment to take place without there being upward pressure on interest rates, we have ensured through our fiscal policy that there will be no net borrowings by any level of government in this country. That is the kind of fiscal policy which our opponents would never be able to match, could not even contemplate in the past, and certainly will never be entrusted to have another go at in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the many structural changes that are occurring in the Australian economy due to the excellent policies and actions of the Hawke Government since its election and the Cain Government in Victoria. Can the Prime Minister advise the House of the effects on the manufacturing industry of the structural changes occurring within the Australian economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and, as I think all honourable members would appreciate, an important objective of all the processes of restructuring the Australian economy is to achieve a diversification of our export base. Of course, that requires a reversal of the years of neglect that characterised government by the Opposition parties when they were on this side of the House. Certainly, I am proud to be able to stand up in this House and say that the policies we have brought in to restructure the Australian economy are having the positive and desired effect.
—Come off it! Rubbish!

—I know that Opposition members do not like the facts so I will give them some. Fact one relates to what the coalition Government did to manufacturing employment in this country. In the coalition's seven years in office manufacturing employment declined by an average annual rate of 1.6 per cent. That is, each year employment in manufacturing was down by 1.6 per cent. This Government has turned that around and now manufacturing employment is growing again at an annual average rate of 0.8 per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at manufacturing investment. Under my Government it has increased at an average annual rate three times greater than that which existed under the conservative Government. In each of the last three years for which figures are available real private new capital expenditure in manufacturing increased by 10 per cent or more. Between June 1976 and June 1983 the increase in manufactured exports in real terms was 5 per cent. That was the coalition's achievement. Under this Government it has increased to 8.5 per cent a year. In 1986-87 real manufacturing exports increased by around 15 per cent and in 1987-88 they increased by 13 per cent. That is the clear indictment of the Opposition's neglect of Australia's manufacturing base. We have turned around that neglect and created an Australia in which our manufacturers can go out and take on the best in the world. They are now beating them in the most competitive markets.

I can also advise honourable members that in this magnificent achievement that has characterised this Government, the State of Victoria is leading the way in the revival of manufacturing industry. Moreover, private business investment in all sectors in Victoria over the past five years has grown at double the rate of that in Australia as a whole. Contrast the six years of the Cain Government in Victoria, when that State has been doing twice as well as the rest of Australia, with the six years prior to 1982 when under the coalition we saw Victoria's share of investment decline markedly.

As we are looking at the contribution of the State of Victoria to this magnificent achievement of the expansion of the Australian economy, I point out that in the last 60 months in a row Victoria has had the lowest unemployment rate in the whole country. While I am speaking of this area, let me also look at the question of industrial relations. Industrial relations were in chaos under the coalition because it looked for confrontation. Under this Government strikes and time lost were reduced by 62 per cent. There has been a 62 per cent reduction under this Government compared with the Opposition's miserable record. In the last 12 months working days lost per 1,000 workers in Victoria totalled 139, as against the national average of 212. In other words, the Victorian achievement is 35 per cent better than that of Australia as a whole. By any measure one can use, the performance nationally under the Labor Government has put to shame the record of those people opposite when they were in government. Indeed, in the enormous recovery that has taken place in the Australian economy in general and in the manufacturing sector in particular, I am proud to say that Victoria, under the Cain Labor Government, has led the way in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Acting Treasurer. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Is she aware of the very serious claims by the Opposition spokesman for defence, the honourable member for McPherson, to the effect that defence personnel at Holsworthy Army Barracks are being forced to buy paint to improve their living quarters and to hire gardeners to mow their lawns? Is there any truth in these very serious claims? What is the Minister doing to address those concerns?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. His concern for and interest in the service men and women at Holsworthy are a credit to him and his representation. The shadow Minister for defence, the honourable member for McPherson, has recently put out two press releases, one on the subject of grass and mowing and the other on the subject of soldiers paying for maintenance out of their own pockets.

ANSWER.PARA: Firstly, I wish to refer to the maintenance of barracks accommodation at Holsworthy. According to the honourable member for McPherson, this has been reduced by 60 per cent in recent years and this year there has been a further reduction of 30 per cent. Those are totally imaginary statistics; they are wrong. This financial year $2.75m will be spent on repairs and maintenance, including $1.2m on programmed items, which represents an increase of about a quarter of a million dollars on the 1987-88 financial year. The Opposition cannot add up, as usual. Over the next five years 19 accommodation blocks at Holsworthy will be upgraded into single room accommodation at a cost of about $8m. The upgrading will also include painting. However, in the meantime soldiers may choose to paint their own accommodation. They may not even like the old colour scheme. The Army encourages self-help. We believe that it is a sensible and quick way to effect minor repairs. That may include minor painting tasks. The Army is happy to supply stores, including paint, for this purpose, though I cannot guarantee that all colours will be available. The shadow Minister for defence will no doubt now produce a further press release claiming that all the colours are not available, but I can live with that. In fact, the Minister for Defence can live with that and, more importantly, so can the soldiers of Holsworthy. I hope that this reassures the honourable member for Hughes.

I come to the second major point referred to-that of mowing. Since the Opposition has announced that it has a shadow Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, I do not know what the next press release will be from the shadow Minister for defence because he never puts out anything of strategic importance. To do justice to the weight of the Opposition spokesman's case on this issue I want to quote directly from what he said. Obviously I will have to edit it because his releases are always very wordy. I quote from his press release:

Soldiers passing the hat around to collect money to hire someone to cut the grass around their barracks is symptomatic of the frustration that Servicemen and women are feeling about . . . the inconsequential duties they are expected to perform.

The fact is that the mowing of unit lawns has been a unit responsibility for years. The mowers are supplied and the mowing is done either as a duty requirement or by defaulters as a mild punishment. That does not seem to me serious enough to justify--
Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition's Treasury spokesman and his colleagues ought to listen to the solution of the honourable member for McPherson to the problem. He says:

ANSWER.PARA: There is only one way to tackle the growing problem . . . and that is to increase the number of uniformed personnel . . .

I can only conclude that it is the shadow Minister's view that the Army should form a mowing corps at Holsworthy. The picture that conjures up is quite appealing: lawn mowers painted in camouflage, equipped with protective armour and light guns mounted on them. But seriously, there are real issues that matter to the service men and women at Holsworthy barracks, and they are the issues that this Government is concentrating on and is tackling. For instance, on Friday I am opening a new maintenance facility at Moorebank set up by the Defence Housing Authority to improve the standard of repairs and maintenance of married quarters throughout the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, you are wasting Question Time.

—The Opposition interjects that we are wasting Question Time by talking about improvements in the Defence Force. We do not believe that to be a waste of Question Time, and we are very proud of our real achievements in defence conditions.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister inform the House of the new arrangements for the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of the House will be aware that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) is required by Act of Parliament to broadcast parliamentary proceedings, and it does so on Radio National. As from the commencement of these Budget sittings the proceedings have also been broadcast by the ABC on an additional set of frequencies operating on ABC standby transmitters as part of a proposed changeover process which is intended to see the proceedings broadcast exclusively on these new channels. These arrangements were announced by my predecessor, Senator Gareth Evans, on 9 August. This week, however, broadcasts are being conducted simultaneously on both Radio National and the new stations for the daytime proceedings but the night-time proceedings are being broadcast exclusively on the new stations. This trial arrangement has been approved by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings, and if it proves satisfactory it is intended to move to exclusive coverage on the new channels thereafter.

ANSWER.PARA: I am sure the moving of the broadcast of parliamentary proceedings from Radio National will please ABC Radio National listeners, as it will give the ABC the capacity to provide the full range of Radio National services whilst enabling those masochists who listen regularly to parliamentary broadcasts to continue to do so. The ABC has publicised the new arrangements for this week through its capital city radio services and in the Listener program magazine. It has also been announced regularly by the announcer who hosts the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. I can assure the House that the new arrangements will be carefully monitored and that the move to exclusive coverage on the new frequencies will occur only if it proves absolutely satisfactory.
