—I refer the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to an article which appeared in the Australian on Saturday and which described southern bluefin tuna as being `driven towards extinction' by fishermen from Australia and Japan. The fishery is potentially one of the world's most valuable but the stock is in a critically depleted state. What is the Government doing in response to the unanimous advice from scientists that, unless the catches of southern bluefin are dramatically reduced, the fishery will collapse?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie-curly Campbell- for his question and for the close interest he has in the southern bluefin tuna fishery. The first obligation of any Australian fisheries Minister is to conserve our fish stocks, unlike the slack previous Government. Under this Government the Australian southern bluefin tuna fishery has been subject to stringent controls through a quota regime under a management plan since 1984. Some scientists are now so concerned by the level of stock depletion that they say that no southern bluefin tuna should be caught until the stock recovers.

ANSWER.PARA: Our catch limit has been reduced to over half the level of the early 1980s. This species is a single, migratory species and its conservation and survival are totally dependent on cooperation between all the countries that fish it. A meeting is presently under way between Australia, Japan and New Zealand to try to establish the catch quota for this year. Those negotiations have been going on for quite some time. To my mind it is absolutely essential that we reduce the quota again this year, possibly by at least another 50 per cent. Australia is also pressing for an international agreement so that we can bring the stock totally under control for the other fisheries that fish in this fishery.

All the catches must now be covered by a quota. Previously, there were incidental catch provisions. In other words, an incidental catch could be caught by fishing boats in other fisheries. The 4,000 or so boats with Commonwealth licences have some incidental catch provision, allowing a catch of up to one tonne. There are 40 other boats with an incidental catch provision of five tonnes.

The development of the sashimi market, where a tonne is worth anything up to $50,000-in contrast to the early days, in 1984, when we put the regime in place and the catch was worth between $700 and $900 a tonne-has made the fishery very profitable. I put into place the regulations to withdraw the incidental catch provisions to preserve the stock. The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology is now looking at the provisions that I have put forward, mainly due to an opportunistic stunt by some Liberal senators. The Committee faces a weighty responsibility. The equity situation is such that anyone can still enter the fishery by leasing or buying quota. A fisherman can still lease quota for $1,000 a tonne, catch his tonne of fish if he wants to and probably get up to $50,000 for it in the sashimi market in Tokyo.

The Australian Fisheries Council agrees exactly with what the Commonwealth is doing. The Senate Standing Committee must see the connection between the crisis in the tuna resource and the removal of the one and five tonne provisions. I re-emphasise that the provisions which were introduced so as to allow commercial gain from tuna caught incidentally by people fishing for other species are now being used by people to enter the tuna fishery by the back door. I intend writing to the Senate Committee to make this point. I need go no further than to report a complaint by a fisherman I met a fortnight ago who said that the deletion of the one tonne and five tonne quota provisions would spoil all his plans for tuna fishing. He admitted that all his planning investment decisions had been based on entry to the fishery by targeting southern bluefin tuna. I believe that it would be absolute lunacy for us to keep on the books a regulation permitting the incidental catch of up to 4,5000 tonnes of tuna when the stock is totally under threat.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister will recall that, following the presentation of the 1987-88 Budget Speech, the Treasurer made several press comments to the effect that his next great objective was to reform the labour market. Can the Prime Minister detail for me those reforms of the labour market that he, the Government or the Treasurer has been able to achieve during the intervening 15 months?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not time to go to all elements of the broad subject opened up by the honourable member, but I will go to what I think will be seen in historical terms as the single most important thing that has been done. That is the cooperative work that has been undertaken by the Government, trade union movement and employers, and now with the endorsement of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, to undertake the restructuring of the Australian awards. I am sure that when the history of this period is written nothing that has been done will be seen to have even approached the importance of this issue.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have in Australia at the moment is a set of awards which, in so many cases, represent the inheritance of 50 or 60 years ago. For instance, let me refer to the metal trades award. The metal trades award has, I think, about 370 classifications which have grown up over 50, 60, 70 or 80 years. As a result of the discussions that we have had with the trade union movement and the employers-and I pay great tribute to the Metal Trades Industry Association in general and to Bert Evans in particular-with their cooperation we are creating a framework within the metal trades so that, instead of having 370 or 380 classifications, that number will be reduced to eight or nine. This means that, in that important section of the labour market, instead of putting people into categories and classifications which have no relevance to modern day production, we will have a system which will be relevant to the type of production that characterises not only the metal trades but manufacturing industry generally. It will affect training and the opportunity for movement between classifications, which hitherto would not have been possible.

Nothing will open up the labour market in a productive sense in the manufacturing area-but not only in the manufacturing area-more than this dramatic restructuring of the Australian award system. I repeat: a great deal of credit is owed in that respect to my Ministers who have been involved, and to the leadership of the trade union movement in general and the leaders of the particular unions concerned. Also, as I say, without question enormous tribute is owed to the employers who have cooperated in this matter. As I say, the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in its most recent decision has set down a framework of principles which will facilitate this massive restructuring.

I say to the honourable gentleman, because I know he has real concern about these issues-he is not just fishing around; he has a real concern-that it is my judgment that when we get that restructuring of the metal trades awards, which will be effective by next year, and having regard to the concurrent work on other major awards, we will have an award system which not only will deal, as the honourable gentleman knows, with the setting of pay and conditions, but also will be relevant to the training processes for labour and industry. We will have a set of awards, award conditions, and facilities for the training and movement of people between positions that will match the requirements of the Australian economy if it is to be fully competitive in the world today.

Many other things have been done. I could talk about them, and would be quite happy to talk in detail to the honourable gentleman in private. If I had to pick one thing during the period which he talked about, the last 15 months, that has changed the labour market, I would pick the changes which are taking place in the area that I have talked about and which will produce a more flexible, more relevant and better trained work force than we have ever had. Importantly, it will continue to be flexible and relevant to the needs of the Australian economy in the years ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I claim to have been misrepresented in the statement made by the honourable member for Bruce (Mr Aldred).

—Order! If the Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting I can continue to hear--
—Why do you not run it fairly?
—If the Leader of the Opposition continues to interject in that fashion I will warn him. I will not enter into any debate with him. I call the Minister.
—On or about 15 or 16 May, the honourable member--
—I did hear the remarks of the Minister. I found them personally offensive and I ask that they be withdrawn. Everybody appears to have heard them except you.

—The Chair did not hear what the Minister said because of interjections. I have asked the Minister, because I did not hear. I can only ask for a value judgment to be made by him. It may help the debate in the House if the Minister withdraws.
—If the honourable member who is making juvenile interjections feels offended and he wants to complain, I am happy to withdraw, but he has not asked me to withdraw.

—He has not asked for me to withdraw, but if he wants me to I would be perfectly happy to do so. —Order! The Minister will not respond to interjections.

—The honourable member for North Sydney would be aware that the Minister has just completed his personal explanation.

—If the honourable member had been watching he would have seen that the Minister was about to sit down.

—The honourable member might resume his seat so that we can get on with the matter of public importance.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I want to--

—Withdraw.
—Is the Minister seeking to take a point of order?

It might help the debate if the honourable member for North Sydney withdraws. We might then get on with the matter of public importance and we will have no more of this juvenile behaviour. I call the honourable member for North Sydney.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The cynical manipulation of interest rates by the Hawke/Keating Government.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The subject before the House today in this matter of public importance is probably one of the single most important failings in economic management by this Government in its term in office-that is, the arrogant, cynical and quite irresponsible way in which it has manipulated interest rates for short term political ends. It has done this on several occasions in its short period in office and it is at it again at present prior to next Saturday's Victorian election. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) cannot help himself when it comes to manipulating interest rates or travelling allowances. But in a typical, cynical and arrogant fashion the Government is attempting to hold interest rates down now against mounting evidence, including today's balance of payments figures, that interest rates are on an upward trend in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members might remember that last February and March the Government did the same thing basically before the New South Wales election. Early last year we saw it do the same thing in the lead-up to the Federal election and in 1984, when the Treasurer cut his teeth, he significantly manipulated interest rates in the latter half of 1984 before an election then as well. There can be no doubt that this sort of behaviour, this manipulation of interest rates for short term political gain, is blatantly dishonest and totally irresponsible. It has a significant fundamental effect on the lives of average Australians.

Let me begin by drawing the attention of the House to some of the circumstances of the past in which this sort of behaviour has been pursued. Any one of the three or four examples that I picked will establish the trend that has been reflected in more recent activity. But the example that I would like to draw on is what I would call the bank holiday massacre of August 1984. I want to try to describe in general terms what apparently took place at that time just before the bank holiday weekend in the early part of August 1984. Two officers of the Reserve Bank of Australia met with the Treasurer for what is traditionally described as the Board debrief. The Board meeting of the Reserve Bank had been held on the previous Tuesday. Of course, such Board debriefings are usually pretty routine matters, not really of much moment, except on this occasion. Honourable members should imagine that the Governor of the Bank and one of his senior henchmen are in the Treasurer's office waiting for the Treasurer, quite innocently and quite unsuspecting. Their reflective mood was soon bowled over as the Treasurer walked straight into the room in normal, quiet and unassuming fashion. They were undoubtedly in awe of this great man and the way that he entered the room; undoubtedly they were fairly twitchy and nervous to be in the presence of such a great one; and obviously they had no idea of what was about to happen to them. Apparently, on that particular occasion, the Treasurer dispensed with the usual pleasantries. There were no `G'day sleazebags, dummies and scumbags' on that occasion-he went straight to the main game. He was preoccupied. One can imagine how the officers were caught by surprise when he said, and I am paraphrasing, `What do you'-I pause here because I have to exclude two fairly colourful expletives which I will replace with the words `fine chaps'-two fine chaps think you are doing with interest rates?' Honourable members can imagine their surprise, especially of a quiet and conservative person like the Governor of the Reserve Bank.

Apparently they were then subjected to the usual rambling barrage of verbiage that tends to flow out of the Treasurer's mouth. Apparently, as it turns out, they had not fully appreciated the Treasurer's very deep-seated philosophical attachment to free markets and apparently they did not appreciate the fact that the Treasurer had been up all night working on his desk top Empire period computer, coming to the conclusion that interest rates should be much lower than they were at that time.

Apparently the Treasurer argued to the Bank that the fall in inflation that he thought was under way at that time was not being fully reflected, or sufficiently reflected, in falling interest rates. In his view, interest rates clearly should have been much lower than they were. The Treasurer's logic apparently had nothing to do with the fact that the Government was planning an early election in late 1984! Apparently, after that fairly illuminating meeting, the Governor of the Reserve Bank and his henchman went back to the Reserve Bank and over the bank holiday weekend called together their troops and explained to them the details of the massacre that had taken place, and issued instructions to lower interest rates. Needless to say, at that time the Government did a pretty heavy job on the media, as is its tendency on these sorts of occasions, to convince them that that was a normal market reaction to the emerging economic circumstances of the time. In this regard I find it quite interesting to recall a very recent comment by Ross Gittins in the Sydney Morning Herald, who, when referring to the incident in 1984, described it thus:

. . . the ham-fisted easing of policy in the runup to the 1984 election, which I now have no doubt was made under political instruction. The episode still rankles, since I was sold a pup at the time, and on-sold it in this column.

Against that background I think it is enlightening to consider some of the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Ministers at the time of the 1984 election. Honourable members will recall the now quite famous statement by the Prime Minister on 20 November 1984 when, a week before the election-and unrelated to that event, of course-he said:
At present, the outlook for interest rates is as bright as it has been for more than a decade.
Australia and Australians will during 1985 reap the interest rate rewards that are flowing from successful policies of the past 20 months.
We've ploughed the fields and sown the seeds. In the near future we will harvest the crop.

A very similar sort of statement was made yesterday by the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), as alluded to by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in a question he asked today. To refresh the memories of honourable members, the Acting Treasurer said that this Government had `set the circumstances whereby there will be a general downward trend in interest rates'. If we go back to 1984 and look at the track record following that brilliant statement by the Prime Minister, we will see that interest rates almost doubled in the course of 1985. Short term market interest rates rocketed from around 10.9 per cent or so at the time of that first meeting to nearly 19.6 per cent by the end of 1985. The prime rate for large corporate loans went up to 21 per cent by December 1985, and savings bank home interest rates hit a record 15.5 per cent not long thereafter. That is the sort of track record we have from this Government.

I turn now to another circumstance earlier this year prior to the New South Wales election. Then there was a desperate attempt to try to save the jewel in the Australian Labor Party crown and protect Barrie and his cardigans from annihilation. The circumstances were quite clear at the time. There was a conscious effort to keep interest rates down against mounting evidence of deteriorating balance of payments and inflationary circumstances. What happened straight after the New South Wales election? Not surprisingly, there was a tightening of monetary policy in April, May and June and interest rates jumped significantly from around 10.5 per cent on average in February to a little over 13 per cent by the end of the financial year. The track record speaks for itself.

Against that background I suggest that it is not unreasonable to ask the Acting Treasurer, as I did yesterday, whether similar discussions took place in current circumstances prior to the Victorian election on Saturday. At the present time interest rates are clearly on an upward course. Undoubtedly the Acting Treasurer will put out the normal party line that things are getting better, that we have turned the corner and that we are on the mend. Of course, he will overlook things like the balance of payments figures that came out today which show a $1.391 billion deficit for August on top of a $1.5 billion deficit, now revised downwards a little bit, for July. That is $2.9 billion in two months. We are a third of the way to the balance of payments projection for this year of a $9.5 billion deficit in a sixth of the time. Of course, the Acting Treasurer will get up and accuse me of picking a couple of figures that are favourable to my cause, so I will go back further: I will take the last six months and include the very favourable figure for April that he likes to draw attention to. If we take the last six months, the balance of payments deficit is presently running, at an average annual rate, at $13.9 billion. That is quite a lot higher than the $9.5 billion projected for this year by the Treasurer in his Budget Papers.

Similarly, the Treasurer would have us believe that inflation is on a downward track. He has the magic projection, which has now almost emerged as a target, of 4.5 per cent by the middle of next year, and somewhere between 3 per cent and 4 per cent by the middle of 1990. However, that seems to fly directly in the face of what is obviously an over-heated economy with very difficult domestic economic circumstances, rising balance of payments pressures, rising wage costs and other labour costs. In the last 12 months the Government has never given substantial justification for an inflation forecast of that magnitude.

One of the characteristic things that we find with this Treasurer, and we are seeing it now on his trip overseas, in his unbounded optimism about how things are going. Even when the International Monetary Fund, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development or some other institution is moderately pessimistic about the world economy, the Treasurer has a glowingly optimistic assessment about how world growth will be maintained, how commodity prices will stay up, how world interest rates will not jump significantly, how world inflation will not pick up significantly and how there will not be a secondary correction in the stock market. I ask the House to think about each of those circumstances. The Treasurer has locked us into a very high risk economic strategy which is unattainable at the present time. If honourable members do not believe me, they need only go back and look at the forecasts in the Budget document, and look at last year's outcomes and compare them with this year's forecast. Some poor misguided soul has basically gone through and copied out those outcomes and made them look like forecasts. The Government does not believe any of that hogwash. It wants to get through the Victorian election, and presumably an early election in Western Australia. The Government is playing its old game of manipulating its assessment of economic circumstances and economic management.
With respect to the bottom line of the Treasurer's Budget Speech for 1988-89, I draw attention to these comments:
But we must be on guard against excessive import pressures threatening the recovery in our balance of payments.
Last year the strong boost to incomes from the lift in commodity prices led to imports rising more rapidly than we had expected.
As a consequence monetary policy was tightened . . .
For the future, while other instruments have taken a greater share of the weight, monetary policy must continue to play its vital balancing role in the overall strategy of restraint.

While the Treasurer has been out there in the last few weeks manipulating interest rates, holding them down, clearly he still has in mind that admission-by somebody in that Budget Speech-that the bottom line will be higher interest rates down the track. The prediction I make in the House today is that once we are through the Victorian election next week official interest rates will go on with their upward trend, as of course will housing interest rates, in a significant way, in the course of the next few months.

Government members may talk and manipulate as much as they like; the fundamentals are there. One of the most interesting things is that the financial markets clearly do not agree with their assessment of what is happening because in the last week or so financial markets have started to move the interest rate structure up. The professional market rates are now running well ahead of the official rates managed by the Reserve Bank. Indeed, there is a very large gap opening up between those rates.

The market is not going to be fooled. It is not going to tie itself into deals for next week or the week after at interest rates that are going to blow it out of the water. It has started to vote with its feet. After today's balance of payments number I bet the market is totally convinced that it is on the right track. Honourable members opposite can manipulate interest rates all they like but they are not going to get away from the fundamental situation that, as the Treasurer (Mr Keating) or somebody else admitted in speaking to the Budget, the bottom line is going to be a tightening of monetary policy in the course of the next couple of weeks following the Victorian election.

The thing that disturbs me as a professional economist is not so much just the dishonesty, but the impact that this will have on the average Australian. We have already seen a one per cent increase in housing interest rates since the mini-Budget, despite a lot of statements to the contrary. We are about to see further increases in housing interest rates with further significant effects on the average Australian. For a $50,000 mortgage another one per cent increase in interest rates will cost the average person in Australia another $40 per month. That is a substantial additional slug on the average Australian. This policy of cynical manipulation of interest rates prior to an election has not changed the fundamental trend over the life of this Government, which is that home loan repayments as a percentage of family income have gone up from 19 per cent to 27 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DAWKINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education and Training and Acting Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, there is an air of total unreality about the contribution of the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), who has just resumed his seat. In one respect, he does take the disgraceful conduct of the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), one step further. Not only did he engage in the same cowardly attack on the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his absence, referring to such personal matters as travelling allowance but, more than that, he decided to attack the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia as well, referring to `the Governor of the Reserve Bank and his henchman'. What he is really saying is that there is some complicity on the part of the Governor of the Reserve Bank. He fails to explain how, in a deregulated system in which exchange rates find their own level and interest rates find their own level-I might say a system much beloved of the honourable member for Wentworth-one can manipulate interest rates.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, this was really a nostalgic trip down the time warp. He spoke of certain meetings which he said had happened, but he failed to provide evidence of them. One would have thought that if he had evidence of these meetings he would have provided it. These are just manufactured meetings which he thinks happened and alleges happened. Why did he not tell us about what actually happened when he was one of the meretricious players flitting across the political stage, as he was described by his predecessor as shadow Minister for Finance. I might say that `meretricious player' is not a description we used; indeed, the description is one which I do not intend to embellish by reference to a dictionary. I would ask people who are interested in the meaning of the word `meretricious' to look it up. I can tell them it has nothing whatsoever to do with merit.

This meretricious player who has now been translated into, first of all, a politician who was elected to this House and now an Opposition spokesman has failed absolutely to explain to us how these mechanisms might work. Of course he could explain to us how they used to work when he was involved with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), Malcolm Fraser and various others manipulating not just exchange rates but interest rates as well. They used to sit down either as a Cabinet committee or as a committee of officials, as we did for a very brief time in the beginning of our term, and they would decide what interest rates should be and what exchange rates should be. We recognised the ridiculous nature of that particular system and of course we changed it; we floated the exchange rate. An absolute undeniable consequence of floating the exchange rate is that however much people might want to manipulate interest rates they simply cannot. They are purely in the hands of the market.

What the honourable member for Wentworth is really saying by his reference to `the Governor of the Reserve Bank and his henchman' is that they are the ones who are manipulating exchange rates. I think that is a preposterous suggestion to make about one of the most distinguished public officials in this country, especially in a cowardly fashion behind the cloak of parliamentary privilege. There is not a scintilla of evidence that this gross allegation has anything whatsoever to support it. We would all be fascinated to know what actually happened during those cloak and dagger meetings within the Cabinet or within the meetings of senior officials as they set about trying to run the economy through exchange rate control and interest rate control. Talk about manipulation!

Let us hear from the honourable member for Wentworth and let us hear from the Leader of the Opposition precisely what did happen in the lead-up to the 1980 election. What we know is that exchange rates were kept artificially high as some failed anti-inflationary policy, with the result that our manufacturing industry was completely destroyed. That was the beginning of the end of the manufacturing industry in this country until such time as we came along and gave it a new start. Let us not have any snivelling from the honourable member for Went- worth, who is as guilty as anyone else when it comes to artificial and totally counterproductive manipulation of important factors such as interest rates and exchange rates. Those opposite are the ones responsible for the ham-fisted, cynical and totally political manipulation of the exchange rates in 1980 designed, as it was, to get them over the 1980 election. They are the ones saying that it was about anti-inflation. They are the ones who wrecked manufacturing industry and now the honourable member for Wentworth has the cheek to come in here and assert that we are doing something that we cannot do in any event. No-one can suggest that we can sustain a period of artificially arriving at an interest rate policy when in fact it is the market which determines it.

The honourable member gave the lie to his whole speech in the last couple of paragraphs when he said that the market is moving with its feet and the market is going to determine interest rates. Of course it is. That is our policy; that is what we set about trying to achieve with the honourable member's great congratulations, his great applause and his great encouragement. It was he who suggested that we should do that. He encouraged us and we did it. That is why it is the market which will determine what interest rates ought to be.

If the honourable member wants to support his nonsense he has to tell us precisely what the mechanism is. When we have floating exchange rates, how on earth can one manipulate exchange rates in defiance of market forces within the financial markets of Australia? He knows it is nonsense but he has been given a brief. He has said, `We are in deep trouble in Victoria. We need a bit of an issue. Let us see whether we can crank up interest rates'. Why is he interested in interest rates? We all know that at one point interest rates can be politically very sensitive, and that is at the level of mortgage interest rates. There are hundreds of thousands or millions of Australians buying their houses and they know that a big part of their household disposable income goes in paying off their mortgage. What does the honourable member for Wentworth really think about mortgage interest rates? Let me quote from the Business Review Weekly of a little over a year ago. He said:

And what about the so-called hallmark of the Government's conservative success, deregulation of the financial sector? An important sop to the business community? Yes-but not all the way. Clearly one of the most economically important interest rates, the housing interest rate on existing dwellings, remains regulated.

So what does he want? He wants the Government to deregulate the mortgage interest rate. Does he still believe that or has he been sat upon by various other people within the Liberal Party so that he can maintain the appearance of deregulation of interest rates? Has he changed his mind on that? Why would he change his mind? I will tell the House why he might have changed his mind-although, on the other hand, he may not have done so. He read out the figures in his own speech. He might have done so because 50 per cent of mortgages are currently under the regulated ceiling of 13.5 per cent, whereas the current market rate for mortgages is about 14.5 per cent. What he wants and what he was saying a year ago-and presumably is saying again now-is that the Government should take the lid off that, so that 50 per cent of mortgages would go up immediately by one per cent from the current regulated rate-a rate which he says is a nonsense-to the non-regulated rate of 14.5 per cent.

The honourable member gave the figures, and got them a little wrong. He said that on a mortgage of $50,000, if it were currently under the regulated rate and moved to the unregulated rate, the additional figure would be $40-I say $45-a month. Frankly, the honourable member for Wentworth cannot have it both ways. He cannot say that one should stop manipulating interest rates-without saying precisely how we should go about this in the current environment-and then hang on to his duplicitous policy of on the one hand wanting us to go the next step of deregulating existing loans and, on the other hand, saying what a terrible thing it would be if interest rates on mortgages went up by one per cent, which was precisely what he said, costing the person with a $50,000 loan an additional $40 or $45 a month. The honourable member for Wentworth should realise that he is not on one of his lecture circuits making cheap points, and probably packets of dough, in front of audiences. When he is making contributions to this House, there will be far greater scrutiny of the consistency of his remarks.

The honourable member went on to make some observations about the balance of payments. Probably the most irresponsible remark made in the wake of the balance of payments exercise was that of the Leader of the Opposition. He asserted without a blush that interest rates would go up in the wake of the balance of payments figure. Of course, the markets will determine that, but that betrays the fact that the Leader of the Opposition and the honourable member for Wentworth want interest rates to go up. They are doing all they can to talk up interest rates and to talk down the circumstances of the economy. This takes us back not very long ago to the famous interview given by the Leader of the Opposition in New York-or was it Washington?-when he said, `The times will suit me'. What did he mean by that? He meant that if only the economy were in a dreadful mess, there might be some slight chance that he would fall over the line and we would all wake up in the morning groggy with the thought of having him as Prime Minister. He thinks he can become Prime Minister by talking down the economy, and takes every opportunity to do so. Now we have his spokesman on finance following suit and trying to talk up interest rates. That is totally reprehensible and irresponsible in current circumstances.

Of course it is true to say, as the honourable member says, that the balance of payments figures for the first two months are higher than they were for the first two months of last year. But he knows very well-and was a little coy about making any predictions about the final position of the balance of payments or the current account-that one cannot take two months' figures, multiply them by six and say that that will be the outcome for the year. He admits that one cannot do that. What on earth is he trying to do by referring to these first two months? We know that if one looks at the first eight months of the year, one finds that the merchandise trade deficit and the services deficit are down. Therefore, there was no justification for making horrendous predictions about what will happen to the current account, and certainly no justification whatever for saying that this month's balance of payments figures provide a reason for the Government to change its policy stance. Certainly it does not provide justification for the Leader of the Opposition to start talking up interest rates in the hope that he might destabilise the economy and therefore help his own political ends.

If anyone is trying cynically to manipulate interest rates for his own political ends, let him not look at this side of the House. He should look at the other side of the House. Those opposite are trying to create an issue where there is none, and are trying to do so not only by besmirching the character of the Treasurer-which in the cut and thrust of politics is okay while he is here but it is a bit rough when he is not-but also by seeking to drag the Governor of the Reserve Bank and his so-called henchman into this as well, which is totally unacceptable in political terms.

The point of this exercise is that the honourable member for Wentworth has been unable to demonstrate how we would go about manipulating interest rates for any period at all in the current deregulated environment. He has not explained how he would do it. We do not have access to the devices which Opposition members cynically used when they sat down and plotted the course of interest rates and exchange rates. This Government has abandoned that. Therefore, the honourable member must explain how on earth one would go about this course. Of course, he cannot explain it. He knows that what he has said today is nonsense. There is no justification for his assertions or for those made by the Leader of the Opposition. The Government's policy stance is correct. With a Budget surplus of $5.5 billion, with inflation trending down, those are the circumstances, to the extent that the Government can influence them, which will usher in a period conducive to lower interest rates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a depressing exercise to sit here this afternoon and listen to the man who aspires to be Treasurer when the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) finally attains the position of Prime Minister. The Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) began in Question Time by making the most remarkable statements in answer to a question when he said that the Treasurer was overseas paying off a debt that the coalition Government had run up and that overall debt had actually been reduced. I remind the Acting Treasurer that Australia's overseas debt has quadrupled since the Government took over five years ago-in 1983.
—That's right.

—As my colleague says, that is correct. The debt was some $25 billion to $30 billion. Today it is some $120 billion. With the current account deficits blowing out in the way they are, there is only one prospect, despite a short plateauing of that figure, and that is that the figure will continue to soar. That is the sort of legacy the Government has left Australia. The Acting Treasurer does not even know about it, which is quite extraordinary.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate is about the mismanagement of the economy, manifested by such figures as high current account deficits and high interest rates. It also is about integrity and honesty in government. As the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), the shadow Minister for Finance, clearly demonstrated, the Government has been fudging the economic figures for electoral gain. I shall return to that point later. It is worth dwelling for a moment on the horrific figure that was released at 11.30 a.m. today relating to the current account deficit, which amounted in the previous month to $1.391 billion, which followed the figure for the month before of $1.667 billion. Therefore, in a period of two months we have virtually got a third of the total of what the Treasurer predicted for the whole year. It has made the prediction of $9.5 billion look ludicrous. The Australian public and even the Australian media are starting to wake up to the optimistic forecasts which the Treasurer has been making to cover up the Government's ineptitude in economic management. His forecasts have depended on stacking together a series of best case scenarios in this country for a whole lot of economic factors such as commodity prices, inflation rate predictions, optimistic predictions for growth, statements on overseas debts, glowing reports of what investment will be next year, and even overseas economic factors such as the size of the United States deficit and United States interest rates. I remind the Government that, if one of these figures fails, all the other figures will start to shift and the position that the Treasurer has predicted will look quite ludicrous.

The Australian economy is in a very fragile position. It is in that position because the economic management of this country has put it there. The Treasurer has been allowed to get away with it. He has got away with it with the help of a subservient media to some extent and with the help of a number of fortuitous factors in his favour that will not come again. We all remember that when he took over in 1983 the drought in Australia broke. The US economy came good, which halved inflation rates around the world. Even in the last year or two in this country we have had a commodity price boom and a strengthening of the exchange rate.

I will deal with those two factors briefly. The commodity price boom has come about because of fortuitous and very welcome factors. We have seen gold at near record levels, we have seen aluminium at near record levels, we have seen beef prices strengthen, and we have seen wool prices increase. In the last two years wool prices have gone up 240 per cent. While that has been very welcome, those commodity prices have peaked and some of them are on the way down. They will not continue to go up. So some of these glowing predictions will not come to pass at all.

Because of commodity prices going up, the exchange rate has strengthened about 10c against the US dollar in recent months. But even that has started to turn around recently. We have seen the Australian dollar shift from about US82c to about US78c. I would not be surprised if it did not continue to move down another 3c, 4c or 5c before the end of the year. When that happens we will see the overseas debt increasing again, and we will see the interest payments on that overseas debt increasing as a result.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will increase $1 billion a month.

—Exactly. The honourable member for Maranoa reminds me that the Westpac review dated September 1988, which has come on to my desk today, states clearly on page 2 that `despite the improved trade conditions, Australia has already lost ground'. There we have it in a nutshell. The trade conditions are already showing signs of some stagnation and are turning around.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer and the Government have demonstrated clearly that they cannot make the hard decisions that are necessary. The Treasurer does not have the stomach for it. He is incapable of it. I am talking about things like making expenditure cuts. The only expenditure cuts he has made have been in payments to the States. Indirect taxes have gone up by massive and record amounts, and that is the only reason he has been able to balance his domestic Budget. At the same time he has maintained, as the honourable member for Wentworth said, artificially low interest rates in the economic circumstances that the Government has plunged us into today. Instead of correcting the fundamentals, it has continued to maintain these rates by heavying Reserve Bank officials. It did that through the last Federal election held in July last year. It put it off for the expected New South Wales election late last year, which did not come until March this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —It didn't do them any good.

—No, because the Australian people saw through it. Now the Government has decided to delay it until after the Victorian election and the Oxley by-election. Australians are starting to see through this sort of charade. They saw through the referendum nonsense that went on when the Government was picked up in the High Court for illegal advertising. It was picked up in this Parliament for the ploy of ticks and crosses. It was picked up for fraudulent wording. Come Saturday, the Victorian people will again see through this sort of deception.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard stories about the Treasurer visiting the Reserve Bank and heavying its officials to keep interest rates down. I remind the Treasurer that there was a court case recently in New South Wales in which the State seat of Port Stephens, which is held by the Australian Labor Party, was judged to have been won because the candidate offered bribes to the electors in the last couple of weeks in the lead-up to the election in a desperate attempt to win votes. That may have just tipped him in with the trickle of votes that he won by. It is not unreasonable to compare that situation with what is going on in the lead-up to the Victorian election on Saturday. These are the sorts of tactics that the Government is resorting to in this country today. The Government has delayed the current account deficit figures. It has fudged the consumer price index figures by artificially lowering the beer excise, it has delayed tax cuts until before the next Federal election, and it is artificially depressing interest rates until the Victorian election is over. So lacking is this Government in ethics that I think we need a new code of behaviour, a new code of ethics, in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —And a new government in Victoria.

—As the honourable member says, we need a new government in Victoria, and federally. I say to the Federal Government: stop cheating before elections. It is trying to do to the Victorian election results what Ben Johnson did to the Olympic 100 metre result. The people of this country are starting to see through this tactic, and Victorians in particular will see through it.

SPEECH.PARA: Conservatives are on a roll right across Australia. We won the Adelaide by-election. We had a 10 per cent swing in Port Adelaide. We had a massive swing against the Government in Groom. We won New South Wales. We are about to win Victoria. And we will probably win Oxley. Because of the atrocious state of the Victorian economy, the people will judge the State Government for what it is on Saturday and vote it out as surely as they will vote the Federal Government out at the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have always had a special regard for the Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard). I have a degree of sympathy for him, as he really is saddled with the National Party. We have just heard a reason for not being saddled with the National Party. I do not know where the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) has come from, but we have just heard a speech riddled with voodoo economics. The honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) should aspire to greater things and not let the voodoo economics of the honourable member for Parkes trip him up. Unfortunately when the honourable member for Bennelong was Treasurer he was tripped up by those in the National Party. Do not let them do it again. They are doing it to him right now. He has a long way to go. I certainly take the view of some members of the Liberal Party: do not have a coalition with these people because they do not move the economic debate ahead. We all know that.
—You don't know what you're talking about.
—Order!
—The circumstances--
—It is a disgrace.
—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa will cease interjecting.
—These characters will totally bankrupt--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Maranoa.

—Those opposite continue to provide evidence for the point I am making. Voodoo economics is all that they are about. They have trouble facing the facts. Let me move on to the facts. We are dealing with the Opposition's approach to economics and our approach to economics. We know what this is about today. It is a pump up for Jeff Kennett. This is Jeff Kennett's steroid dose for Saturday. On Saturday there will be a dope test, and Jeff Kennett and the Liberal Party will be found to be dopes. We know what this is all about. We have seen it coming for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard just now from the great regulators. When they were in government they were the greatest exchange rate regulators and the greatest interest rate regulators. They cannot come in here today and talk about an approach to economics which does not recognise their history. Australians will remember them for a number of things. They will remember them for regulating interest rates and they will remember them for regulating the exchange rate. They will not forget that. They will also remember a number of other things. They will remember the $9.6 billion deficit that we inherited. We have turned that around to a $5.5 billion surplus. They will remember the Opposition creating unemployment-in terms of a quarter of a million people during the last year it was in office. They will remember that many young people in Australia who at that stage were embarking on careers saw those careers destroyed by the fact that the Opposition made a mess of economics when it had its chance. That is why the people are looking at the Opposition more speculatively now than they would have in the past because the mystique has gone. The Opposition cannot get away with it now.

The people will also remember the Opposition for making a mess of wages policy. It got wages policy completely out of kilter. It would be very salutary for some members of the Opposition to read the Australian Financial Review of Monday where it talks about what happened when the wages policy got out of kilter and unemployment rose dramatically. We have had to address that. We have had an incomes policy which has attempted to address that-that is, we have engaged in a social wage trade-off to reduce wage pressure and thereby increase employment. The result is on the board. We should talk about facts because some people on the opposite side have tended to allude to facts that suit them, but when we talk about facts-for example, the one million jobs that have been created since 1983-they are substantial facts. People can look around and see a more prosperous Australian community and that is also a substantial fact. The Opposition cannot get away from that, because those facts are there.

In terms of the previous Government's manipulation of interest rates, I must say that it kept the ceiling on interest rates. But what it was not able to do was increase the number of housing starts. This is very significant. I recognise what the honourable member for Wentworth said about one of the products of interest rates being the impact on housing and I think it is fair to say that both sides of the House take that issue seriously and want to put Australians into housing. But when the previous Government addressed this in 1982 it got housing starts down to 106,000 a year-the lowest for 20 years. The end product of one of those policies of interest rate activity was the very low level of housing commencements. That is just not good enough. In the years we have been in office we have averaged 135,000 per year. That is tangible. When one talks to people in Australia one discusses a number of issues, but one certainly talks about jobs and housing. I have already mentioned our achievement on the jobs front and people can demonstrate that. The achievement on the housing front is also there because we are getting people into houses. Those are substantial matters.

These are not easy tasks, especially when we are bringing about cuts in Government expenditure so that we are reducing the impact of the Budget on the gross domestic product (GDP). We have had a substantial achievement there in terms of the impact of the Government sector on the GDP. That is there to be demonstrated; we have achieved that. The $5.5 billion surplus that was foreshadowed in the Budget that is still before the House is there and the Australian community understands that. The Opposition left us with a deficit of $9.6 billion; we have turned that around to a surplus of $5.5 billion.

There are still some tests that the Opposition has not met and one of those to which I have already referred is the wage test. The Opposition has not been able to come up with a wages policy and I suspect that will continue to haunt it in opposition. It cannot come up with a substantial recognition that wage pressure can provide problems in terms of the level of employment if in fact those industries are competing in a highly competitive market. The Opposition has not addressed that while it has been in opposition. I think it will have a lot of difficulty there.

I did not begin to speak about the National Party of Australia without having a purpose. The reason I mentioned it was that one of the factors that bedevilled the Liberal Party in government was its inability to arrive at a wage policy that the National Party would accept. That is on the record and it is still with the Liberal Party. On this side of the House we are still waiting for an Opposition wages policy to emerge but it has not done so. That will bedevil the conservative parties and keep them in opposition.

On the question of the exchange rate policy, which is significant, because the Opposition had a controlled exchange rate it had, in effect, an overvalued Australian dollar. This had many impacts upon the Australian economy but one that was clear was that we could not develop an efficient export manufacturing sector. As a further consequence, we could not engage in effective import substitution. Therefore, we had in the long term a structural problem in Australia. One or two people from the National Party, who were sounding off earlier and who have now left the chamber because they exhausted their intellect after 30 seconds, spoke about rural exports. It is true that rural exports are still substantial in terms of our economic performance, but it also must be true that if we are to operate in the world which includes countries such as the United States, the European Community, Japan, South Korea and so on, we must have a viable export manufacturing sector. That is developing, but it would not have developed had we continued to have a controlled exchange rate because in effect we would have had an overvalued Australian dollar. That would not have provided the competitive position in which an export manufacturing sector could develop.

That is the history and honourable members cannot escape that. That is the history of having one approach to economic policy that was quite wrong. It is not just a case of being wise with hindsight; it was quite wrong at the time and honourable members opposite know that. We could go right back in history to the times when the Liberal and National parties had substantial debates about setting the value of the Australian dollar. We can understand the tension that would have arisen because there were competing interests in those governments in those days. There is nothing wrong in that. But unfortunately the people in the National Party tended to carry the day in those debates. Thus, we had an Australian economy that was not prepared to face the competitive world market and not prepared to be adaptable in terms of training needs, wages policy and so on.

These are the matters that are before us and before the Australian people. The people understood these issues in 1983 and they made a judgment about them then. That judgment was that the coalition Government had failed the economic test. The people are still making those judgments. The Opposition does not have the policies. For example, there is no tax policy and no wages policy. It is interesting that I should have mentioned tax policy because John Elliott gave the Liberal Party until the end of August to produce a tax policy. It is not there; there is no tax policy. I can understand that because again the Opposition is facing difficulties in terms of the groups within its own ranks. It must come up with that policy because the Australian community will not believe it. Tax policies that are just dreamed up for election purposes are not substantial and the Opposition has not done its job.

Let me sum up by saying that we know what this is about. As I said at the beginning of my speech, this debate is a pumped up attempt for the Victorian elections on Saturday. But other judgments will be made by the Victorian electors between now and Saturday and those judgments will be about economic competence, performance and solidarity in government. In those terms the Cain Government will come out way ahead of the Opposition Leader, Mr Kennett. As I said at the outset, the Opposition cannot do a steroid fix to try to get Jeff Kennett over the line for Saturday. The fact is that his policies are not there any more than the Federal Opposition's policies are. There is an absence of policy and the Australian electorate will judge the Opposition accordingly.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is a significant step in the Government's objective to provide more diverse television and radio services. It amends the Broadcasting Act to introduce a special category of limited licences aimed at meeting the need for a variety of specialised services which require technical planning but do not warrant the stringent program conditions applied to current broadcasting services. These services will include such things as information services and special event coverage. Most significantly in this Bicentennial year, they will provide also an appropriate means of implementing the Government's policy of placing control of broadcasting to remote Aboriginal and Islander communities where it belongs, in the hands of the communities themselves. I refer, of course, to the BRACS scheme, the broadcasting for remote Aboriginal communities services scheme, announced jointly in September last year by my predecessor and by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand).

The Bill also makes a number of other less significant, but equally necessary, changes. These are desirable reforms to the Broadcasting Act and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act which cannot wait for the thorough reviews of all aspects of broadcasting policy now being conducted by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure and by the Department of Transport and Communications. The Bill also clarifies the legal status of a number of practices, such as relaying radio services to people `on hold' on the telephone. I will deal now with the proposals in more detail.
New Licensing Arrangements

The specialised services to be encompassed by limited licences do not have the public interest implications as current forms of broadcasting, either because of the minor nature of the service or, as in the case of BRACS services, because they are primarily the concern of the community served. Any possible public interest in these services can be safeguarded without invoking the complex rules applying to existing categories of services. Initially, limited licences will permit the licensing of services for local information, special event, remote Aboriginal community or national broadcaster channel-sharing purposes. Limited licences will be administered by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as they involve program origination. However, they will be subject to simplified administrative procedures and flexibility will be ensured by the capacity to create new types of limited licence by regulation.

The Minister currently initiates licensing of all broadcasting services by inviting applications. Prospective limited licensees will be able to apply for licences without invitation. The Minister will retain the power to reject or defer those applications on planning or technical grounds but, otherwise, they will be referred to the Tribunal for consideration. The licence will specify the purpose for which it is granted and licensees will be required to provide a service consistent with that purpose, not one which is `adequate and comprehensive' as for existing forms of service. Either the Minister, through specifying the purposes, or the Tribunal, in imposing licence conditions, may refine the purpose of the service.

A licence for information purposes will authorise one of two kinds of service. The first is an information service relevant to the interests of persons residing in, working in or visiting a particular area. Operators of tourist attractions and leisure resorts and some local councils see potential in broadcasting, for example, up to date information on events or places of interest in the local area. Other services could provide information about local road conditions.

The second kind of information service will provide text or graphic material. Some doubt has arisen as to whether these services are covered by the main broadcasting licence of the service provider. Licensing teletext services as limited licences will allow the legal status of those existing services to be clarified. Special event licences will relate to sporting events, festivals, exhibitions, expositions or other special events. For example, a licence may be granted to cover the environs of an exhibition for the duration of the particular event.

The BRACS scheme, which I referred to earlier, will bring broadcasting services to more than 60 remote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and provide opportunities for these communities to include their own programs. It will enable communities to control reception and will therefore help to protect traditional languages and culture. Under the scheme, Aboriginal and Islander communities will be able to receive Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), public and commercial services and rebroadcast them, either live or delayed, under agreements with the host broadcaster. It will be possible to insert other programs like those now being produced by Aboriginal media organisations such as CAAMA, the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association in Alice Springs, and the first Aboriginal-owned commercial television service, Imparja. The communities will be able to delete offensive material or switch off the entire system at certain times, such as during ceremonial occasions.

The Bill empowers the ABC and the Special Broadcasting Service (SBS) to make broadcasting facilities and staff available to limited licensees for broadcasting purposes. In the past, the national broadcasters have entered into informal channel sharing arrangements with public broadcasters and community based program makers. Examples include the ABC's high frequency inland service where about 45 per cent of week day programming is provided by Aboriginal groups through CAAMA and SBS Television's Windows series. The host broadcaster retains editorial and publishing responsibility for broadcasts and, therefore, potential legal liability for defamation and other breaches. `Special interest' limited licences will enable the programmers to accept responsibility for programs transmitted with ABC or SBS assistance.

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will have flexible licensing powers for limited services. It will retain its powers to refuse to licence a service of the kind applied for and to make program standards for limited licences. It will have to commence inquiries into granting the licence but will be able to terminate those inquiries where it is satisfied that no further investigation is necessary.

Only those limited services providing text information will be permitted to broadcast paid advertisements. However, special event and channel sharing services will be allowed to broadcast sponsorship announcements. The prohibition will be not prevent remote Aboriginal community licensees retransmitting advertisements included in the host service where no payment or other consideration is received by the licensee community. Limited licensees, like other licensees, will be required, as far as possible, to use the services of Australians in the production and presentation of their programs in accordance with section 114 of the Broadcasting Act.

In summary, the essence of limited licences is flexibility-flexibility for the Minister and the Tribunal to consider new, non-commercial forms of broadcasting service; flexibility demanded by technological developments; flexibility long overdue in the labyrinthine Broadcasting Act. The Bill also introduces temporary transmission and retransmission permit schemes to replace the existing test transmission permits and rebroadcasting and retransmission licences. Rebroadcasting and retransmission licences authorise the retransmission of commercial, public or national broadcasts. The new scheme will consolidate these two categories of licence and recognise that, since there is no element of program origination in a retransmitted service, the Tribunal's involvement is unnecessary.

The decisions involved are purely planning and technical and thus fall within the responsibilities of the Minister. Ministerial grant of such permits will eliminate the need for double handling between the Minister and the Tribunal. This will substantially speed up the process for small communities who seek to obtain or improve reception of broadcasting services. The scheme will also eliminate the need for broadcasters to have a separate licence to relay their service by cable within their own service area. The permits will also cover retransmission outside a licensee's service area to particular persons or classes of persons. No permit will be required to authorise the playing of radio to people held on telephone queues.

Test transmission permits are granted to existing licensees for testing new technical equipment, to new licensees prior to the formal grant of the licence and to aspirant broadcasters who wish to test public reaction to program formats. While these may involve some program origination, they involve primarily planning questions and the Tribunal's involvement is generally unnecessary. The new scheme will transfer responsibility to the Minister, with a provision for referral to the Tribunal in appropriate circumstances such as where particular programming issues arise. The maximum length of permits will be extended from the existing seven days to 14 days. Guidelines will be developed in consultation with interested groups to replace the existing Tribunal policy statement and practice note on test transmission permits. Fees for limited licences and for retransmission and temporary transmission permits will be introduced under Bills shortly to be introduced. The level of fees has not yet been finalised and will vary with the nature of the service to be provided.
Local Origination

A licensee must currently obtain approval from the Tribunal before it can broadcast different programs from different transmitters within a service area; a practice known as `local origination' and intended to provide more local programs. The Bill removes the requirement for prior Tribunal permission to locally originate but makes the practice subject to scrutiny by the Tribunal as part of the assessment of the adequacy and comprehensiveness of a service. This will be a relevant issue at licence renewal inquiries. However, failure to locally originate will not of itself disclose a failure to provide an adequate and comprehensive service.

The Bill provides a range of mechanisms for delivering services which will be particularly important for remote and regional audiences. Licensees will have more flexibility in providing local origination. Local communities will be able to receive, more quickly, authorisation to establish their own re-transmission facilities. Remote Aboriginal and Islander communities will have enormous flexibility in providing services appropriate to their cultural needs and the national broadcasters will be able to consider proposals by limited licensees to share their facilities. Together, these reforms open the door for significant improvements in the range of broadcasting services available to under-served areas.
ABC Amendments

The Bill will allow the ABC to borrow money from the Commonwealth or other sources with the Finance Minister's or Treasurer's approval respectively and to offer its assets as security. It will permit the Commonwealth to guarantee loans. The Bill also confers powers to enter into hedging contracts to reduce the risks of foreign exchange or interest rate fluctuations and to invest surplus funds in a manner approved by the Treasurer.

These powers are consistent with the greater independence and accountability of the Corporation in financial matters stemming from the Government's decision to introduce three-year funding. They will certainly be of use to the Corporation in financing a number of proposals for development of accommodation in Sydney and Melbourne, amongst others.

The Bill also greatly simplifies the legislative provisions covering the ABC's staffing matters in line with the Government's policy of streamlining those provisions from independent statutory bodies. The Corporation will continue its endeavours to achieve and maintain high standards as an employer in relation to terms and conditions of employment, occupational health, industrial safety, industrial democracy, non-discriminatory employment practices and other matters.

Subject to the co-ordination arrangements which apply to all Budget-funded agencies, the Corporation and staff organisations will have greater flexibility in negotiating conditions of employment. The Government expects the Corporation to develop and maintain all future employment arrangements in full consultation and negotiation with relevant unions. These arrangements will be incorporated into industrial agreements or awards which will bind the Corporation in the same way as awards bind the Commonwealth, under section 41a of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1901. However, this does not mean that the Commission will be arbitrating or interfering in matters which may be properly regarded as coming within managerial prerogative. The staffing provisions will commence on a date to be proclaimed to allow the Corporation and relevant unions time to finalise the new arrangements.
Similar powers are available to other Commonwealth authorities operating in a competitive environment. The Government believes they will assist in creating a more flexible and efficient ABC.
Tobacco Advertising

The Bill extends the current ban on broadcasting advertisements for cigarettes and cigarette tobacco to cover other tobacco products such as cigars, snuff and chewing tobacco. It will bring the advertising requirements in the Broadcasting Act into line with those set out in the guidelines for video and audio entertainment and information services currently licensed under the Radiocommunications Act.
Administrative Matters

The Bill will eliminate areas of administration duplication in a range of routine planning and technical matters and will allow the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to carry out activities incidental to its functions. In particular, the Bill will allow it to provide and market publications and information services and hold conferences.

The Bill also provides that the Tribunal may require corporations `related' within the meaning of the Companies Code to a licensee corporation to furnish information about the activities or affairs of the related corporation which is relevant to the operation of the licence fees acts. A corporation is `related' to another if they are subsidiaries, holding companies or joint subsidiaries of a third corporation.

The Bill rectifies a defect in legislation which extends the electoral blackout provisions in the Broadcasting Act to elections for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly and such other bodies prescribed by regulation.
Finally, the Bill contains some reorganisation of provisions in the Act covering licensing criteria. These changes have no policy effect and are intended only to make the Act more readable.
Financial Impact

There is expected to be some increase in the administrative workload of the Department and the Tribunal resulting from the planning and licensing of new limited services. In the Department, this will be added to by the assumption of responsibility for temporary transmission and re-transmission permits, partially offset by savings from simplified planning and technical procedures. Any additional workload will be absorbed within existing resources. The loss of responsibility for test transmission permits and re-broadcasting and re-transmission licences will provide the Tribunal with small but useful administrative savings. These also can be expected in the ABC with simplified staffing provisions and more efficient cash management. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill imposes fees in respect of limited licences granted under the Broadcasting Act 1942. These fees will be by way of a tax with the amounts to be fixed by regulation. This new category of licence is being introduced into the Broadcasting Act by amendments in the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 which has just received its second reading.

Limited licences provide a flexible method of licensing a range of new broadcasting services which do not raise public interest implications of the same magnitude as conventional forms of broadcasting. Consistent with this approach, the Limited Licence Fees Bill provides considerable flexibility in the types of fees which may be set for different forms of limited licences.

The regulations will be able to prescribe fees payable annually or on the grant and renewal of licences. The fees may be set to recover the administrative costs of planning and licensing limited services or to impose charges which ensure that the revenue derived by the Commonwealth properly reflects the value in alternative uses of the frequencies allocated.

The regulations will be able to prescribe that fees for the grant of limited licences be set by tender, bidding or auction. In this situation, the choice by the Tribunal of the most suitable applicant for the particular limited licence will be made by selecting the highest suitable bidder. While none of the forms of limited licence expressly mentioned in the Broadcasting Legislation Amendment Bill is expected to be allocated in this way, the provisions give flexibility to apply it to future forms of limited licence if the public interest would thus be best served. The power to set fees is not mandatory and some forms of limited licence might not be required to pay fees at all.

Regulations will be made to commence on the date of commencement of this Bill. They will be set at levels consistent with those applying for similar users of the spectrum licensed under the Radiocommunications Act 1983.
Financial Impact

It is not expected that significant revenue will be generated by the Bill. The precise amounts will depend on the demand for limited licences, which cannot be estimated with any precision. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the Bill to the House.
