PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Postal Services Amendment Bill is part of the first stage of legislative amendments to implement the Government's reform package for Australia Post as announced by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, on 25 May this year. The reforms to Government business enterprises are central to the Government's micro-economic reform agenda for restructure of the public sector. In the present difficult and fiercely competitive international trading environment public sector efficiency is especially important. Many public business enterprises-particularly those in the Transport and Communications portfolio-produce not only final goods and services for the consumer, but also provide intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, and thus influence the nation's overall cost structures.

In 1975, the Whitlam Labor Government took the bold step of creating from the Postmaster-General's Department the two major public enterprises, Telecom Australia and Australia Post. Time has shown the correctness of this decision. For example, in the 11 years before 1975, the postal operations of the Postmaster-General's Department consistently showed a loss. Since 1975, Australia Post has made a profit in every year but one. However, the increasing importance of postal services to our economy necessitates further building on the achievements to date. Consequently, the Government is continuing the process of commercialisation by adopting a reform package which will put Australia Post on a sounder commercial footing. Key elements in these reforms are that the Australian Postal Commission will become the Australian Postal Corporation, with a board of directors and with a new financial structure and accountability mechanisms. A myriad of unnecessary government controls over day-to-day management decision-making will be removed.

In future, the Government will be less involved in scrutinising the day-to-day activities of Australia Post. Instead, it will focus on planning, through corporate plans and financial targets and accountability for results with strategic aspects monitored on an ongoing basis. The emphasis in future will be on the bottom line, on how successfully the goals and targets are met. The Government aims, through this approach, to establish a clearer distinction between the ownership of the enterprise, the board and management.

The reform process requires extensive legislative and administrative changes. Legislation will be implemented in two stages. This amendment Bill represents the first stage. It provides for the change of name to `Corporation' and the establishment of the board, new employment provisions, and removal of day-to-day controls. A second Bill, proposed for passage in the autumn sittings 1989, and to operate from 1 July 1989, will remake the Postal Services Act 1975 as the Australian Postal Corporation Act 1989, redefine the objectives, functions and powers of the Corporation, and provide for the corporate planning and financial accountability measures.

The Bill before the House provides for the constitution of the board, including a chairperson, deputy chairperson and managing director and up to six other directors. Board members are to be appointed by the Governor-General and will be subject to dismissal for ongoing underperformance, in addition to current grounds such as misbehaviour, mental illness, et cetera, in line with the emphasis on accountability for results. The managing director will be appointed by the portfolio Minister after receiving a recommendation from the board. Terms and conditions of employment for the managing director will be a matter for the board. The board will consult with the Remuneration Tribunal about the remuneration package for the managing director in line with the amendment of the Remuneration Tribunals Act introduced in the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill-part V. The board's most important function will be to formulate policy directions for the Corporation, in accordance with the Act and any directions from the Minister. The managing director will have the responsibility, under the board, for managing the affairs of the Corporation.

The change from Commission to Corporation does not change the status of Australia Post as a statutory corporation and rights under contract are not affected. The Australia Post board will be a new and separate corporate entity and the Bill takes account of the need for continuation of such matters as delegations. All the provisions dealing with the change of name and the board will come into operation from a date to be proclaimed, likely to be 1 January 1989.

Employment provisions in the current Act will be replaced by simpler provisions which make the board responsible for determining terms and conditions of employment. Australia Post is currently consulting staff associations on how existing terms and conditions will be dealt with in awards or by the board. As this process could take some time, the new employment provisions will be subject to a special proclamation date. The Government will not proclaim these changes until it is satisfied that the interests of Australia Post employees are protected and existing terms and conditions are preserved on changeover. The Government expects Australia Post to make satisfactory arrangements, including issuing of board determinations as necessary, to ensure that no current staff member loses any entitlement, classification or other term and condition of employment on transfer to the Corporation. Also, the Government has taken the additional step of including within the Bill provisions for continuity of employment for all current staff.

The Bill allows for day-to-day Government controls to be minimised in line with the enhanced responsibilities of the board. There will be appropriate mechanisms to allow the Minister to exercise strategic oversight, through the corporate plan and financial targets. These are currently being developed and will be provided for in the second stage legislation, once necessary asset revaluations are completed to provide for the new financial structure on which targets will be based. Australia Post will be free to engage, on its own authority, in such standard business practices as entering into contracts, partnerships, joint ventures, and normal business investment arrangements. In some cases, such as establishing subsidiary companies, the board will be required to notify the Minister in writing before business activities are expanded. Subject to overall Loan Council scrutiny, Australia Post will not be required to obtain ministerial approval to the terms and conditions of individual borrowings.

The Bill also includes amendments to allow Australia Post to develop its properties commercially. In many cities throughout Australia the post office is located in the heart of town. These sites are prime real estate but the existing constraints on Australia Post's powers have inhibited their commercial development. In line with Australia Post's assuming responsibility for the telegram service, the Bill recognises that Australia Post's electronic mail services are equivalent to the traditional telegrams that they will replace. Lettergrams, like telegrams, will be able to be ordered by telephone or across a post office counter and Australia Post will undertake their delivery. Transition to these new arrangements is expected to be completed by March next year.

Finally, the Bill does not involve any additional expenditure by the Commonwealth or, of itself, additional revenue for the Commonwealth. However, improvements in the performance of Australia Post that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit the shareholders and all users of Australia Post's services. I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to authorise the Treasurer (Mr Keating), on behalf of the Commonwealth, to guarantee borrowings raised by Qantas Airways Ltd to finance the purchase of three Boeing 767-300 extended range aircraft. The aircraft will be delivered in October, November and December of this year. These aircraft, which are the latest development of the 767 series, will provide Qantas with greater flexibility in meeting the requirements of the rapidly growing inbound tourist market. Unlike Qantas's existing 200 series, these aircraft provide for first class passengers and carry 231 passengers compared with 208. The aircraft will be utilised primarily on the Tasman and Japanese routes, two of Qantas's and Australia's important markets.

Qantas has brought forward delivery of these aircraft to meet the end of year peak demand for travel. The company plans to operate 154 extra round trips this summer to accommodate the anticipated higher demand. These extra flights will be in addition to a substantial increase in regular scheduled capacity. New schedules to take effect in November reflect an increase each week of about 6,700 seats, equivalent to 17 jumbo jets, compared with last summer's schedules. In addition to the early acquisition of the 767s, the airline has arranged to lease two 747 aircraft, which will be in the Qantas livery, to help operate the supplementary flight program.

The provision of a guarantee for Qantas's payment of, and payment of interest on, amounts borrowed for these new aircraft and related spare parts and equipment will be limited by the Bill to $US235m or its equivalent in other currencies. This represents 85 per cent of the total project cost for the three aircraft. The provision of the guarantee does not involve the Government in any cash outlay, but does create a contingent liability for the Commonwealth.

The terms and conditions on which the moneys are borrowed will be subject to the Treasurer's approval. The Bill also provides for proper security to be given to the Commonwealth over such property as the Treasurer deems satisfactory, and Qantas is to undertake to maintain adequate insurance of the items under the loan guarantee, and to protect the Commonwealth against the sale or mortgage of the property offered as security. The Bill also allows the Treasurer to require the fulfilment of any other conditions he thinks necessary before he gives a guarantee.

The previous Minister for Transport and Communications announced on 25 May 1988 a new reform package which included the primary aim of giving Qantas directors greater commercial autonomy to direct the affairs of the company. The appropriateness of further guarantees for Qantas aircraft is to be reviewed in the process of implementing that package. I commend this Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Willis, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Telecommunications Amendment Bill is part of the first stage of legislative amendments to implement the Government's reform package for Telecom as announced by Senator Gareth Evans, the then Minister for Transport and Communications, on 25 May this year. The reforms to Government business enterprises are central to the Government's micro economic reform agenda for restructure of the public sector. In the present difficult and fiercely competitive international trading environment public sector efficiency is especially important. Many public business enterprises-particularly those in the Transport and Communications portfolio-produce not only final goods and services for the consumer, but also provide intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy, and thus influence the nation's overall cost structures.

In 1975, the Whitlam Labor Government took the bold step of creating from the Post-master-General's Department the two major public enterprises, Telecom and Australia Post. Time has proven the correctness of that decision. Australia has a technically advanced and highly reliable telephone service. The telephone network has continued to expand and now well over 90 per cent of Australian households have a telephone service. However, the increasing importance of telecommunications to our economy necessitates further building on the achievements to date. Consequently, the Government has decided to continue the process of commercialisation by adopting a reform package which will put Telecom on a sounder commercial footing. Key elements in these reforms are that the Australian Telecommunications Commission will become the Australian Telecommunications Corporation, with a board of directors, and with a new financial structure and new accountability mechanisms. A myriad of unnecessary government controls over day to day management decision making will be removed.

In future the Government will be less involved in scrutinising the day to day activities of Telecom. Instead, it will focus on planning, through corporate plans and financial targets, and accountability for results with strategic aspects monitored on an on going basis. The emphasis in future will be on the bottom line, on how successfully the goals and targets are met. The Government aims, through this approach, to establish a clearer distinction between the ownership of the enterprise, the board and management.

The reform process requires extensive legislative and administrative changes. Legislation will be implemented in two stages. This amendment Bill represents the first stage. It provides for the change of name to Corporation and the establishment of the board, new employment provisions and removal of day-to-day controls. A second Bill, proposed for passage in the autumn sittings 1989 and to operate from 1 July 1989, will remake the Telecommunications Act 1975 as the Australian Telecommunications Corporation Act 1989, redefine the objectives, functions and powers of the Corporation, and provide for the corporate planning and financial accountability measures. The second Bill will be a companion to a further Bill to provide for new regulatory arrangements for the telecommunications industry in Australia as announced in the ministerial statement of Senator Evans on 25 May, `Australian telecommunications services: a new framework'.

The Bill before the House provides for the constitution of the board, including a chairperson, deputy chairperson and managing director and up to six other directors. Board members are to be appointed by the Governor-General and will be subject to dismissal for ongoing under-performance, in addition to current grounds such as misbehaviour, mental illness, et cetera, in line with the emphasis on accountability for results. The managing director will be appointed by the portfolio Minister after receiving a recommendation from the board. Terms and conditions of employment for the managing director will be a matter for the board. The board will consult with the Remuneration Tribunal about the remuneration package for the managing director in line with the amendment of the Remuneration Tribunals Act introduced in the Government Business Enterprises (Miscellaneous Reforms) Bill, part V. The board's most important function will be to formulate policy directions for the Corporation, in accordance with the Act and any directions from the Minister. The managing director will have the responsibility, under the board, for managing the affairs of the Corporation.

The change from Commission to Corporation does not change the status of Telecom as a statutory corporation and rights under contract are not affected. The Telecom board will be a new and separate corporate entity and the Bill takes account of the need for continuation of such matters as delegations. All the provisions dealing with the change of name and the board will come into operation from a date to be proclaimed, likely to be 1 January 1989.

Employment provisions in the current Act will be replaced by simpler provisions which will make the board responsible for determining terms and conditions of employment. Telecom is currently consulting staff associations on how existing terms and conditions will be dealt with in awards or by the board. As this process could take some time, the new employment provisions will be subject to a special proclamation date. The Government will not proclaim these changes until it is satisfied that the interests of Telecom employees are protected and existing terms and conditions are preserved on change over. The Government expects Telecom to make satisfactory arrangements, including issuing board determinations as necessary, to ensure that no current staff member loses any entitlement, classification, or other term and condition of employment on transfer to the Corporation. Also, the Government has taken the additional step of including within the Bill provisions for continuity of employment for all current staff.

The Bill allows for day-to-day government controls to be minimised in line with the enhanced responsibilities of the board. There will be appropriate mechanisms to allow the Minister to exercise strategic oversight, through the corporate plan and financial targets. These are currently being developed and will be provided for in the second stage legislation, once necessary asset revaluations are completed to provide for the new financial structure on which targets will be based. Telecom will be free to engage, on its own authority, in such standard business practices as entering into contracts, partnerships, joint ventures, and normal business investment arrangements. In some cases, such as establishing subsidiary companies, the board will be required to notify the Minister in writing before business activities are expanded. Subject to overall Loan Council scrutiny, Telecom will not be required to obtain ministerial approval to the terms and conditions of individual borrowings.

As part of the regulatory measures announced in the Government's statement `Australian Telecommunications: A New Regulatory Framework' the private sector will be permitted to carry out maintenance work on PABX from 1 January 1989, in addition to the installation of PABXs currently allowed. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act currently exempts Telecom employees who would otherwise be guilty of interception because of conversations overheard in the course of their work. The Bill extends this exemption to private sector employees lawfully engaged in installation and maintenance of PABX equipment. The provision making it an offence to divulge any information obtained already applies generally to all persons exempted.

Finally, the Bill does not involve any additional expenditure by the Commonwealth or, of itself, additional revenue for the Commonwealth. However, improvements in the performance of Telecom that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit the shareholders and all users of Telecom's services.
I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

The Satellite Communications Amendment Bill is part of the Government's reform package for Aussat as announced by the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans, on 25 May this year. The reforms of Government business enterprises are very important for the Government's overall micro-economic agenda. Public sector efficiency is especially important in the current economic and international trading situation because many public business enterprises produce intermediate inputs for the rest of the economy and have an influence on Australia's overall cost structures

Aussat was established in 1981 for the purpose of establishing, owning and operating a national satellite system. Commercial operations commenced in 1985 with the launch of Aussat 1 on 27 August 1985. From its beginning Aussat was established on a sound commercial basis. It is incorporated under the Companies Act and has a board of directors, a commercial financial structure and relatively few unnecessary government controls over its day-to-day managerial decision-making. Since July 1984, the Commonwealth has held 75 per cent, and Telecom Australia 25 per cent, of the company's shares.

Since Aussat is a company, most of the steps needed to implement the 25 May reform package can be achieved by amendment to the company's memorandum and articles of association. Consequently this Bill contains only a relatively small number of amendments. One amendment modifies the definition of neighbouring regions to allow Aussat more scope for selling its services.

Telecom owns 25 per cent of shares in Aussat and is entitled to nominate up to 25 per cent of the directors. The Bill makes two minor technical amendments to the provisions relating to the Aussat board. The first ensures that a government director appointed to both the Telecom and the Aussat boards does not affect Telecom's entitlement to nominate Aussat directors. The second provides that any Telecom employee appointed to the Aussat board falls within the 25 per cent limit. Provisions have also been included to exempt Aussat from the Public Works Committee and Lands Acquisition Acts.

In future the Government is to be less involved in scrutinising the day to day activities of Aussat. Instead, the Government will focus on planning, through corporate plans and financial targets, and accountability for results with strategic aspects monitored on an ongoing basis. The emphasis will be on the bottom line, on how successfully the goals and targets are met. By this approach, the Government aims to establish a clearer distinction between the ownership of the enterprise, the board and management.

Finally, the Bill does not involve any additional expenditure by the Commonwealth or, of itself, additional revenue for the Commonwealth. However, improvements in the performance of Aussat that result from the implementation of the reform package, of which this Bill is a part, will benefit the shareholders and all users of Aussat's services.
I commend this Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The proposed amendments will make possible a more flexible approach to Commonwealth overseas debt raising and management activities in the interests of more cost effective management of the Commonwealth's external debt portfolio. In particular, the Bill enables the Commonwealth to use a wide range of modern borrowing instruments and would assist in the management of foreign currency exposure with currency and interest rate swaps and other hedging techniques. This is essential if the Commonwealth is to minimise the cost of its external debt portfolio.

The proposed amendments to the Act do not provide the Government with additional powers to borrow money overseas. However, under present arrangements, the Government can only issue securities, such as medium term notes or short term commercial paper, with the Governor-General's approval for each issue. This is because under the present legislation each issue or short term roll-over is considered to be a new borrowing.

In practice, it is very cumbersome to submit each issue of notes under a medium term note program, or frequent roll-overs of short term debt, for approval. Under the proposed amendments to sections 3 and 5a, the Governor-General could approve a program of borrowings up to a certain limit. This would be consistent with the arrangements applying to the Commonwealth's domestic borrowings and powers held by other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development sovereign borrowers.

The new subsection 5b(1) is designed to provide the Treasurer with specific power to enter swaps or other financial agreements for debt management purposes. Swaps, which are essentially agreements between two parties to exchange financial obligations, are used extensively by a large range of international borrowers as a hedging technique. Section 5b(1) would also enable the use of other debt management techniques, such as interest rate caps which are designed to limit exposure to floating interest rates. While the Government already has the authority to enter swap arrangements under the Constitution-and has undertaken a number of swap transactions during 1987-88-subsection 5b(1) would provide specific authority to this effect.

The proposed legislative amendments to subsection 5b(2) provide for standing appropriation for swaps. Swap contracts are presently being met from annual appropriations but, given their unpredictable nature, it would be more appropriate if they were funded by way of standing appropriation. Such an amendment would bring more certainty to the future commitment of funds to honour swap contracts and would put swap funding on the same basis as overseas borrowings which are covered by standing appropriation. It is in line with the Government's view that unpredictable outlays be authorised by standing appropriations.

In seeking Executive Council authority for the Government to undertake overseas loans and swap arrangements, it has been customary for the Governor-General, in the documentation for each loan, to give the Treasurer the power to submit the Commonwealth to foreign legal jurisdiction and to waive legal immunity for the Commonwealth in respect of itself or its property-except for property used or intended to be used for diplomatic, consular or military purposes. Accordingly, the new section 5c encompasses the existing arrangements formally into the legislation.

Finally, the proposed legislation-section 5d-expands existing arrangements for the Treasurer to delegate his powers regarding borrowings, swaps and other financial agreements or arrangements to a specified departmental officer or, in overseas countries, to a specified member of the Australian diplomatic mission. This would allow Treasury officials to set prices in line with market conditions subject to least favourable terms set by the Treasurer. Under a medium term note issue, securities are offered to investors continuously at market related rates and it would not be practical for the Treasurer to determine individual bond prices on a continuous basis-possibly several times a week.
Financial Impact Statement

The proposed amendments provide the Government with the flexibility to undertake a wide range of overseas borrowings and make more timely use of favourable interest rate or exchange rate movements to manage its debt portfolio more efficiently and reduce the overall cost of the portfolio.

During 1987-88 the expenditure on net swap payments was $11m and the Government has appropriated $30m for these purposes in 1988-89. The transactions undertaken in 1987-88 were essentially aimed at changing the composition of the Commonwealth's external debt liabilities to better hedge the debt portfolio against possible exchange rate risk. The proposed amendments will ensure that swap commitments are provided for under standing appropriation.
I commend this Bill to the House and present the associated explanatory memorandum.

Subclause 215 (3), which is based on subsection 30h(3) of the Companies Act 1981, provides that a person shall not, at a hearing before the Companies Auditors and Liquidation Disciplinary Board, give evidence that is false or misleading. The amendment provides a defence if the defendant can show that when giving the evidence he or she believed on reasonable grounds that it was true and not misleading.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I understand the wording correctly, the amendment involves a reverse onus of proof. The person who supposedly contravenes sub-section (3) will not be guilty of an offence against subsection (4) if it is proved that he or she, when giving evidence, believed on reasonable grounds that it was true and not misleading. The Attorney-General can correct me, and I hope he does, but that seems to be a reverse onus of proof. Whilst the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee obviously had other grounds for worrying about the previous provisions, I have concerns about that. It is not something that we should lend ourselves to lightly. Would the Attorney-General like to comment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would share the concern of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) if it were a reverse onus of proof. It is not a reverse onus of proof. The honourable gentleman will notice that at present a person shall not give false or misleading evidence. That would certainly be an offence. Whilst it might be said that a person has given false or misleading evidence, under this provision the person has the right to say, `At the time that the evidence was given, I believed on reasonable grounds that it was true and was not misleading'. In other words, it gives a person a defence; it is not a reverse onus of proof.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, at present a defendant would not be able to raise the defence because it is absolute in its terms. That is what the Senate Committee says, and I guess it is right. It says that, once a person gives false or misleading evidence, that person is guilty. This provision gives a defendant a chance to explain that at the time the evidence was given he or she had an honest belief that what he or she said was not false or misleading. So it is not a reverse onus of proof. It is a guarantee that an accused has the right of defence.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to me that the clause is not clear on that. It uses the words `if it is proved that', et cetera. I accept the Attorney-General's assurance, but I am a little worried about the words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think what the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) is trying to say-and I understand it-is that an accused has to say something, but that is not a reverse onus of proof. It just means that there is a requirement for a defendant to give an explanation. If one gives the explanation, it will be entitled to be accepted as a defence against the fact that at the time the evidence was given it certainly was not true and was misleading. There is no argument about that. The fact is that a person cannot be convicted if he or she can say, `At the time I had reasonable grounds for believing that what I said was the truth'. In other words, the defendant gets a chance to correct the absolute liability that is there. Otherwise, it would have to be said that the evidence the accused gave was false and misleading. In other words, it was not true. This gives the opportunity for a person to say, `I will acknowledge that, but at the time I had reasonable grounds for believing that what I said was true'. The question of intent comes in to it. I think that is a very effective method, and I am sure the Senate has been anxious that something like this be done rather than leave the absolute liability there with no opportunity to give any defence of that nature.

SPEECH.PARA: (28) After clause 230, page 81, insert the following new Part:
``PART 12a-JURISDICTION OF COURTS UNDER NATIONAL SCHEME LAWS
Jurisdiction of Federal Court of Australia
``230a. (1) Subject to subsection (2), jurisdiction is conferred on the Federal Court of Australia in any matter arising under a national scheme law.
``(2) A prosecution for an offence against a national scheme law shall not be instituted in the Federal Court of Australia.
Jurisdiction of State and Territory Supreme Courts

``230b. (1) Subject to section 9 of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, the Supreme Court of each State (other than the Northern Territory) is invested with federal jurisdiction in any matter arising under a national scheme law.
``(2) To the extent the Constitution permits, jurisdiction is conferred on the Supreme Court of each Territory, and of the Northern Territory, in any matter arising under a national scheme law.
``(3) The jurisdiction with which subsection (1) invests the Supreme Court of a State, or that subsection (2) confers on the Supreme Court of a Territory or of the Northern Territory:
(a) is not limited by any limits to which any other jurisdiction of that Supreme Court may be subject;

(b) is exclusive of the jurisdiction of any other court of that State or Territory, other than a court to which section 41 of the Family Law Act 1975 applies by virtue of a Proclamation made under subsection 41 (2) of that Act; and
(c) shall be exercised by a single judge of that Supreme Court.
Transfer of proceedings

``230c. (1) A civil proceeding, under a national scheme law, in a court having jurisdiction under section 230a or 230b, or an application in such a proceeding, may, on the application of a party made at any stage or of the court's own motion, be transferred by the court to another court having jurisdiction in the matters for determination in the proceeding or application.
``(2) Where, under subsection (1), a court transfers a proceeding, or an application in a proceeding, to another court:

(a) the Registrar or other proper officer of the first-mentioned court shall transmit to the Registrar or other proper officer of the other court all documents filed of record in the first-mentioned court in respect of the proceeding or application, as the case may be; and
(b) the other court shall proceed as if:
(i) the proceeding had been originally instituted in the other court;
(ii) the same proceedings had been taken in the other court as were taken in the first-mentioned court; and
(iii) in a case where an application is transferred-the application had been made in the other court.
Courts to act in aid of each other

``230d. All courts having jurisdiction in matters arising under national scheme laws, the Judges of those courts and the officers of, or under the control of, those courts shall severally act in aid of, and be auxiliary to, each other in all such matters.
Appeals from State and Territory Supreme Courts
``230e. (1) An appeal lies to the Federal Court of Australia from a judgment or order or another court exercising jurisdiction that the other court has under section 230b.
``(2) An appeal lies to the High Court, with special leave of the High Court, from a judgment or order of a kind referred to in subsection (1).
``(3) Subject to subsections (1) and (2), no appeal lies from a judgment or order of a kind referred to in subsection (1).
Effect of Part on other laws
``230f. Nothing in this part affects the operation of section 68 of the Judiciary Act 1903, or of the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross-vesting) Act 1987.''.
(29) Before clause 231, page 81, insert the following new clause in Part 13:

``230g. (1) In this section:
`decision' has the same meaning as in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.
``(2) Applications may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for review of a decision by the Commission:
(a) to make an order under section 72, 73 or 74;

New part 12a relates to the jurisdiction of courts and administrative review under national scheme laws. The Bills, as drawn, provide for concurrent jurisdiction to be conferred in all matters arising under the Bills in the Federal Court of Australia and the State and Territory Supreme Courts. New part 12a is proposed to be inserted in the Australian Securities Commission Bill dealing with the jurisdiction of courts and appeals under national scheme laws. The main features are: concurrent jurisdiction in all civil matters arising under national scheme laws is conferred on the Federal Court and the State and Territory Supreme Courts; prosecutions for offences against national scheme laws are to be brought in the relevant State or Territory Supreme Court; in exercising their jurisdiction under national scheme laws, the State and Territory Supreme Courts are to be constituted by a single judge; and an appeal from a judgment of a single Supreme Court or Federal Court judge will lie as of right to the full Federal Court, or directly to the High Court if that court gives special leave.

In addition, in order to reduce the likelihood of forum shopping between jurisdictions, a new clause 230c is proposed which will enable the transfer of proceedings from one court to another having jurisdiction. This will enable proceedings to be heard in the most appropriate court, having regard to the nature of the matter, the parties, the location of the witnesses, and so on. There is concurrent jurisdiction at present. Matters that would be the subject of prosecution are always dealt with in State courts. Matters of appeal, where we are dealing with the law, are always dealt with in the court that has that jurisdiction, which in this case would be the full Federal Court.

There are other matters. To prevent forum shopping, we have what is called cross-vesting arrangements, which have now been agreed to by the States, where a court itself can transfer from a State court to a Federal court or from a Federal court to a State court on the basis of where is the most substantial element-is it a Federal element or is it a State element? That is a matter of discretion for the judge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I mention my reservations about double jurisdiction in the sense that the Federal Court of Australia and the Supreme Courts in each of the States and the Northern Territory potentially may be involved or, more accurately, one of the Supreme Courts or the Federal Court of Australia may be involved. Although I suppose this has applied ever since the Federal Court of Australia was created, it is a worry to me that the choice of jurisdiction could be used vexatiously. I do not say that the courts would do so, or that if they did do so they would do so wittingly, but it might be that the prosecution was conducted and framed in such a way that a defendant had to appear in a court far removed from his or her State of residence.

SPEECH.PARA: That is just one of the problems that arise. There is an absence of certainty of the location of the jurisdiction and there is that reservation in the back of my mind that in certain circumstances, and undoubtedly somewhere down the track, the prosecution could be vexatious in its choice of location for hearing an action. Whilst I do not know whether the law could be framed any better, I simply wish to express that reservation and those concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to put to rest the fears of the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) because the Bill provides for the prosecution to be in the relevant State-that is, where the offence occurred. That is what that means and there can be no doubt about it. The honourable member should bear in mind that at present the corporate affairs commissions in each State are able to judge that situation rather well and in terms of natural justice it would be vexatious to suggest something should be transferred to another State. But that would not happen. Under the jurisdiction here, the action would be heard where the offence occurred. I assure the honourable member that there is no problem there.

—I just wish to point out that this has happened in cases where the Commissioner of Taxation has been involved. In cases where he has had a choice he has obliged defendants to travel elsewhere. In one case of which I am personally aware he obliged a defendant to travel to Queensland when it was extremely doubtful that that course of action was necessary. In my mind there are very serious questions as to the good intentions of the Commissioner of Taxation. I am not suggesting that that automatically flows to those who are charged with the responsibility for this Bill, but somewhere down the track that sort of thing might happen. However, I accept the Attorney-General's assurance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the Attorney-General the base question: If this package of Bills is to succeed will the matters become subject wholly to Federal law?
—No, not necessarily. We can vest the State courts. The State courts are very keen to play a part.

``230g. (1) In this section:

This amendment provides for review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of certain Australian Securities Commission (ASC) decisions. Under the cooperative scheme legislation, the courts have a general power to review administrative decisions on their merits-for example, there is a reference to section 537 of the Companies Act 1981. Due to constitutional restraints it is not possible for the Commonwealth Parliament to confer this power on the courts, except in the Territories.

Consistent with current administrative law policy, new clause 230g is proposed which will confer power on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to review on their merits decisions of the ASC where a person has failed to comply with a requirement during an ASC hearing or investigation. Similar provisions providing for AAT review are also to be inserted in the Corporations Bill and the Close Corporations Bill.

I also wish to point to the general handling of the Bill which clearly indicates that the amendments that were brought forward were not those of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), but rather those of the collective interest groups that have hijacked the whole process. SPEECH.PARA: It is really an appalling performance for the Government to expect the legislative processes of the Australian Parliament to be treated in such a way. I did not want to let this opportunity pass without pointing out the way in which Parliament has been so shabbily treated in relation to these amendments and those to which we will now proceed. I would hope that all of those who may read the proceedings of this debate understand that at 5.30 p.m. last night, just 24 hours ago, 280 amendments were dropped on my table, and they were to be discussed at 10 o'clock this morning. Is that the way we are to have corporate law in Australia run? If that is the way the corporations of Australia want things to be run, they are certainly out of touch. Corporations do not necessarily want quick changes in corporate law; they want certainty within the law, to know where they are going. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I have to put it on the record that I do not think the Australian Securities Commission Bill has been hijacked by a small, select group. A consultative group did deal with it. The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) made a significant omission in that he forgot to mention that the Bill was introduced in May and laid on the table to enable the business community to make submissions on what it thought. I am aware of the fact that the Opposition does not want to be involved in the introduction of federal law. I accept that, and perhaps this legislation will be defeated in the Senate. There is no argument about that. But it should not be put on the record that somebody else has some ulterior motive for moving the amendments other than to improve the legislation. SPEECH.PARA: (19) Clause 66, page 63, lines 20 to 43, and page 64, lines 1 to 11, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Excluded issues, offers and invitations
``66. (1) An issue or allotment of securities is an excluded issue if, and only if:
(a) the amount subscribed for the securities by each person to whom the securities are issued or allotted is at least $500,000;
(b) the securities are issued or allotted to persons whose ordinary business is to buy or sell securities, whether as principal or agent;
(c) the securities are issued or allotted to an underwriter under an underwriting agreement;
(d) no consideration is paid or provided in respect of the issue or allotment;
(e) both the following subparagraphs apply:
(i) the securities are issued or allotted to a person as a result of the acceptance of:
(a) an offer made personally to that person; or
(b) an offer made by that person pursuant to an invitation issued personally to that person;
(ii) either:
(a) no other securities of the same class are issued or allotted at the same time, or have been issued or allotted in the preceding 12 months, to any other person; or

(b) that person, and any other person or persons to whom securities of the same class are issued or allotted at the same time or have been issued or allotted in the preceding 12 months, do not together exceed 25 in number;
(f) the securities are issued or allotted to:
(i) an executive officer of the corporation by which the securities are issued or allotted or of a related body corporate;
(ii) a person (in this paragraph called a `close relative') who is the spouse, or is a parent, brother, sister or child, of such an executive officer; or

(iii) a body corporate in which such an executive officer or a close relative of such an executive officer has, or any 2 or more of such an executive officer and the close relatives of that executive officer together have, a controlling interest (including any interest that gives control);

(g) the securities are issued or allotted pursuant to the exercise of an option, being an exercise effected by the execution of a form of a kind that had been attached to, or to copies of, a prospectus issued in relation to the option;
(h) in the case of an issue or allotment of shares in a corporation:
(i) the shares (in this subparagraph called `new shares') are issued or allotted to the holders of other shares (in this subparagraph called `existing shares') in that corporation:
(a) in connection with a proposal referred to in section 507 that relates to shares in that corporation; or

(b) in satisfaction in whole or in part of dividends payable by that corporation to the holders of existing shares where those holders exercised the right to have the dividends so satisfied by the issue and allotment of new shares, or acquired that right, by the execution of a form of a kind that had been attached to, or to copies of, a prospectus issued in relation to the existing shares; or
(ii) the shares are issued or allotted under a provision contained in a convertible note, whether the note was issued by that corporation or by another body corporate;
(j) in the case of an issue of debentures of a corporation:
(i) it is made to existing holders of debentures of that corporation; or
(ii) that corporation is an excluded corporation;
(k) in the case of an issue of prescribed interests (in this paragraph called `new interests') to which an approved deed relates:
(i) it is made to existing holders of prescribed interests (in this paragraph called `existing interests') to which the same approved deed relates:

(a) in satisfaction in whole or in part of amounts payable to those holders in respect of their existing interests, whether the existing interests are of the same class as, or are of a different class form, the new interests; or
(b) in exchange for existing interests of a different class from the new interests; and

(ii) each person to whom a new interest is issued exercised the right to have that interest issued, or acquired that right, by the execution of a form of a kind that had been attached to, or to copies of, a prospectus issued in relation to the existing interests; or
(m) the issue or allotment of the securities is, or is of a kind that is, declared by the regulations to be an excluded issue.
``(2) An offer or invitation in relation to securities is an excluded offer or an excluded invitation, as the case may be, if, and only if:
(a) it is an offer for subscription of, or an invitation to subscribe, at least $500,000 by each person to whom the offer is made or the invitation is issued;
(b) it is made or issued to a person whose ordinary business is to buy or sell securities, whether as principal or agent;
(c) it is an offer or invitation to enter into an underwriting agreement or is made or issued to an underwriter under such an agreement;
(d) no consideration is paid or provided in respect of the contract resulting from acceptance of the offer or from acceptance of an offer made pursuant to the invitation;
(e) it is made or issued personally to a person and:
(i) no offer or invitation in relation to securities of the same class is made or issued at the same time, or has been made or issued in the preceding 12 months, to any other person; or

(ii) that person, and any other person or persons to whom offers or invitations in relation to securities of the same class are issued or made at the same time or have been issued or made in the preceding 12 months, do not together exceed 25 in number;
(f) it is made or issued to:
(i) an executive officer of the corporation to securities of which the offer or invitation relates or of a related body corporate;
(ii) a person (in this paragraph called a `close relative') who is the spouse, or is a parent, brother, sister or child, of such an executive officer; or

(iii) a body corporate in which such an executive officer or a close relative of such an executive officer has, or any 2 or more of such an executive officer and the close relatives of that executive officer together have, a controlling interest (including any interest that gives control);

(g) in the case of an offer or invitation in relation to shares in a corporation it is made or issued to the holders of other shares in that corporation in connection with a proposal referred to in section 507 that relates to shares in that corporation;
(h) in the case of an offer or invitation in relation to debentures of a corporation:
(i) it is made or issued to existing holders of debentures of that corporation; or
(ii) that corporation is an excluded corporation; or
(j) it is an offer or invitation that is, or is of a kind that is, declared by the regulations to be an excluded offer or excluded invitation, as the case may be.
``(3) In this section, `prospectus' means a prospectus that:
(a) was lodged under Division 2 of Part 7.12 or a corresponding law; and
(b) was registered under that Division or corresponding law, where such registration was required.''.

Amendment (19) deletes clause 66 and replaces it with a new provision which excludes from the operation of the prospectus provisions a wider range of offers and issues of securities. The following additional categories of offers and issues are excluded by the new clause: offers and issues involving no consideration, for example, bonus shares; and offers and issues made personally to no more than 25 persons in a 12-month period. Because the prospectus provisions are no longer limited by the concept of an offer to the public, a number of essentially private offers would otherwise have been caught. The limit of 25 has been fixed at a level which should not affect the formation of small companies, or other small offers or issues. Other additional categories include offers and issues made to an executive officer and various associates of the issuing corporation, because executive officers would have ready access to information concerning the offer; issues of new securities to existing holders pursuant to various rights granted by the issuer, for example, to acquire securities pursuant to an option or a dividend reinvestment facility; the conversion of convertible notes to shares; and the exchange of existing prescribed interest for new prescribed interest pursuant to what is known as a switching facility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the amendments to legislation, I remind the Committee, which was first debated this morning and which gave rise to certain remarks from the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) when he was speaking to the third reading of the Australian Securities Commission Bill dealt with by the Committee and subsequently by the House. I am reduced to simple arithmetic to illustrate my point: The amendment seeks to delete something like 36 lines from the Bill as it was first introduced and replace them with something like 125 lines. That places the Committee in an impossible situation. It emphasises the criticisms of the honourable member for Ryan to which I have referred. These amendments were available to the honourable member for Ryan, at best, only late last night and certainly were not available to me until mid-morning. If it was not for the dedicated interest of my colleague the honourable member for Ryan, there would be just no chance of anyone making a serious contribution to this debate and exercising the very great responsibility we have to at least make legislation with which we may not agree-and we do not agree with this legislation-workable, should it be successful.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to the honourable member for Ryan, the Attorney-General said, `Well, I guess it is all right, because we have the support of the business community'. I remind the Attorney-General that, firstly, however high sounding the names of some of those bodies to whom he has spoken, they are not necessarily representative of the vast majority of individual businesses and businessmen. Secondly, we are in no position to move amendments because, even if we had gone to the great time and trouble to draft them, they would have been rendered useless by the Government's own amendments. So we have nothing to apologise for in that regard. In the interim, anyway, the Government was toying with the idea-and the Attorney-General confirmed it this morning-that there would be a parliamentary committee of some sort, either from the Senate alone or preferably a joint committee of members of both the House of Representatives and the Senate. It is simply impossible, given that this amendment deletes 36 lines and inserts something like 125 lines in their stead, for anyone to digest the full implications of the legislation. I might add that, firstly, it is not simple legislation and, secondly, the amendments are far from straightforward to anyone but the best informed of corporate lawyers in this country and perhaps to some in the Attorney-General's own Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposed changes here are quite large. While my colleague the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) was speaking I noted that the amendment refers to the area of the prospectus and provisions relating to the use of the prospectus. The argument put forward with respect to the original proposition was that registration of a prospectus itself should be done away with. However, as a consequence of the exposure of the Bill, a number of propositions have come forward suggesting that we should not go through with that completely but that we should broadly define the prospectus as applying to a public company and a private company. I do not believe that the proposition put forward is the right answer. I can well remember as an underwriter and a broker that one relied very substantially on the prospectus in all regards. When a proposition is put forward, one must know the individuals behind the float. It is the drawing together of the prospectus that the underwriter relies on to sell those securities, be it a debenture or a share. An underwriter is reliant on the prospectus and, in my view, the underwriter's clients-institutions or private clients, but more particularly the latter-are reliant in no small way on that prospectus. The private client is reliant on the quality of the reporting in the prospectus and the quality of the accounting assessments and expert assessments, be they in mining, building or real estate. One of the 36 faceless men-I would name the honourable gentleman if it was needed-arrogantly told me that because we have such a small group of experts in Australia none of us would dare do the wrong thing. That is complete nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: I will relate a story to honourable members. In the boom of the 1960s a very well-known stockbroker arranged to meet me at the Wentworth Hotel. In the course of an hour we finalised three prospectuses for three company floats. Although the prospectuses gave an absolute minimum of information, the floats were all successful, very largely because of the stockbroker's name. In those days the requirements for prospectus vetting were negligible, as honourable members know. I have to say in retrospect that the people who bought those shares were buying a pig in a poke. There was nothing in the prospectuses to say what the companies were about, only that they were mining companies and had large prospect areas. There was no comment on what the quality of the prospects was or where they were. The propositions put forward in those three floats were complete dogs. They all got off well because the market was good. When the market subsided in 1969 all three disintegrated.

The arrogant advice given to honourable members opposite by one of the 36 faceless men was that because there is such a small group no-one is going to do it unless he is outside the group. The person who underwrote those three issues was one of the leading members of the Sydney Stock Exchange. I therefore do not hold the view that prospectuses should be let go because these things can be looked at in some form by an authority to ensure that there is some standard. When the market is good one could even float Kerin. When the market is bad it would not be possible to float even Hawke-although Keating might want to do that these days.

I urge the people concerned not to stop at this jig back in relation to prospectuses, because I do not believe that the investor is sufficiently looked after. Those who are looked after are the fast track boys who want to get these things out quick smart and down the track because it suits one or two large investors, particularly in the banking area. They can be accommodated. It is not beyond the wit of corporate lawyers and the Commission to get some form of check list of basic requirements in relation to prospectuses. There is, I am quite convinced, a form of prospectus for use in large fund raisings such as debentures. But I believe the Commission ought to have some role in relation to share issues for new corporations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) for his contribution. There is already a proposal to exclude from the normal issue of prospectuses certain invitations, and that is what this is about. The honourable member will notice reference to small people, professional people and those in respect of whom there is no need to go through the whole prospectus operation. This clause identifies those people as being one of a total number of not more than 25, executive officers, existing holders of securities and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable gentleman talked about what the business community thinks. If there is one thing the business community gets very concerned about, in the wider concept of prospectuses, it is bureaucrats vetting a prospectus, trying to work out the estimated profit and the value of the prospectus and taking an enormous amount of time when the market should be judging the prospectus. I will admit that perhaps in the 1960s there were people that, as the honourable member has said, became dogsbodies or whatever.

If investing in mining, one does take a risk, but one usually relies on some geologist's report. We are trying to put liability into a prospectus. It is all very well to say, `Well that's marvellous. We've had it vetted by some well meaning officer in the Corporate Affairs Commission and he has given it the okay'. There are still plenty of companies that do not do very well and that is the risk of the stock exchange. All we are saying is that if in the future the honourable member gets his fingers burnt because he relied on something in a prospectus that was not a fair statement he can have a go at the person responsible.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can do that now.

—Yes, but it can be claimed that the prospectus was dealt with by the Corporate Affairs Commission before it was issued. We saw the extraordinary situation which developed with Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd.
—But that does not stop you taking action.

—No, it does not, but it creates the problem that the business community-and I would have thought that the honourable member would have been supportive of it-is saying, `Why can't we take the risk ourselves? Why do we need the subjective judgment of somebody who is not in the business?' That is not the issue here, by the way. We are saying that professionals and semi-professionals should not be put under that burden. The honourable member is always too anxious to tell me that what is happening here is not in accordance with the dictates of the business community. One of the things that business people are very mindful of is the need to be able to get onto the share market with a good proposition, prepared to take the onus and accept their responsibility as reputable businessmen. I see nothing wrong with that.

(25) Clause 73, page 70, line 40, omit ``section 1179,'', substitute ``Division 4 of Part 8.3,''.

These amendments seek to clarify the position. They delete existing clause 73 (3) (c) and insert a new expression, which clarifies the circumstances in which a person will be taken to have done an act as a futures representative for another person. Some commentators have interpreted similar clauses to the present clause 73 (3) (c) as covering only conduct within a representative's actual or apparent authority, whereas it was intended also to encompass conduct which is outside the authority of the representative. Clause 73 (3) (c) has therefore been amended to make it clear that conduct outside the authority of the representative but done on account of or for the benefit of the broker or adviser is included.

Amendment (25) relates to clause 73 (4). That provision has also been amended by deleting the reference to section 1179 and substituting the reference to division 4 of part 8.3. The reference to section 1179 is no longer necessary as a result of the amendments made to clause 1179. The reference to division 4 of part 8.3, which deals with the liability of principals for representative conduct, has been inserted to make it absolutely clear that a person will not incur any liability under that provision merely because another person holds himself or herself out to be a representative of that person. It is now clear that a person will be liable under division 4 of part 8.3 only for the acts of persons who are actually the person's representative.

These are clarifying amendments to clause 94. The first amendment deletes the existing clause 94 (3) (c) and inserts a new expression which clarifies the circumstances in which a person will be taken to have done an act as a securities representative of another person. Some commentators have interpreted the present clause as only covering conduct within a representative's actual or apparent authority where it was intended also to encompass conduct that was outside the authority. Clause 94 (3) (c) has therefore been amended to make it clear that conduct outside the authority of the representative but done on account of or for the benefit of the principal is included.

Clause 94 (4) has so been amended by deleting the reference to section 813 and substituting a reference to division 4 of part 7.3. The reference to section 813 is no longer necessary as a result of the amendments made to clause 813.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I am not sure what is meant by division 4 of part 7.3, I would point out that the matter raised in this area is one of the items to which I was referring earlier as it relates particularly to an employee in a broking office. It refers to the relationship between principal and agent when the employee acts on what appears to be his own account. There have been cases in the past in the liquidation of certain broking operations where accounts that were incurred by an employee of a broking firm were held to be not its responsibility. That occurred a long time ago, and I am talking about the crash of 1968. Basically I support the principle that every person who is a dealer should be licensed, because by so doing one has some control over the employees. Once one passes on to the concept that one has a member, partner, shareholder or corporation that is held responsible, the background to every dealer must be held in some register. I doubt whether that will do much in terms of the responsibility for these actions. Quite a number of people who are in this position are apt to run dummy accounts. Consequently, certain accounts are left when it comes to the crunch. I bet that in the event of last October a large number of the bad debts were in unidentifiable accounts but in real terms were in the accounts of employees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is some interest in what the honourable member is saying but, if he looks at it from the point of view of the actual wording, he will realise that we are deleting the words `on the other person's behalf'. We are saying that there has to be conduct on account of or for the benefit of the principal. In other words, whilst it might be said that a person was not acting with authority, it would need to be shown that what he did would be for the benefit of the other person. That is probably not giving an absolute liability. In other words, if the person is acting for his or her own benefit, there will be that difficulty.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member is right that there is an argument about whether we would license everybody or take the short course, that is, not license everybody because they are deemed to be in accordance with the licensing principles in that the licensee is already employing them. Rather than put the licensees to the trouble of having to get a licence for everybody, the one licence would cover their employees. That is the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the way it is handled.

—I think the honourable member will find that that is the intention of saying, `you do not have to go to the difficulty of having licences but, if you are acting in accordance with what is deemed to be the authority or for the benefit of another, that is where the question of liability comes in'.

—I respond to the Attorney-General by making a couple of points. Firstly, what he has required them to do is not to license the lesser advisers. However, he has required them at the same time to hold a very substantial register.
—But that is not a difficulty.
—In my view, we are far better off licensing than having a register, which involves a lot of paper work and a lot of responsibility.
—But they are your employees.

—They may be. However, the other aspect the Attorney is referring to is that a person may not act under the authority of his employer, but his actions may result in a profit to the employer. Let me give an example of where I can split hairs with the Attorney. One of the great accounts that one runs as a broker is the overseas arbitrage account. As a member, one very seldom does that. Only the lesser lights do that. If one has a very good employer, he will let the cheap operator go. The best operators for the major firms in Australia run arbitrage accounts which run into millions every night. They are all on the nod. At the end of the day what happens in relation to that? There is a subdivision of those accounts. Some are held offshore and some are held onshore. None of this legislation will go anywhere near that in relation to the responsibility. The Attorney is setting out examples which are all good stuff but, when it gets down to the real operators, the legislation is nowhere near them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman--
—He makes a very good case.

—Yes, he was in practice. The more one listens, the more one realises the dangers of being on the stock exchange if one does not have the experience that the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) has got. The honourable member has made a good case for all the problems that bedevil the stock market. In fact, that might explain why only 14 per cent of people invest in it-they do not have the skill. In the recent crash, to which the honourable member for Ryan referred, there were substantial runs on the fidelity funds. That is the risk, is it not? We are trying to protect and encourage a market in which, if people hold themselves out to represent somebody, the person who employs them ought to have some knowledge of it. I would not think there is any great problem in the suggestion that we have to have a register on that matter. I do not think that is the problem the honourable member is facing. We have to have a register of all these people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Amendments (35) and (36) are largely, as the Attorney-General has claimed, corrections of simple drafting errors or misprints. They are further evidence, as were the previous three items, of the way in which this legislation has been drafted. The kudos the Attorney-General claims because he has allowed this legislation to lie around is somewhat mitigated by the fact that we have in this series of amendments, including the two actually before the Committee, a series of stupid drafting or printing errors with which members of this side of the chamber, and presumably the 36 or 40 faceless men to whom the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) referred in an earlier debate, have had to grapple.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no credit to the draftsmen, the Attorney-General's Department or the Attorney-General himself that we are now considering these amendments under the circumstances of which the honourable member for Ryan complained in the course of today's debate. The basis for that complaint has been that these amendments were put before the Opposition only last night and, in some cases, as recently as this morning. This legislation will have a great impact on the conduct of commerce of this country and, with all its implications for the centralisation in Canberra of power in company law and regulation, it can only be deplored in those terms.

In precise terms amendments (35) and (36) are an extension of sloppy draftsmanship which is careless in the extreme. I imagine that these amendments are quite unnecessary and certainly not justified because this legislation has been around throughout the winter break-for more than two or three months-and the amendment of drafting errors, the correction of simple, even stupid, mistakes should have been put before the Opposition parties long before now. Instead, we have to consider them along with a raft of 280-plus amendments that came up this morning. The Government is to be condemned. Bearing in mind the Attorney-General's advice this morning that at that stage he had not even been briefed on these amendments, I make the point that the evidence in favour of sloppy draftsmanship, sloppy legislative programs and an uncaring approach to the framing of legislation leaves us somewhat bemused and disappointed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased that the clause of this legislation on loans to directors, which is quite lengthy and detailed, is now before us. It is one of those areas covered in the former explanatory memorandum in which we were told that there were no changes to company law; that the present situation would continue. However, there are significant changes. I compliment this aspect of the legislation in so far as it directs itself to one of the great rorts in relation to these affairs. A corporation, be it private or public, which has extensive private loans to the directors, who may or may not be substantial shareholders, is, without any doubt at all, one of the great rorts of corporate life in Australia. In a public sense I point directly to the Holmes a Court situation where, after the great crash, one of the great creditors of the Bell Group was the proprietary company. The actions of that debt were well known in the financial community of Australia-I was tipped off almost immediately that one of the companies that would be significantly hurt in the crash would be the Bell Group. Why? Because the proprietary company was one of the big debtors which lost the brass.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bell Group is no Robinson Crusoe; a lot of companies have the same sort of arrangement with directors. That is one thing in a proprietary company where, presumably, the shareholders have a mutuality, if not a family relationship or a business relationship, but is another thing altogether in a public company in which the citizens of Australia-and indeed, the world-are invited to participate if at the same time, the private company, the principal shareholders or the chairman are being propped up. Frankly this is not on. That is especially so when those loans bring about the demise of what was then one of the major companies in Australia. This certainly had a major impact on the equity market in Australia.

Therefore, some of the proposals here are to be commended. Frankly, I have not had time to read all the ins and outs of these proposals, but my experience tells me that limits on the judgments to be made in this area are quite on target. This will do a fair bit to clean up the Act. Holmes a Court and the Bell Group are not the only ones by any means and it is simply outrageous that investors' equity should be placed at risk by that corporation making loans, either secured or unsecured, to the principal shareholder or the principal director of the corporation involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) for his contribution. I think it was a constructive contribution and I welcome that. He addressed his remarks quite properly to the clause relating to loans to directors.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) took my Department to task. My staff are not to blame; if there is any blame I must bear it. My staff worked very hard on this legislation and I think that it is very unfair to describe this as sloppy drafting, especially as this is a Bill of some size. Let us look at the two matters which concern the honourable member so much. We left out the word `and' and we use a singular instead of a plural. I do not mind criticism, but I do not think it is fair for the honourable member to stand up and suggest that my staff are to blame. They have worked very hard on this legislation. This would not be the first Bill that a government-any government-has brought in that has had to be amended because of errors. I acknowledge that there have been more errors here because the Bill is of such size, but I am disappointed that the people who have been attacked are those who cannot defend themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the comments of the Attorney-General warrant some response. If he is prepared to accept responsibility I am quite willing to allocate it to him. He accepted the blame graciously and quite properly because the buck does stop with him and he said that in general he accepted that proposition. However, he did not accept it this morning when he said that he had not been briefed on these matters. Although he did not seek to escape his ultimate responsibility in this matter, he at least gave us room to suspect that implicitly he did not accept a whole lot of responsibility because, in various contexts, he said that the business community had sought and insisted upon a great many of the 300 to 400 amendments to the Bills that we are considering today.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Attorney-General accepts that responsibility it is no credit to him, but he should then clarify the explanations that he made earlier in the debate because they are not consistent with what he has just said. It was just a question of taking an opportunity in a sequence of crazy, unnecessary errors which were only notified to the Opposition parties as recently as last night. It is only a short while since we have received the corrections to these drafting errors or printing errors or whatever the Attorney-General likes to call them. I accept the Attorney-General's assurance that these errors were not due to the sloppy work of his Department. But we only got to know of these errors last night. They have been around for three or four months, as I said in my earlier remarks which gave rise to the Attorney-General's response. I simply say that he has allowed members of the Opposition to develop their views and opinions on the basis of legislation which has lain on the table for two or three months.

The Attorney came into the Parliament earlier today and complained that we are not at all happy with the legislation, and in fact that we are opposed to it. Yet we did not receive the courtesy of having even the simple, obvious errors explained to us, let alone those which the Attorney now attributes to the wishes of the business community-and I should put business community in inverted commas-following remarks I have already made in this committee discussion. If I was wrong in allocating responsibility, I will accept the Attorney's view. But it is simply not good enough just to say that I have risen to query a few simple errors. They are a few simple errors but they happen to be in succession in the order of amendments as we have them before us tonight, and this seemed like a good time to raise the matter. However they are also errors about which the Opposition parties should have been notified long before last night.
