SPEECH.PARA: (40) Clause 290, page 254, lines 15 to 42 and page 255, lines 1 to 12, omit subclauses (10) to (15), substitute the following subclauses:
``(10) Where the directors of a holding company make an application under subsection (4) in relation to a subsidiary:
(a) subsection (1) does not apply in relation to the subsidiary until the determination day for the application; and

(b) subject to subsection (12), the period within which the directors of the holding company are required to comply with subsection (1) in relation to the subsidiary is the period of 12 months beginning on that day.
``(11) Subsection (10) has effect despite sections 41 and 44a of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.

``(12) Where an order is made under this section authorising a subsidiary of a holding company to have, or to adopt, a financial year that does not coincide with that of the holding company, compliance with the order (including any limitations, terms or conditions set out in it) shall be taken to be compliance with subsection (1) in relation to the subsidiary.

``(13) Where the directors of a holding company make an application under subsection (4) in relation to a subsidiary, the directors of the holding company are not entitled to make another application under subsection (4) in relation to the subsidiary within 3 years after the determination day for the first-mentioned applications unless:
(a) the first-mentioned application resulted in the making of an order granting the application or granting it subject to limitations, terms or conditions; or
(b) the Commission is satisfied that there has been a substantial change in the relevant facts or circumstances since that day.
``(14) In this section:
`determination day', in relation to an application under subsection (4), means:
(a) if the Tribunal makes a decision on an application for review of the Commission's decision on the application under subsection (4)-the day when:
(i) if there is an appeal from the Tribunal's decision-any appeal arising out of the Tribunal's decision is finally determined or otherwise disposed of; or
(ii) otherwise-the Tribunal's decision comes into operation;

(b) if paragraph (a) does not apply but an application is, or applications are, made to the Tribunal for review of the Commission's decision on the application under subsection (4)-the day of withdrawal or dismissal of the application, or of the last of the applications to be withdrawn or dismissed; or
(c) otherwise-the day when the Commission's order on the application under subsection (4) is served on the holding company.''.

This amendment is consequent upon the removal of the right to appeal to a court against a decision of the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) and the substitution of a right of review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT). The effect of the consequential changes is that where an application to the ASC is made for an order authorising a subsidiary to have a financial year that does not coincide with that of its holding company, firstly, no action to ensure coinciding financial years is necessary until 12 months after the determination day-that is, the day when any AAT decision relating to the application comes into operation, any appeal arising out of an AAT decision is determined, an application to the AAT is withdrawn or dismissed, or in any other case, the day when the ASC's order on the application is served on the holding company-and secondly, no further application may be made to the ASC in relation to a subsidiary within three years after the determination day unless the ASC's order granted the application, conditionally or otherwise, or the ASC is satisfied there has been a substantial change in the relevant factual circumstances since that day.
Again this relates to the issue we discussed earlier. There would be a right of review by the AAT, but after that of course there would be a right of appeal to the court.

``(2) Where a person has, or proposes to enter into, an agreement with another person:

(c) under which the other person may be required to dispose of shares in accordance with the first-mentioned person's directions;
then, whatever other effect the agreement may have, the first-mentioned person is entitled to those shares.''.

The amendments narrow the range of an associate's relevant interests to be included in a person's entitlement to shares for the purposes of clause 609. Clause 609 (2) was specifically drafted to rectify an anomaly in the equivalent cooperative scheme provisions in relation to acquisition agreements by limiting the entitlement to only those shares the subject of the agreement. In trying to extend this exception to other agreements giving rise to associations it became apparent that another fundamental problem existed in relation to the scope of clause 609's application.

Where an agreement gave rise to an association under paragraphs 12 (1) (d), (f) or (g), then both parties to the agreement became associates of each other. Accordingly, under clause 609 (1) (b) each had the relevant interests of the other attributed to them. Thus, even the person proposing to sell the shares had his associate's shares attributed to his entitlement. This result was clearly anomalous as it was intended under both the cooperative scheme provisions and the Corporations Bill that the section should operate only in relation to persons who had acquired, or were about to acquire, shares or power to control shares. The amendments ensure that this intention is given effect to.

Downstream acquisition resulting from acquisition of shares in a listed company
``629. Section 615 does not apply in relation to an acquisition of shares in another company if:
(a) at the time of the last-mentioned acquisition, the other company is a listed company; and
(b) the acquisition of the shares in the other company:
(i) results from the acceptance of an offer to acquire those shares that was made under a takeover scheme or takeover announcement; or
(ii) would, but for subsection 620 (1) or (2), contravene section 615.''.

The new clause 629 incorporates two changes. The requirement that the listed upstream company have control, that is 20 per cent or greater shareholding, of the downstream company before clause 629 exemption operated has been removed because its inclusion may have produced unintended consequences, for example, allowing the listed upstream company to more easily discourage takeovers. An additional requirement is inserted for the exemption to apply. The upstream acquisition must be made pursuant to a takeover scheme or takeover announcement. This will clarify and buttress the takeover provisions in so far as they apply to holding companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the convoluted way in which this Bill has been strung together to get heads of power and the fact that holding companies appear to be beyond the realm of the Commonwealth statute, this clause appears to me to have a number of question marks hanging over its head. If Federal power under the Constitution does not extend to holding companies, how is it proposed to have any control whatsoever over acquisitions up or down a chain relating to holding companies? I think this is one of the very doubtful areas of the whole operation, one in respect of which I do not think the Government has a leg to stand on, as far as I can interpret it, unless the High Court of Australia wants to change what I think is the interpretation of law today. Given that, the whole basis of this clause is a waste of time.

—What the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) has said, of course, is going to be the subject of a challenge. I think that is true. The fact that we pass laws does not prevent a challenge. At least, when the High Court of Australia deals with the matter we will know the extent of the power which there is confusion about. That is the way this will develop because we have been unable to do anything else. We cannot get the arrangement that we thought we might have been able to get on the basis of a scheme that there would be no doubt about. Therefore we just cannot abdicate the responsibility which we feel we have. The question of power, though, will be the subject of High Court litigation.

—That does not answer the question; it only makes an attempt to answer the question as it relates to a holding company. This clause relates to the acquisition of shares that are in the chain of a company. If the holding company falls to the ground, the whole basis of chain acquisitions under this Act falls to the ground. There have been countless examples in recent times of acquisitions being made within, shall we say, a corporate relationship in which there may be a holding company or a series of minority holdings. I am not talking about major companies. There is a lesser group in my mind at the moment which operates in the mining sector, Sydney based, and which has a very dubious record in relation to shareholders. Acquisitions by this group have been the flow-on from minority shareholdings and the shareholders outside that group have been grossly disadvantaged. This proposition does nothing at all to address that, putting to one side the holding company problems under the Constitution. The Attorney-General has to answer the question about acquisitions of this lesser type when minority shareholdings become dominant and majority shareholders in some cases get a much poorer deal because of the way in which the minority or major shareholdings have been able to manipulate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment is saying that there is a requirement that the upstream acquisition be made pursuant to the takeover scheme or takeover announcement. This will buttress the take-over provisions in so far as they apply to holding companies. That is the whole point. I think it is an attempt to give people the same entitlement as others.

SPEECH.PARA: (97) Clause 710, page 519, line 36, omit paragraph (a), substitute the following paragraph:

This amendment will bring clause 710 into line with clause 709 (3) (a) in not necessarily requiring a form to be prescribed for the lodgment of notice of a change in substantial shareholding. Clause 710 (3) (a) presently requires a substantial shareholding form to be lodged in all circumstances prescribed. The proposed new paragraph 710 (3) (a) will be required only if a form is prescribed. The complexity of the present form has caused difficulties. Notice will still be required to be given even if a form is not prescribed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the areas of change in the legislation. As a consequence of that it is worth spending a few moments on it. Currently, once a person reaches a 10 per cent shareholding he has an obligation to notify his shareholding on the prescribed form, which has some difficulties. Under section 260, I think it is, there are also tracer provisions which allow the corporate entity in a defensive situation to let loose section 260 to find out exactly who these people are and to see whether they are a collection of nominee companies. In the new Bill, the notification has dropped from 10 per cent to 5 per cent. As I understand it, the rather onerous form has been dropped to a very simple form of notifying that one is a holder of 5 per cent or over. The tracer provisions have been dropped.

SPEECH.PARA: The consequences of that move are quite significant. First, the benefit of the tracer provisions is apparent when it is remembered that a large number of companies in Australia have been subject to pincer-type movements through nominee companies, both onshore and offshore, but more notable notably offshore, and bank nominees have been one of the more generous places to handle these operations. It has been possible to pass the 20 per cent limit through a variety of concoctions in this way, and I will identify some of the operations of Industrial Equity which have used devices that are totally within the letter of the law but may not be in the spirit of the law. The proposed change is to make 5 per cent equity the level at which one must notify the company of one's position. Taking away the tracer provisions does very little to improve the position of knowledge. The association between various shareholdings, especially dealing with foreign companies, can make this provision rather obscure. Therefore, on the whole I do not favour the knocking out of tracing provisions. They do have a benefit. I do not think that the notification of a 5 per centshareholding is terribly relevant these days.

I refer the Attorney-General to the fact that in the late 1960s the AMPs of this world would buy only 5 per cent of the equity of a company. Today it is up to 20 per cent. Other institutions are moving in the same direction. In five years' time, it is reasonable to assume, that percentage will go higher. Notification of a 5 per cent shareholding seems to me to be fairly redundant as it relates to the sort of operation that the Attorney has in mind in this area. I favour the retention of 10 per cent. I think it will do away with some of the bookwork and some of the notifications. Maybe the form that companies were required to fill in was onerous and probably detracted in some respects. But the realities are that the shareholdings of institutions and the like will get larger rather than smaller. The general idea of dropping down to 5 per cent notification without tracing provisions seems to be out of kilter with the way in which investment trends in Australia are developing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter that the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) referred to is one that I have often been anxious to explore. I have some notes which might be of some assistance. They say that these changes ought to be considered in conjunction with reforms in the tracing procedure which remove the capacity of a company or shareholder to issue tracing notices and to confine the power to require disclosure of beneficial ownership. Tracing notices have been extensively used even for small transactions, and company resources previously expended in this area will be more readily available for more productive purposes. By lowering the substantial shareholder notification threshold information regarding significant holdings, the company will be available to the market without the need to resort to any tracing procedure which can be costly and capable of frustration.

SPEECH.PARA: Disclosure of 5 per cent shareholdings will provide investors and potential investors with greater information on developments in a company's ownership, and such information may play a crucial role in investment or disinvestment decisions. The new requirement for notification of only one per cent incremental changes-previously any change-will assist in lowering the paper burden for companies. Notification procedures have been simplified and notification will no longer be required to be in accordance with the prescribed form. The 5 per cent notification threshold already applies in the United Kingdom and the United States and is included in the proposed New Zealand legislation.

I understand that what the honourable member for Ryan is concerned about is the tracing procedure. I often thought that it would not be too difficult at the time of disclosure to also indicate for whom the ownership was held. I think it is a matter that companies might look at. It obviously has been considered. It would appear that they think they are reducing the paperwork, but the honourable member for Ryan is more interested in keeping the tracing provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suspect that the argument about the cost of tracing is fairly illusory. All companies at every board meeting manage to trot up for the benefit of directors all the significant shareholdings and all significant share movements since the last meeting. That is a common practice. To say that it will be a great cost to the companies is a lot of nonsense. I do not subscribe to that. It seems to me that in these days, when corporations pay an enormous amount of attention to their shareholdings, a 5 per cent notification threshold might give more joy to the directors of major companies than does the 10 per cent. The cost involved is neither here nor there.

Client may apply to Court for partial rescission

``799a. (1) If the client gives a notice under section 798 but the notice does not rescind the agreement because rescission of it would prejudice a right or estate of the kind referred to in section 799, the client may, within a reasonable period after giving notice, apply to the Court for an order under subsection (4) of this section.

``(4) On an application under subsection (1), the Court may make an order:

(a) varying the agreement in such a way as to put the client in the same position, as nearly as can be done without prejudicing such a right or estate acquired before the order is made, as if the agreement had not been entered into; and
(b) declaring the agreement to have had effect as so varied at and after the time when it was originally made.
``(5) If the Court makes an order under subsection (4), the agreement shall be taken for the purposes of section 800 to have been rescinded under section 799.

The new clause provides in effect for court assisted partial rescission of contracts with unlicensed dealers. Under clause 799, a notice of rescission given to a client has the effect of rescinding the agreement unless the rescission would prejudice third party rights. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (119) Clause 850, page 612, line 21, omit ``Defence'', substitute ``Defences''.
(120) Clause 850, page 612, at the end of the clause add the following subclauses:
``(2) Where:
(a) a dealer or investment adviser, or a representative of a dealer or investment adviser:
(i) when making a recommendation orally, fails to disclose; or
(ii) when making a recommendation in writing, fails to set out in that writing;
as required by subsection 849 (2), particulars of a matter;
(b) in the case of a representative of a dealer or investment adviser-by making the recommendation, the representative does an act as a representative of the dealer or investment adviser;

(c) it is proved that the dealer or investment adviser had in operation, throughout a period beginning before the decision to make the recommendation was made and ending after the recommendation was made, arrangements to ensure that:
(i) the natural person who made the decision knew nothing about the matter before the end of that period; and
(ii) no advice with respect to the making of the recommendation was given to the person by anyone who knew any-thing about that matter; and
(d) it is also proved that:
(i) the person in fact knew nothing about that matter before the end of that period; and
(ii) no such advice was so given;
the failure is not a contravention of that subsection.
``(3) Neither of subsections (1) and (2) limits the generality of the other.''.

The amendments provide an additional defence to a possible breach of clause 849 (2). Doubts have been expressed that companies and firms operating Chinese walls-despite the defence currently offered by clause 850-may still be in breach of clause 849. `Chinese wall' is a term used to describe a set of internal rules and procedures established by a firm for the purpose of preventing sensitive information known to one part of the firm from being communicated to other parts of the firm. The problem has been overcome in effect by expressly referring to Chinese walls in the defence provision. It will mean that anyone, including directors or partners, who is enclosed by an adequate Chinese wall will not have to disclose interests of associates, et cetera, on the other side of the wall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The provision that the Attorney referred to as the Chinese wall is one of the more fascinating provisions in the financial community. It comes about through the development in Australia of stockbroking firms, dealing with just a few shares, to the money market, to acquisitions to a corporate division and, ultimately, to institutional shareholdings-and the division between institutional broking business and personal broking business. I think that the broking community has a right to make judgments on what these days are fashionably called Chinese wall agreements. Nevertheless, in some cases, such as the Patrick Partners case of years ago, it is very difficult to say that some people knew and some people did not. Nothing has happened since the Patrick Partners case that has made some aspects of the Chinese wall any more secure.

SPEECH.PARA: While I fully understand the approach of people who operate in the financial markets to attempt to divisionalise, to keep separate records and to keep things apart-indeed, many London merchant banks and American banks go to enormous lengths to keep their various divisions apart-we must remember that ultimately, in all these things the piper calls the tune and, therefore, the ownership of these concerns must have some ultimate responsibilities, including those of policy setting. While I have great sympathy for and understand this completely, I think that the partners of a stockbroking firm or, as is the case these days, the directors and proprietors of corporations which own broking merchant banking money market arms will be increasingly hard put, in the one house, to defend the Chinese wall position.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman raises an issue which is of concern but, as I understand the practicalities, firms are getting so large now that they really do not know what one partner might be dealing with; indeed, it could be on the other side of the fence from what another partner is dealing with. That is happening in legal firms these days. There is a proliferation of firms which have many hundreds of partners acting for clients and who perhaps find themselves in the end acting against each other. It is one of the difficulties which have arisen. I can see that there are difficulties, but nobody is suggesting that we can reduce their size in the event of a conflict of interest. Disclosure was, and still would be, the normal course to take, except if there is an entitlement to raise a defence. There is an entitlement to raise a defence-it is not an excuse-if it can be proved that there should have been disclosure of these matters.

—I refer to what occurred in America when the anti-trust laws got under way. That country is far bigger than Australia and the companies involved are bigger. I refer, for example, to the J. Pierpont Morgan empire. He was instructed to separate his investment arm from his general banking arm. So there was Morgan Guaranty down the road, Morgan Stanley up the road and there was also a third wing. Those wings were very clearly defined on the basis of the decision made in those days on the anti-trust law. I do not think that we have reached anywhere near that stage in Australia. We are seeing that some major international banks are now significant shareholders in Australian banks, merchant banks or brokers. They have different ideals and different business principles. In the days of partnerships there was a sense of great personal responsibility, both in a commercial sense and in a personal standing sense. These days that is not so. As those personal responsibility levels fall and corporate involvement rises, one must look at the question of real commercial responsibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) is quite right to talk about responsibility. In fact, clause 849 states that a client must be told. That is the responsibility. Clause 850 deals with the defence to an alleged breach. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the person was not, and could not reasonably be expected to have been, aware of that matter when making the recommendation . . .

Because of the great increase in size of firms, they may decide to establish internal rules and procedures which prevent sensitive information from one part of the firm becoming known to the another. So the defence position is dealt with in that clause. There ought to be a clear understanding that there is not an exemption. If it is proved that a person could not reasonably be expected to have been aware of a matter, that is a defence to what would have been an offence under clause 849.

The honourable member is right to raise the matter. He is virtually saying that the responsibility ought to be to ensure that information is available throughout the whole firm. It should be known if the firm is supposed to have set up procedures to guarantee compartmental arrangements so that information would not be passed from one part of the firm to another. It is very difficult. I accept what the honourable member said. We are basically dealing with an opportunity for a person to say, `I couldn't reasonably be expected to have been aware because my firm has this arrangement'-it ought to be able to prove this-`for rules and procedures which prevent information from one part of the firm being made available to the other parts of the firm. Therefore, I was not aware of something which another part of the firm knew about'. It is a defence to the requirement that a client be told of an adviser's interest. That is the way in which it has been drafted.

Adviser who breaches this Division liable to compensate client
``852. (1) This section applies where:
(a) a securities adviser contravenes section 849 or 851 in relation to a securities recommendation to a person (in this section called the `client');
(b) the client, in reliance on the recommendation, does, or omits to do, a particular act;

``(2) Subject to subsections (3) and (4), the securities adviser is liable to pay damages to the client in respect of that loss or damage.

``(3) In the case of a contravention of section 849, the securities adviser is not so liable if it is proved that a reasonable person in the client's circumstances could be expected to have done, or omitted to do, as the case may be, that act in reliance on the recommendation even if the securities adviser had complied with that section in relation to the recommendation.

``(4) In the case of a contravention of section 851, the securities adviser is not so liable if it is proved that the recommendation was, in all the circumstances, appropriate having regard to the information that, when making the recommendation, the securities adviser had about the client's investment objectives, financial situation and particular needs.''.

This amendment deletes clause 852 and replaces it with a new provision that requires a more appropriate causal connection between the damages a client suffers and the breach of clause 849 or 851 as the case may be. This problem also existed with section 65a of the Securities Industry Act, the predecessor of clause 852. This new clause requires a causal connection through the mechanism of providing the securities adviser with a defence to a claim for damages if the adviser can show no causal connection exists.

SPEECH.PARA: (137) Clause 1006, page 697, lines 35 to 38, omit paragraph (f), substitute the following paragraphs:

``(f) a person named, with the consent of the person, in the prospectus as a stockbroker, sharebroker or underwriter of the corporation or for or in relation to the issue or proposed issue of securities;

(138) Clause 1006, page 697, line 41, omit ``or (f)'', substitute ``, (f) or (fa)''.

The effect of these amendments will be to modify the liability of auditors, bankers, solicitors and other advisers named in a prospectus so that they will bear more appropriate liability for the function they perform in relation to a prospectus. Clause 1006 requires persons responsible for a prospectus, including professional advisers named with their consent in a prospectus, to compensate subscribers who suffer loss as a result of a misleading or deceptive prospectus.

As a result of these amendments, auditors, bankers, solicitors and other advisers named in a prospectus will bear liability for matters for which they are responsible in the prospectus or for statements they make in the prospectus. The liabilities of underwriters, stockbrokers and sharebrokers have not been similarly limited because they are in practice intimately involved in the structuring and preparation of a prospectus. However, these persons will continue not to be liable for any information supplied by directors or company officers on which they have reasonably relied.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment represents a quite significant change from the original and, of course, reflects the 36 faceless men. They have a healthy dose of self-interest in this area as they are the ones who were very heavily involved in the provision of advice and, therefore, would have been more harshly treated under the original proposal than they would be under these amendments. I am not surprised that they put them up.

SPEECH.PARA: I mentioned earlier in the debate the predicament one has in an underwriting agreement and a prospectus. Underwriting agreements always have a number of out clauses in them which provide the brokers or underwriters with their ultimate recourse in the case of some form of catastrophe. We saw many examples in the post-19 October crash of those out clauses being used by underwriters in relation to proposed issues. As I read this amendment, a large number of expert advisers have limited their exposure to liability under the legislation, whereas before they appear to have had a more general responsibility. If that is the case, I can well understand it. However, it does not hang together too well to see the experts watering down their direct responsibilities at the same time as we have prospectuses being taken away from the purview of the relevant commission-either the National Companies and Securities Commission or the proposed new Commission.

On the one hand we are saying, `Do not worry about having reviews of the prospectus because, to quote one of the people involved, we are such a small club, we know each other and would not do the wrong thing'. On the other hand we are saying that those provisions are too hot and we will have to cut them down a bit. The amendment is an attempt to have it both ways, and the Government has modified its position in relation to this matter. I only point to the fact that the Attorney-General must have been advised by a very small group of people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that that is necessarily the case. The difficulty the business community has had has been the necessity for registration of the Part A statements and matters of that nature which it felt were difficult to get through in time. After all, the business community still felt a responsibility because it gave professional advice that people would rely on. The people vetting these prospectuses were not necessarily looking at the issue in relation to the professionalism of the advice. This Bill was drafted on the basis that when a prospectus was issued and there was no vetting arrangement, there would be a liability in the prospectus.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the explanation here is that whilst a prospectus might cover a number of experts, whether they be solicitors or geologists or whatever, they would all make their own contribution to that prospectus.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr LIONEL BOWEN

TALK.START.PARA: —I was making the point that the clause, as drafted, provided for complete liability with respect to the prospectus and one could not then avoid that liability, even though the contribution by a professional adviser was completely valid but was some mis-information or disinformation, for example, by another part of the professional aspect of the prospectus. The amendment provides that one will bear liability for the professional advice that one gives in the prospectus, but one does not bear liability for someone else's mistake. I think that that has some reasonableness in it. After all, people who read a prospectus rely on the information that is given.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members will notice that we have done a fair bit of this also in the Trade Practices Act with respect to architects and engineers. They are able to limit their liability on the basis that they do not want to be liable for anything other than the advice that they give. I can understand that, if someone suffers damage, something must have gone wrong with some part of the prospectus. It does not prevent a person from making a claim; it simply prevents everybody involved in the prospectus from being liable, rather than limiting it to the actual part that was defective.

TALK.START.PARA: —This once again points to some of the deficiencies in this package. It is an area which the Attorney-General cannot get at. It is one of these areas in respect of which he has to go through the maze. He has to look for constitutional pegs and has failed to find one relating to building societies and friendly societies. If I were to quiz all honourable members about how many had accounts with building societies, I probably would find a majority. One of the great growth areas in investment deposits in Australia in the last 10 years has been building societies. Their influence is quite strong-to the extent that today building societies issue cheque books in their own name. They have, as a consequence of that, relationships with banks and therefore a relationship with a clearing system. That clearing system operates under the banking legislation in Australia. `listed unit trust' means a unit trust the units in which are listed for quotation on a stock market of a stock exchange;
`unlisted corporation' means a corporation other than a listed corporation.
``(2) A prospectus in relation to securities of a corporation is a registrable prospectus unless it is exempt from registration under section 1020A by virtue of this section.
``(3) A prospectus in relation to shares in or debentures of a corporation is exempt from registration under section 1020A if:
(a) the corporation is a listed corporation; or
(b) the corporation is an unlisted corporation and the relevant allotment, issue, offer or invitation is proposed to be made or issued:
(i) in the case of shares-to existing members of the corporation;
(ii) in the case of debentures-to existing holders of debentures of the corporation; or
(iii) in the case of shares or debentures-to:
(A) the trustee of a superannuation fund constituted by or under a law of the Commonwealth, of a State, of a Territory or of a foreign country;
(B) a holder of a dealers licence acting as a principal;
(C) a corporation registered under the Life Insurance Act 1945 or the Financial Corporations Act 1974;
(D) an investment company within the meaning of Part 4.4;
(E) The trustee of a trust that is declared by the Commission to be an equity unit trust and in respect of which there is an approved deed for the purposes of Division 5;
(F) a declared institutional investor; or
(G) if the corporation is an approved unlisted corporation in relation to such shares or debentures-employees of the corporation.
``(4) A prospectus in relation to prescribed interests made available by a corporation is exempt from registration under section 1020a if:
(a) the prescribed interests are interests under a listed unit trust; or
(b) the prescribed interests are not interests to which paragraph (a) applies and the relevant issue, offer or invitation is proposed to be made or issued to:
(i) existing holders of prescribed interests to which the same approved deed relates;
(ii) the trustee of a superannuation fund constituted by or under a law of the Commonwealth, of a State, of a Territory or of a foreign country;
(iii) a holder of a dealers licence acting as principal;
(iv) a corporation registered under the Life Insurance Act 1945 or the Financial Corporations Act 1974;
(v) an investment company within the meaning of Part 4.4;
(vi) the trustee of a trust that is declared by the Commission to be an equity unit trust and in respect of which there is an approved deed for the purposes of Division 5;
(vii) a declared institutional investor; or
(viii) if the corporation is a listed corporation, or is an approved unlisted corporation in relation to such prescribed interests-employees of the corporation.''.

Amendment (147) provides for a new clause which specifies the classes of prospectuses which will not need to be registered under the new clause. The present Bill only requires prospectuses to be lodged and not registered by the Australian Securities Commission (ASC). The Government has accepted the concern that it is desirable to provide additional protection to the general investing public in respect of offerings by unlisted companies. The Bill will now require certain prospectuses to be registered with the ASC.

New clause 1017 adopts a classification for registering prospectuses recommended by the Securities Information Review Committee in its report entitled Reforming the Law Relating to the Offer of Securities. Registration of prospectuses will now be required for the following: listed corporations, unlisted corporations to existing shareholders and debenture holders; unlisted corporations to institutional investors-for example, statutory superannuation funds, finance companies and insurance companies; and approved unlisted corporations to their employees if those corporations have established extensive disclosure policies to keep employees well informed about the operations of the corporations. The rationale for excluding listed corporations from this registration requirement is that the stock exchange scrutinises prospectuses for the purpose of ensuring compliance with listing requirements and listed corporations are subject to a non-market disclosure regime. The rationale for the other exclusions is that the persons for whom the prospectus is issued have sufficient expertise or access to relevant information so as not to require pre-registration vetting by the Australian Securities Commission.

I think it draws a line probably between the professional investor and the ordinary investor, where I think there is a real difference and the protection of the prospectus for the ordinary investor is something for which I think we all have a responsibility.

the corporation complied with the listing rules concerned before the making of the offer, or the issue of the invitation, as the case may be.

``(3) For the purposes of paragraph (2) (b), but without limiting its generality, where an obligation or condition is imposed on a corporation at a particular time, by or under a particular listing rule of a securities exchange, in connection with a particular matter:

This amendment makes three changes to clause 1018. Firstly, an issue of securities will be prohibited unless a registrable prospectus is in fact registered. This new requirement will only apply to those prospectuses such as various prospectuses and securities offered by a list of corporations which are required by the Bill to be registered. Secondly, the present prohibition in clause 1018 (a) on the issue of allotment of securities without a prospectus will be removed. Clause 1018 (a) appears to have given rise to some confusion as to the extent to which the prospectus provisions apply to secondary trading. Thirdly, the trading of securities on the stock market will be exempted from the prospectus provisions where a prospectus relating to those securities has been lodged or where the corporation has complied with the listing requirements applicable to it regarding further information required by the securities exchange in the case of what is called a backdoor or compliance listing.

SPEECH.PARA: (150) After clause 1020, page 704, insert the following clause:
Registration of prospectuses
``1020a. Where a registrable prospectus is lodged, the Commission shall register the prospectus unless:
(a) it appears that the prospectus does not comply with the requirements of this Division; or
(b) the Commission is of the opinion that the prospectus contains a false or misleading statement or that there is an omission from the prospectus''.

This amendment inserts a new clause which sets out the criteria according to which the Australian Securities Commission will register what is called a registrable prospectus. The registration test in the new clause will require the Securities Commission to register a prospectus unless it appears that the prospectus does not comply with the law, or where it contains a matter that it materially false or misleading.

This test differs from the current requirement in the Companies Act which requires the NCSC to refuse to register a prospectus unless it is satisfied about these matters. The new test follows the approach recommended by the Securities Information Review Committee in its report on reforming the law relating to the offer of securities. This reversal of the registration test will give the ASC more flexibility and permit more efficient resource allocation. It will also reduce costs and delays to business in having to comply strictly with sometimes unnecessary and irrelevant rules.

TALK.START.PARA: —The consequence of this amendment is that it will switch the responsibility from the Commission to the lodgers of the prospectus. Here it is being said that the Commission shall register the prospectus-unless. It is not a question of making a judgment of the contents of the prospectus, but rather saying that `it appears that the prospectus does not comply with the requirements of this division-which is a very gentle test-or `the Commission is of the opinion that the prospectus contains a false or misleading statement...'. A considerable degree of expertise has been built up to handle prospectuses. Admittedly, some areas have been slower than others, but this amendment will eliminate in one swoop the need for expertise and rather reduces the question of the operation of registration of prospectuses with the Commission to one of checking signatures.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member would know that there can be all sorts of fluctuations in the market. This is the biggest danger. In a small market with the investment funds all chasing the same shares one gets speculation and there might not be adequate remuneration in regard to dividend.

SPEECH.PARA: (166) After clause 1123, page 779, insert the following new clause:
Using eligible communications services in connection with unauthorised futures markets
``1123a. A person shall not use an eligible communications service in the course of, for the purposes of, or otherwise in connection with:
(a) the person establishing, conducting, or assisting in establishing or conducting, an authorised futures market; or
(b) holding out that the person conducts an unauthorised futures market.''.

This amendment is intended to reduce the possibility of unauthorised futures markets emerging. It complements clauses 1123, 1124 and 1125 in this respect. The amendment was prepared to allay the concerns of the Sydney Futures Exchange about the possible emergence of what are called `bucket shops'. Overseas experience has shown that trading is frequently rigged on unauthorised markets with the object of fraudulently misappropriating investors' funds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two aspects to this amendment. Firstly, in the whole of this maze, this is one of the pegs that the Attorney-General has found to give some constitutional grounds for putting together this legislation. This is the communications power. It has come out of the glad bag-one can put in one's hand and pull out what one can get. This time we have come up with communications. In this case we have excused the use of communications by saying that the Sydney futures market is concerned about any competition. It is astonishing that the Government should interpret `any competition' as the establishment of bucket shops all around the place.

SPEECH.PARA: The futures market in Australia started many years ago in a very small way with the greasy wool futures market, and developed into its current operations no more than 10 years ago. In the United States of America there are quite a number of futures markets, the best known being Chicago. However, the American futures market is not restricted to Chicago; it is found in a number of places. At present in Australia it is basically a one-city operation based in Sydney with a large number of members, both from overseas and within Australia. To attempt for a start to place the mantle of monopoly on the Sydney futures market and say that because of its request we will use that excuse to dredge up one of the constitutional powers to hang the whole corporate package on is to have a pretty weak excuse all round and one which ought to be shown for what it is.
Proposed new clause agreed to.

Amendment (167) relaxes the requirement for all members of the Futures Exchange to be incorporated. Individuals or other non-corporate entities may become and remain members of an exchange under this amendment where they deal on behalf of other persons and they do so as representatives of a licensed futures broker. However, if a member wishes to deal directly on behalf of an investor, he must be incorporated. The Sydney Futures Exchange is currently encouraging individuals and other non-corporate entities to become members of, and gain access, to, the Exchange so as to develop greater depth and liquidity in the market. The amendment enables that initiative to continue.

Amendments (168) to (174) relate to clause 1132. The consequential amendments to clause 1126 (2) (d) vary the wording of the clause to recognise that some members of a futures exchange may not be incorporated. These amendments are consequential to amendment (167), which replaces the requirement for all members of a Futures Exchange to be incorporated.

The reason for the great requirement for futures exchange members to be incorporated is that under the Constitution the Government can lay its hands only on incorporated bodies and not individuals. As a result of that, the Government has had a chat with the Sydney Futures Exchange and suggested that everyone should be incorporated. It is rather strange that under the current taxation law the Government will be doing itself out of a few bob if it does that.
—Ten per cent.

—Ten per cent is swinging around in the wind at present. From what we hear, the guys paying the top rates are not going to get any relief. So there are no prospects of getting off the hook in that respect. The Government will give them a 10 per cent break on taxation if they incorporate. It wants them all to incorporate because that is the only way in which this can be made to work. This is another one of the cons that have been put forward to make this whole thing stand up.

SPEECH.PARA: (186) After clause 1141, page 793, insert the following new clause in Part 8.2:
Qualified privilege in respect of disciplinary proceedings
``1141a. (1) In this section:
`disciplinary proceeding', in relation to a futures organisation, means:
(a) a proceeding under the business rules of the futures organisation that may result in the disciplining of a member of the futures organisation; or
(b) an appeal under the business rules of the futures organisation from a proceeding of a kind referred to in paragraph (a);
`disciplining', in relation to a member of a futures organisation, includes expulsion from, or suspension of, membership of the futures organisation;
`member', in relation to a futures organisation, includes a person who is under an obligation to comply with or enforce the business rules of the futures organisation.

``(2) A futures organisation, or a member, officer or employee of a futures organisation, has qualified privilege in respect of a statement made by a person, orally or in writing, in the course of, or otherwise for the purpose of or in connection with, a disciplinary proceeding of the futures organisation.
``(3) A person has qualified privilege in respect of the publication of:
(a) a statement made by a person, orally or in writing, in the course of, or otherwise for the purposes of or in connection with; or
(b) a document prepared, given or produced by a person, in the course of, or otherwise for the purpose of or in connection with;
a disciplinary proceeding of a futures organisation.''.

This new clause provides qualified privilege to futures organisations, their members, officers or employees in respect of statements made by them arising out of disciplinary proceedings of the organisation. It is based on clause 779, which has a similar effect in relation to disciplinary proceedings of securities exchanges. The clause recognises the importance of the publication of the results of disciplinary proceedings as a deterrent in addition to and instead of a fine or other penalty. It also protects persons who made adverse comments in the course of disciplinary proceedings, because without this protection they might not be so candid.

Client may apply to Court for partial rescission

``1165a. (1) If the client gives a notice under section 1164 but the notice does not rescind the agreement because rescission of it would prejudice a right or estate of the kind referred to in section 1165, the client may, within a reasonable period after giving the notice, apply to the Court for an order under subsection (4) of this section.
``(2) The Court may extend the period for making an application under subsection (1).

``(3) If an application is made under subsection (1), the Court may make such orders expressed to have effect until the determination of the application as it would have power to make if the notice had rescinded the agreement under section 1165 and the application were for orders under section 1166.
``(4) On an application under subsection (1), the Court may make an order:

(a) varying the agreement in such a way as to put the client in the same position, as nearly as can be done without prejudicing such a right or estate acquired before the order is made, as if the agreement had not been entered into; and
(b) declaring the agreement to have had effect as so varied at and after the time when it was originally made.
``(5) If the Court makes an order under subsection (4), the agreement shall be taken for the purposes of section 1166 to have been rescinded under section 1165.
``(6) An order under subsection (4) does not affect the application of section 1168 or 1170 in relation to the agreement as originally made or as varied by the order.''.

The amendment inserts a new clause to provide, in effect, for court assisted partial rescission of contracts with unlicensed futures brokers and advisers. Under clause 1165 a contract with a non-licensee may be rescinded unless rescission would prejudice third party rights. The proposed new clause deals with the situation where a contract between a client and an unlicensed person relates to a variety of transactions only some of which affect third party rights. The proposed new clause would enable the contract to be partially rescinded in so far as the contract relates to transactions not affected by third party rights.

``PART 9.4a-REVIEW BY ADMINISTRATIVE APPEALS TRIBUNAL OF CERTAIN DECISIONS
Interpretation
``1317a. In this Part:
`decision' has the same meaning as in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975.
Applications for review
``1317b. (1) Subject to this Part, applications may be made to the Tribunal for review of a decision made under this Act by:
(a) the Minister;
(b) the Commission; or
(c) the Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board.

``(2) For the purposes of this Act and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal 1975, the Commission shall be taken to be a person whose interests are affected by a decision made under this Act by the Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board.
Excluded decisions
``1317c. Section 1317b does not apply in relation to:
(a) a decision in respect of which any provision in the nature of an appeal or review is expressly provided by this Act;
(b) a decision that is declared by this Act to be conclusive or final or is embodied in a document declared by this Act to be conclusive evidence of an act, matter or thing;
(c) a decision by the Minister to make, or to refuse to make, a declaration under subsection 112 (3);
(d) a decision made by the Commission in the performance of a function, or in the exercise of a power, under section 342 or 350 or Division 8 of Part 5.6; or
(e) a decision by the Commission to refuse to exercise a power under section 342 or 350 or Division 8 of Part 5.6.''.

The amendment confers general jurisdiction on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (AAT) to review decisions of the Minister, the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) and the Companies Auditors and Liquidators Disciplinary Board made under the legislation. This replaces the general jurisdiction of the courts under the cooperatives scheme legislation to review decisions on their merits. The main exceptions to the AAT review will be declarations made by the Corporations and Securities Panel of unacceptable conduct during a takeover-an AAT review is inappropriate given the special function of the Panel, which itself will be an independent body of experts; acts of the Commission relating to defunct companies or restoration of a company's name to the register; and quasi-legislative decisions such as accounting standards made by the Accounting Standards Review Board or decisions by the Minister declaring that an unincorporated body consisting of up to a specified number of persons may carry on a specified profession.

Unlike other provisions conferring jurisdiction on the AAT, there will be no requirement for the decision-maker to notify persons affected by reviewable decisions of their right to an AAT review. This is because of the difficulty in identifying the persons affected and the fact that the business community could be expected to be well advised of its entitlements and should not require the same level of protection as individuals affected by other reviewable decisions. Of course, and ASC and other decision-makers could voluntarily notify individuals of their right to an AAT review in appropriate cases.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Lionel Bowen) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now 14 hours since debate on the Corporations Bill started. It has been what we might describe as lengthy, drawn out, protracted, tedious and all the rest of it. It is quite remarkable, What must be going on in the legislation committee of Cabinet to allow Bills such as this to come out in this form, unread--
—Order! The honourable member for Ryan can speak to the matters that have been adopted by the House. He has to speak to the Bill itself as it has been adopted, not have general debate on matters--
—He is talking about the commas.
—The honourable member for Deakin might not be here long enough to participate in the debate if he continues.

—I am talking about all the amendments, all the corrections, that have been made to the Bill. It is quite remarkable that a Bill of this type and character can come out with 270-odd amendments, and take 14 hours, with a few subtractions, to get through the House. It is the responsibility of the Cabinet legislation committee to ensure that those sorts of things do not take place. It has not been a great month for the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). He has gone down badly--

—Order! The matters that the honourable member is debating are not allowed to be canvassed in the very constricted area of a third reading debate. The honourable member must speak to the Bill that was passed by the House at the second reading stage, not what happens with the Cabinet, the Attorney-General or anything such as that.
—I am getting to that, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—You had better get to it rather quickly.

—The effect of the legislation and of the amendments that have been brought about today have been the consequence of the advisings of the 36 faceless men. They advertised around Australia for brand new types of amendments or upgradings in relation to this legislation. They got 20 responses. From those 20 responses we dredged up 270 amendments. One really has to wonder what occurs. While this is going on, no less than four Government inquiries of one nature or another are taking place which will impinge on this legislation. On top of that, the Attorney-General himself said that in November he is to have a meeting with the State Attorneys-General to discuss this legislation. One might wonder what the background to it all is. The total package that has been brought forward involves massive rewrites of company law, significant changes to security legislation, and significant changes to the futures market, but what about the new reforms? What about the share buy-back scheme we have been looking at for nearly a year in the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities? There is no action on that.
—Why not?
—It is not dealt with in the Bill. Where is it dealt with? The Attorney-General has discussed it in the Ministerial Council.
—Order! If the honourable member for Ryan himself admits that the matter is not in the Bill, he shall not canvass it.
—Wake up to yourself.
—I tell you what, Scotty, you wake up this time--
—Order! The honourable member for Ryan will address honourable members by their correct title.

—The Bill that we have put through is unacceptable to the Opposition. We hope that when it eventually goes to a Senate Committee or a joint committee, whichever it may be, it has an appropriate airing in the commercial world of Australia, right around the nation and in all the capital cities, so that the genuine operators of commercial enterprises will have a chance to present their cases on company law, securities laws and futures law. The evidence that has been brought forward to date and taken up in this legislation has been far too narrow and far too self-serving.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Bill was laid on the table in May to enable the public and others to participate. It was not dealt with by faceless people. It was dealt with by people in the real world of business. The amendments, of course, were substantial, but many of them dealt with typographical errors. I think this would be the first time that an Opposition has refused to allow typographical errors to be dealt with immediately.
—The Attorney-General will also address the Bill as it has been passed by the House.

—I am addressing the amendments and the way they were passed. This would be the first time that an Opposition has insisted that every typographical error be explained. I would have thought, if a second reading debate had some merit, that the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) would have picked up the errors himself. He had the Bill for three months.
—How does one get to know what is in the amendments?

—The honourable member would at least have known the errors. It has taken all this time to bring in a number of very incidental amendments which were explained to the honourable member for Ryan by my Department yesterday. He decided to teach the House a lesson tonight and for the first time in history to debate every amendment. He does not often appear here, but he has broken a record today on the basis of the amendments which he knew had to be moved.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

Mr West to move-

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Construction of the National Biological Standards Laboratory, Symonston, ACT.
Mr West to move-

That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Redevelopment of HMAS Coonawarra, Darwin.
Mr Cross to move-
That the House of Representatives speaking for the Government and people of Australia-
(1) welcomes sailors and warships from many parts of the world joining our own Royal Australian Navy in the Bicentennial International Naval Review;
(2) express its appreciation for the friendship and goodwill shown by all participating nations, and

(3) trusts that the welcome extended by Australians not only in Sydney but in many other ports around Australia will build links of friendship and understanding which will assist all our navies and maintain the peace in the years ahead.
